description:
A few nights ago bar hopping we came across this pub and went in to check it out. We ended up not getting drinks and decided to leave but the friendly bouncer told us to come back during the day to eat the food and try the "best fish n chips in SF". The next day at lunch my wife and I were deciding on where to eat for lunch and we decided to try out the Irish Bank. We ordered fish n chips, chicken nachos, and an Irish coffee. 

The bartender was incredibly friendly and attentive and got us our food and drinks quickly. The fish and chips were actually very tasty. The fish seemed to be fresh because the cod was not fishy. It was also breaded nicely and was very fresh. The chicken nachos were not good. We were hungry and ate them all but nothing about them was anything that good. The Irish coffee was also not good. It was much waterier than it should have been and lacked the needed alcohol and chocolate. The speed of the food service was good and the bartender was pretty good considering she had the entire interior of the bar/restaurant to take care of. As for "the best fish and chips in SF", I have nothing to compare it to in SF. They were good though. They were not fishy and tasted fresh to my wife and me.
author: Nico M.

description:
Come for the atmosphere. Skip the food.

We came here for a work happy hour and it was decently packed on a Friday. The patio is one of my favs in the area. It's nothing to look at, but it's spacious and simple and there's always seating. There's a guy that checks ID by the front alley. If you're under 21, you have to stay outside on the patio. 

Their beer selection is okay. Nothing special. I ordered a couple rounds of Smithwicks, which was one of the only Irish beers on tap. They had the usual Guinness, Stella, Harp, Mangers etc. I would love to see them carry more Irish beers on tap.

For food, we tried a little bit of everything. For apps we tried their Mozzarella sticks, chicken wings, and bleu cheese fries. The Mozzarella sticks were generous. It came with way more than the usual 4 or 5. The bleu cheese fries were interesting. It was literally semi melted bleu cheese on steak fries. The fries had no flavor though and the combo of the blue cheese didn't really match that well. Not sure if I would recommend it.

For mains we tired their Bratwurst and Sauerkraut and their Bangers. The sausages were okay. The outside was fried so it was crispy. The mashed potatoes were interesting. I wasn't sure what they added to it, but it had an after taste, almost chemically, so I did not finish them. My coworker loved it, she claimed they tasted very "German."
author: Junella T.

description:
We visit the Irish Bank on Friday evening.
I never saw the seating setting like this before.
The tables were in the alley between the buildings.
Food was good and service acceptable.
author: Dimitre I.

description:
Being that it's nearing St. Patrick's Day, I decided to pick an Irish spot for dinner with a friend in town for a conference.

We shared the shepherd's pie and got the cabbage and corned beef special. Overall, it felt like simple comfort food you'd find at home, with lower than average SF prices to match. 

The shepherd's pie was sweet and tomato-y-- almost reminiscent of something you'd find over rice at a Cantonese cafe. Made of ground beef instead of lamb, at $10 it was surely filling. We were able to replace to baked mashed potato top with a side of fries and added curry for $1. The curry was more a thin British / Asian style, as opposed to Indian curries. Tasty. 3.3/5.

The corned beef was somewhat bland for restaurant food, though the portion was generous. The cabbage was literally boiled cabbage. Horseradish and mustard sauces were fresh and pungent, though standard. 3.3/5, but realistically on taste, a 3/5.

The entire place felt pretty divey, and there was a distinct lack of windows, which made it feel much later than it was. Service was pretty standard.
author: Nicole H.

description: Delicious, battered, tender fish and chips! Compliments to the chef! My partner (who is Irish) ordered the shepherds pie and said it was amazing as well, reminded him of home.
author: Lea C.

description:
The bar inside was packed but there was plenty of seating outside. Love the concept of sitting out in the alley. A vibe that I feel like America doesn't offer as often. 

The bouncer/hostess at the front were nice and made us feel very welcomed! You can also order outside. They were efficient in cleaning up tables and putting away cups. 

Didn't get to try any of the food but got a cider. Would come here again and try other stuff too.
author: Sherluna V.

description:
Fish and chips for the WIN! The Irish Bank cranks out some delicious beer and delectable eats!

I came here for some grub-a-dub-dub before meeting up with some friends at a nearby bar later on in the evening. First off, this little gem is off the beaten path!  If you're walking down Bush street, you'll pass the Akiko Sushi and make an immediate left on Mark lane. You'll see some outdoor seating and then make a left into the bar. 

The atmosphere just screams divey pub! It's dark and low lit with brick walls and rustic wooden tables and chairs. There's a second room that's separated by a curtain for people who are looking to dine in. The bar is lively with loud music and interactive bartenders! Since I was dining solo, I took a seat at the bar and a cute couple chatted me up and kept me company. 

I saw someone order the fish and chips and I knew that I just haaaad to have it! The smell alone was making my mouth water. I also started out with one of those specialty cocktails which was a Smirnoff sourced pineapple Mule! It was a delicious tasting cocktail; it wasn't overly sweet but just sweet enough. I later had a Harp Lager (you know I had to get some beer!) and it was perfectly light and crisp and went perfectly with my fish and chips!

Speaking of those fish and chips; they were the STAR of the show! The chips were nice and thick but weren't dry and had a nice season to them. But that FISH! OMG! Crispy fried HEAVEN! It was so remarkable! Some of the best that I've had in a long time. And the creamy tarter sauce that they served with it?! A winning combo indeed!

 The fish was crispy, flaky, and flavorful! The batter was just perfect, and even after barely finishing my meal, it left me wanting more. The portion size was hefty! I guess it left quite an impression on the couple sitting next to me because they ordered it right after mine came. Only difference was that they spilt theirs' while I devoured mine all by myself! Miss Piggy don't need NO help when it comes to finishing her meals!

The bartenders here are so fun and entertaining! They were laughing and cracking jokes the entire time and it was so fun! I would love to try more of their beers during my next visit and possibly a different entree if my fish and chips craving doesn't get the best of me next time.
author: Shayla B.

description: An Irish bar is a dime a dozen and there wasn't anything really noteworthy about my experience good or bad that would make me come back or stay away. It was a cool vibe in the alley, it was slightly dim inside, and had a bunch of cool trickets on the wall. I mostly wanted a drink and my feet were hurting so I wandered in, nice place. Friendly bartender but not over friendly which is always a good thing too!
author: Patrick A.

description: Amazing service and food. Will return next time I'm in SF. Veggie pie was exceptional. Drinks at the bar were great.
author: Kitty Q.

description: Great fish and chips, drinks, stew, and Shepard's pie...the waitresses we had were super accommodating and so friendly!
author: Samantha S.

description: This is my go-to can't-think-of-anywhere-else-to-go-after-work bar.  Especially great for large groups because there's tons of seating.  Even better on a warm day so you can sit outside.  Sitting outside is more like sitting in alley, but with limited outdoor seating places in SF I'll take what I can get.  The food is typical pub food and you can never go wrong with their chicken tenders and fries.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Damn what a night.!! We come here nightly.. and spend money here... maybe it's busy today with one bartender ?? Well our bartender was giving their own staff shit ??!! He so busy that he couldn't serve us faster...!! He can't keep up with our drinking !! The other clean up staff try to help him out n served us.. but got yelled at from bartender ??? 
We paid the check in full and didn't pay tips for bartender.. and this bartender has time to come over to us.. why we didn't tip him ?? And ask us to Get The FUCK out ??????? REALLy ???? So unprofessional to talk to customers who comes in nightly ......... is he racist ???? Shit service tonight..
author: Crisy G.

description:
This is a great place to get drinks with friends. It had a very dive bar feel inside while seating outside is very casual with plastic chairs and tables. 
The drink menu is great and the prices are very good too. I got a glass of Merlot for $7.00 while my fiends for beer $6.00 and Gin Tonics ( similar pricing). 
We also got the fish and chips and the bank burger which was actually pretty good ! Not the greasy bar food I expected which was awesome. The French fries were excellent and that is how I usually judge the quality of food. Again well priced dishes with good portions. 

We sat outside and I actually had a great time. Reminded me of being on holiday somehow! 
The staff is super friendly and I recommend this place highly ! Will be back !!
author: Shivani B.

description: I really enjoyed this place. The wife and I just popped in for a quick beer before we went to dinner . Overall it was a great experience, sat at the bar, beer selection was great and if you're into whiskey and bourbon they have a great selection. The place has a divy feel which I like and the bartender was a cool dude.
author: Dj K.

description:
I came here to have a quiet beer at their bar on a Friday afternoon and work on my laptop while I waited for traffic to calm down. Ha ha ha, I got jokes. This place is SLAMMED on Friday afternoons during happy hours, and even though I snagged a seat at the bar, I could hardly hear myself think.

I still had two delicious beers and some chicken tenders. The bartender was a nice guy who didn't seem to think it was weird I was working by myself while people yelled their orders behind me. There is some nice seating outside for a more traditional dinner option, even though it looked equally as rowdy. I would definitely come back here with my husband and partake in some yelling of my own. This is a great spot. Cheers!
author: Joanna R.

description:
Are you feeling lucky of being Irish? Well look no further cause this Irish Pub has it all from start to finish! Located at Mark Lane near Grant Avenue and Chinatown's Gate Entrance at Bush Street, the Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant brings the customers to enjoy and taste their finest Irish cuisines and assortments of drinks from Guinness and finest cocktails every day and night! The atmosphere is very laid back and active as I welcomed there. The concept is much like visiting to a local alley bar with tons of tables and seats outside, and on the inside, there's some good vintage wooden interior Irish designs from the past filled with photographs and classic signs across the whole room.

The bartenders, security officers and servers are doing a fine job for accommodating the customers like me an amazing service despite the busiest environment on a bust Saturday afternoon on 3/11/2017. I just hope they need to improve their speediness in the near future someday, but other than that, no issues so far.

Since I haven't got a chance to try on one of their foods due to a larger early St. Patrick's Day party, I ordered a glass of beer of Lagunitas IPA at the main bar side. As I drank it, that beer is simply refreshing and cooling which it gives the best aromas of pale ale and bolder taste. Sensational!

Parking at Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant can be difficult to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the meantime, the Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant is a good, averaged local Irish Pub that I've ever enjoyed and visited there for the first time in 26 years. Perfect for friends and co-workers gathering! A fine visit, and I'll be back for more to try it again! My rating: 3 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: Friendly bartenders and decent whiskey choices. Very chill environment. They have a nice alley to be seated.
author: sarah b.

description:
It was St Patty's week and I was craving the corned beef - but KNEW I could not handle the madness of a lunch on the 17th.

I gathered a bunch of friends from work and my husband (SO 5 ladies and a dude, he enjoyed that part) - we sat inside, in the back - the back door was open and all I could smell was the dumpster, the waitress let me close the door - Whew.

A few peeps ordered the fish and chips and loved them. On gal got the bangers and mash - she said the potatoes were good and that it was overall "okay".

I got the Ruben, and my husband got the stew - which was tasteless.  The Ruben was good, not super greasy - not super huge. And the fries were nice and crispy - if a bit over salted.

The waitress let us put down 6 credit cards! - awesome.
author: Amy W.

description: I came here with some friends for some beers before we headed to the bars. It was pretty decent. We asked to be seated outside and ordered beers. There was one thing that bothered me. One of my friends who happens to be AA went to use the restroom and was followed by the outside security and was told where to go (he already knew) and security also told him if he went in the woman's bathroom he would be kicked out. I thought it was unprovoked and completely unnecessary. I don't think I'd be back. It was okay.
author: Angelica P.

description:
The Irish bank is one of my favorite San Francisco establishments. Particularly on St. Patrick's Day when the entire alley is blocked off and becomes a party complete with live music, drinking, and dancing.  The remaining days of the year, the food is awesome, the drinks are well priced, and you can actually sit and talk (what a concept) while having a beer. 

Some of these reviews are weak as shit. But hey, this is San Francisco and people love to complain...
author: Alexandra F.

description:
Asked for an itemized bill, which showed two charges that were incorrect (bud lights and house drinks, when we only ordered Harp and Stellas the entire time), then only got a $10 discount on the bill....

Based on their questionable business tactics, I probably would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Annie R.

description:
Wow, this place was AWESOME!  We were walking to Chinatown and saw a beautiful gate with Irish Bank on it.  We walked down the alley and it opened up into the outside seating for this bar.  Dating an Irishman, of course we had to try it.  Opening at 11:30, we were two of three patrons who entered as the doors opened.  It was my honey's birthday too.  Drinks were great, tried a new Irish whiskey, Slane.  We shared chicken nachos and those were delicious.  The waiter was cordial and helpful.  The vibe was awesome.  Jazz filled the airwaves while the dimly lit bar displayed tons of Irish photos, news articles and other memorabilia on the walls.  We purchased a rugby jersey there and it was $45 and excellent quality.

Will definitely go back when in the city again.

Only criticism:  We ordered an Irish Car Bomb, to celebrate his birthday and the waiter did NOT pour equal amounts of Guinness in each glass and in mine, it was very foamy (I know...Guinness doesn't have foam, but it was all head and no beer.)
author: KT T.

description:
I went here at around 8pm after having eaten nearly nothing all day, desperate to sate my hunger. I opted for a simple burger and fries, but, noting that the menu described the house burger in no words beyond "8 oz. burger", I decided to ask what exactly was on it. The bartender answered that it's all the usual, "you know, lettuce, tomatoes, whatever." I said that sounded good, and that I'd take one. "Do you want cheese on it?" the bartender responded. Sure, I affirmed. "Okay, that'll be a dollar extra." 

I approved the one-dollar cheese surcharge, but my stomach pre-emptively filled with dread: being charged extra for cheese is never a good sign. 

Eventually my food arrived. The fries were crisp, oil- and salt-free, not too powdery inside, all while maintaining the distinct smell of deep-fried potato. They weren't outstanding, but certainly decent enough for snacking on. 

The burger had been served open-faced, with one side containing the patty and the hundred-cent-cheese-surcharge slice of cheddar on top, which looked suspiciously rectangular and translucent. I'm quite sure that, legally speaking, this was not cheese, rather some kind of imitation-cheese-esque substitute in the vague spirit of cheddar. 

I folded the two halves of the burger into one, and bit into it. I wolfed down a few thoughtless bites -- I was very hungry -- but eventually  I started to register a kind of waxy flavor. Intermingled with the normal taste of char on a patty was the distinct flavor of freshly molten wax (yes, like candlewax). At first I dismissed it -- it might just be a peculiarity of this patty -- but after a few more bites, it dawned on me that maybe this was indicative of a health risk, so I stopped. I couldn't pin down whether the distinct flavor of wax came from the patty, the cheese-in-name-only, or the bun, but in any case, this avant-garde flavor served as a whole armada of red flags. 

Beyond that, the burger wasn't very tasty anyway, so I picked the remaining avocado (two dollar surcharge, by the way) out of the burger with my fork, and left. 

That's right. I had not eaten anything all day, and I did not finish my meal here. I made it barely halfway through. I went home and ate toast and ice cream instead.
author: John L.

description:
I like the Irish Bank. I have fond memories of meeting friends that worked at the PSE ( pre Equinox fitness)  sharing a pint of Guinness over stories of making markets in microsoft and cisco....crazy stuff.

Service is always okay. The food is so so...I do love their chips...nice and crunchy basket of lightly fried potatoes. Ambiance is lowbrow for sure...but it adds to the authenticity.

Option of drinking/eating inside or in the Alley outside....Alley is pretty grunge...but if its warm and sunny its okay

Best legit drawn Guinness pint in San Fran ....imhho
author: David G.

description: I have come for 12 years, on occasion. Maybe 2 times / year. Always had great food and a great time until tonight when a bartender named Mark flat out made fun of our group. Mocked us thinking we couldn't hear his comments. A little age-shaming mixed with a little classism. What a bummer, Mark. Ruining a good thing after all these years.
author: Joel G.

description:
Really convenient weeknight bar when I just want to have a conversation with a friend over some fresh Guinness without having to shout. The prices are really good for the location, which is also super convenient being in the middle of the Financial District/Union Square area.

They also serve some food, of the very greasy variety. If I'm really hungry I get the fish and chips, but a few drinks will fill me up before I get there.
author: Henry Z.

description: I went to this bar for my 21st and met the best people. The bartender was amazing and the drinks were great. Always a great time at this place.
author: Mayah C.

description: The Irish Beef Stew was steaming hot, was loaded with meat and the mashed potatoes still had lumps in them...perfect with the stew. Service was quick and friendly, too!
author: Wendy H.

description: Loved the atmosphere of the bar. I had the Irish Coffee and it was very delicious and strong! I as
author: Andrea T.

description: This is the shittieat bar in SF..  Not a place to go... The bouncers are the best assholes in San Francisco. The biggest ones possible
author: Jithin S.

description:
I haven't found too many places that house my top favs (Laphroaig and Connemara) on the same shelf, and although the going rate (fueled by Union Square/SF prices in general) for a shot of Laphroaig is $11, you get a generous pour. And it's SF--in many cases, a tiny shot can run upwards to $17. I also don't know any bar where the going rate for a shot of Connemara is $8. So you can get your socks knocked off with a generous double for a mere $16, which is usually the going rate for a standard watered down cocktail at every other bar in a mile radius. Worth it. 

Hard to believe a quaint little place is tucked away so close to Union Square. The inside venue is a little meh, primarily because the music is ridic loud, which wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing, but the tunes are all customer selected on the e-jukebox. So you get to hear your standard crappity pop and bad oldies blaring through what is a low-key Irish bar. My suggestion is to sit in the adorable alleyway. There are heaters during the colder months so you won't freeze. Although service is a little slow out here, it's worth not having to shout your conversations over Taylor Swift and Katy Perry tunes. Haven't yet tried the pub food, but it's always looked pretty good from afar. 4.5 stars, and seriously would be a 5-star review if the music didn't suck so hard.
author: Alison A.

description:
Good place but the lack of McEwan's brand ale and Kerrygold Irish Whiskey really left me thinking that I came to the wrong pub.
I did enjoy the time spent and will continue to extol the benefits of pubs, the official sunblock of Ireland
author: Andy B.

description: Hidden gem in SF. We really enjoyed lunch and a beer at this place. Great service and amazing food. The photos all over the walls are really neat too. My chicken sandwich and beer came to $24 and my partners turkey club and beer was $23. Can't beat that! I would highly recommend.
author: Casaundra E.

description: Good atmosphere to have a drink. Bartenders are pleasant, quick and keep the riff-raff out.
author: A U.

description: The cutest bartender in Union Square (the one wiith the curls) makes the best Gin Gimlet in town at the old school, authentic Irish Bank,  a Pub on Mark Ln.  Plus he's a sweetheart!!!  It's a Win Win!
author: Kani T.

description: I've been here enough times to grow to like the place. It's a nice little bar with outside seating in an alleyway that you don't see too often in SF. Inside's a smaller, crowded place, so I've always preferred outside seating. It's a great place to talk over beer and small bites after work.
author: TJ P.

description:
Started out great, ended very disappointed 
Very cool building. After arriving we finally learned that you seat yourself. Food arrived fast (which leads me to believe it's not cooked to order). I had grilled chicken w/mashed potatoes & veggies, Husband had banger& son had chicken strips. All tasted good. About 15 minutes after we were done eating, an employee cleared our table. We were looking forward to dessert & iris coffee but our server never came back. The restaurant was not busy. After 30 minutes of watching her walk around, check herself in mirror, greet a new table, get their drinks, come back and take their order (all the while ignoring us) I finally had to call out & wave so she knew we were still there (sitting right by her current table). By that time we were fed up & no longer wanted dessert or coffee. Her tip reflected her poor service. I think this would've been a nice place to come back to but unfortunately she ruined it. 
Food 4 stars. Service 0 stars.
author: Lisa R.

description: I had deliberately planned for an Irish lunch today. The bar wasn't busy. Not greeted, had to ask for menu. Left after waiting. Guess they were too busy talking Irish politics.
author: Da P.

description: The bar seems decent enough. The people are nice enough. The bangers and mash were some of the worst I've ever had. They didn't even taste like bangers. They were way over cooked and tasted like chewy hot dogs. The mash was cold and the beans were all over the plate I might go back for a beer but I wouldn't eat there again, that's for sure.
author: Tim G.

description:
Stopped in for lunch the other day with my daughter. She wanted French fries and I wanted a beer. We went the usually fried bar food.

Fish and Chips - ($13.95)
Chicken Strips - ($8)

I was trying to go into detail with these dishes but can't. They are about as straight forward as you'd imagine.

Not bad, but not great. Standard pub fare with outdoor seating in the alley.

Overall Irish Bank is a good option for convenience and a beer. Otherwise, there are better pubs/restaurants nearby, especially if you're looking for quality food.
author: Zoran L.

description: I was there late night mid week. Probably should have gone back to my hotel but, yada yada, I didn't. Sat at a picnic table in the alley. I think I probably had a Boddingtons. Great local haunt. I'd go back.
author: David N.

description: This was the place to be during SantaCon. We sat outside and the weather was perfect.  Had nachos, various other appetizers.  As busy as it was, they kept everyone in the place happy.
author: Lisa F.

description:
The best thing about this bar is the outside patio. It's great for a group lunch or an evening dinner. It feels like a more typical Irish pub on the inside than many other so called Irish pubs I have frequented in the city. Nice memorabilia on the walls. 
The menu is typically Irish. Good choice of old favorites and also other pub classics. 
My favorite is the shepherds pie with a side of coleslaw. Also good is the bangers and mash with beans. Also tried a side of the Irish bacon which was pretty decent and reminded me of home.
author: Derek M.

description: Good Anglo-Irish food with good beer, friendly staff and more available space than most bars in the area. Good place to watch soccer.
author: Matt A C.

description: Went during a business conference and loved it. Not your typical hippy SF bar. Sit outside and enjoy the breeze and conversation with other groups at your table.  I couldn't stand SF in general, but this place was visited a couple times by our group.
author: Patrick M.

description: It was kind of okay don't expect good food. The menu is very pedestrian. Go to drink and nothing more. Good draft beer selection.
author: Sara P.

description:
This is an irish style bar/pub kinda sorta not really in the financial district/union square.

Street parking only, but there are some parking garages not too far away.

It's got some unique things about it both good and bad.

The bar has all the basics for a decent irish pub, long wooden topped bar, rail footrest, clips for hanging your wrap, jacket or bag on underneath the bar seating (perfect for leaving your stuff behind!), and of course a fair amount of snug.

The have about a dozen taps of beer all of which, excepting the required local cali style IPA thingys (Lagunitas), would not be out of place in any Irish pub in the home country. I do note that the Harp is not necessarily the same as what you'll find across the pond. In the US it's brewed in Canada, as that's more profitable then shipping it from Europe. I can't tell the difference, but then it's been 15 years since I was overseas. The irish/scotch whisky selection is profound and the wine selection isn't bad, although if you're drinking wine in an irish pub, you have bigger issues then the depth of the wine collection.

Assuming you don't want to linger at the bar, there's a collection of dining tables and what would be patio seating except for the fact it's in the alley. I'm not a big fan of the alley seating. Sure, you can be as loud as you want, and if you're a smoker it's a better place to break San Francisco's public smoking laws then inside, and you can barely see the dumpster but you're in a fricken alley. In San Francisco. Without going into rat infested, pee stained, homeless drug addict using, details alleys in San Francisco are not famous as being a super fun place to hang out. 

The food is pretty good, verging on great. Thier shepherd's pie is a perfect rendition of the type. If you have a shepherd's pie craving this place will serve as perfect a plate as you'll find anywhere.

Pricing is steep even by the area's standards. Along with the alley seating I consider this another weak spot. The whisky wall commands premium pricing so a low to mid range quality shot will run you 11 dollars or so. The pint happy hour pricing is six bucks a pint. Food starts at roughly 20 dollars a plate. So a couple drinks and a meal will most likely be around 50 dollars for you.
author: Steven W.

description:
This place is a great bar with outdoor tables sheltered on windy days by their placement in the alley. There are also large umbrellas or awnings that protect the outdoor seats from rain.

I used to think it was only a bar. I found out recently it's also a restaurant. I have not yet eaten there, but it smells like my favorite restaurants and steak houses my family used to visit when I was a kid. This brought back some great memories and I'll try the food soon (I've learned anything that smells this good tastes good too).

Lastly, the bartenders are really down-to-earth and chill. Sadly, I find bartenders at some other places lack these things. I always get the feeling they really care about every customer here though.
author: Noah P.

description:
The Irish Bank presents a very merchandised Irish pub experience but hey, for a casual pint (or many) outdoors-ish in Union Square, it has its own appeal. 

There is the ever-present pints of Guiness and I am even pleasantly surprised that they have Harp on tap. I definitely had quite a bit of both when I lived in Dublin. But when I'm at the Irish Bank, I tend to typically order pints of Leffe since you don't often see this Belgian brew on tap at most places in SF - makes the $7 pint feel worth it. Semi-outdoor seating in the alley can be competitive on busy nights but the servers come by pretty frequently. Nothing necessarily remarkable about the food here but its reasonable pub grub with fairly large servings.  Can't really go wrong with some fish and chips with your pints or some curry or shepherd's pie on cold wet nights.

Interesting mix of folks from tourists who stumble in to the ad folks who work around the block. All just looking to the Irish Bank for a pint and a decently grand time. Sláinte.
author: Jon L.

description:
Good bar with a nice whiskey selection. We had to order food to sit at one of the only available tables, so we went in on some calamari. 

Come here, drink. Maybe get the fish and chips because they looked freaking amazing. Do not get the calamari. It's perfectly cooked, props, I thought. But then my mouth was like wtf?! Soooo bland. I swear they were bland enough to remove flavor from the cocktail sauce. 

I feel like we got the one bad thing. Nice staff all around.
author: Mari H.

description:
DRINKING AT ST PATRICK'S DAY & EATING LUNCH

I've been coming to The Irish Bank for St Patrick's Day weekend for the last three years. I come to The Irish Bank for St Patrick's because this place is convenient to my work about two blocks away.  That's convenient because if I needed to the bathroom I would use the bathroom at my work instead of standing at the long line at The Irish Bank. St Patrick's Day Weekend at The Irish Bank is a euphoric atmosphere. The setting is at an alley full of people drinking beer and dancing to the music. Two weeks ago I brought my nephew, cousin, and brother in law for St Patrick's Day Weekend. We had a great time unwinding and enjoying the celebration.

Even though I have been here for St Patrick's Day Weekend I haven't eaten here despite it's only about two blocks away from my work. I ate here last Friday for lunch. I read about the Yelp review of the bleu cheese fries - an interesting concept I thought. I ordered fish and chips. Instead of the regular fries I substituted for the bleu cheese fries. The fish was moist, but I wish the batter was crunchier. The bleu cheese on the fries doesn't make the fries soggy as melted cheese would. Overall I wasn't too impressed with the bleu cheese fries as nothing stood out in flavor. 

I noticed a table next to me a customer ordered the Irish beef stew. I thought that looked more appetizing than my fish and chips. However I wasn't going to order the Irish Beef Stew right after I ordered the fish and chips. So I came here last Tuesday and ordered the Irish beef stew. On the side I also ordered Irish bacon, which is similar to Canadian bacon. The Irish beef stew had slices of potato, but also topped with mashed potato. I felt the dish had too many potatoes and not enough chunks of beef - I counted four pieces of beef. I actually enjoyed the Irish bacon more. The grilled bacon brought out the flavor.

So I experienced eating and drinking at The Irish Bank. I actually enjoy drinking at The Irish Bank more than eating here. If I come back to The Irish Bank it would be for St. Patrick Day's Weekend instead of eating there for lunch during my lunch break at work.
author: Gerald R.

description: Excellent pub for drinks and food! Try the "Hot Apple Pie" Declan the bartender does a great job  with drinks and service!! The atmosphere is authentic and they had Premier League in the TV. Highly recommend this Pub for a Guinness and delicious Fish and Chips or Beef Stew.
author: Robert G.

description:
The Irish Bank is one of those hidden (while at the same time kind of famous) gems in San Francisco. 

The casual and friendly charm of this Financial District institution is always inviting for a nice time with friends. 

Lots of regulars and tourists keep the place at that sweet spot between busy and crowded. The food is tasty, comforting and inexpensive. 

Drop by and have a beer or a snack, you won't regret it.
author: Jose R.

description:
3.5 Stars

Outdoor area good for groups but fills up quick
Bar area is spacious enough for small groups 
A wide range of draft beers including Boddington and other European beers
Very loud atmosphere, hard to talk/hear

Overall Thoughts

No frills Irish Pub hangout for you and your friends/coworkers
author: Eddie W.

description:
Great outdoor seating area, service was quick, and the food pretty decent. My party had the banger, fish and chips, and beef stew. The meat in the beef stew was tender and delicious, the bangers were cooked perfectly, and the fish was alright. 

Good place for a quick bite and a beer.
author: D Ann W.

description:
Had the fish and chips and a Boddingtons around 4:30 on a Tuesday.  Typical bar food, though the fries were very nice compared to most places.  It was moderately busy, but by no means packed when I arrived.  The service was so dreadfully slow.  There were no waitstaff in view the first five minutes or so after I sat down.  My beer and food took some time to arrive.  I was basically ignored afterward and had to ask for the check.  It wasn't that they were understaffed and running fast, it was more that they had a very 'relaxed' approach to service.  This matched my approach to tipping at the end of it.

Upside - great location, fries were good, beer was cold and fresh, the outdoor seating was nice.

Downside - be prepared to wait a while, and don't come in expecting fine cuisine.
author: Mr. Average Guy X.

description: A bit disappointing. Beer selection was just so-so, Irish coffee could have been better and food menu is just basic fare.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Been here several times with friends and we keep going back. It's a fun and chill atmosphere with great food and drinks selections. Love the style of the restaurant being in an alley. Such a cool place and only walking distance from union square. Completely recommend this place!
author: RamonaEliza D.

description: This is a neat location with an awesome outdoor alley type seating, which they light up at night. We only had drinks here, which were average price and we enjoyed the atmosphere!
author: Irish F.

description:
Tucked in the alley, this pub offers communal seating and plenty of room to chill and drink up.  I am surprised that they have this hidden, spacious pub right in the FiDi area.

It's a pleasant outdoor spot to enjoy over a pint of beer or more if you are thirsty.

They have good food that compliments the beer like fish and chips, sandwiches and so forth.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Very good Irish bar tucked away from Main Street. Good Guinness. Good burger and fries. Authentic. Highly recommended.
author: Kevin S.

description: The food is great! And I don't mean good for a pub, it's better than most restaurants I've tried. Inexpensive too. Nice customer service as well.
author: Stephanie K.

description: In search of Aikiko's Restaurant aka 431 Bush Street, I wandered into the Irish Bank. A lovely old school pub with all of the Irish artifacts to match. Enjoyed two corners of Jameson with two maintenance workers enjoying their lunch. The food looked great and the menu is my kind of style of pub food. Received clear directions to the sushi bar from the charming and lovely bartender. Bookmarked for a return visit someday.
author: David N.

description:
Why did you not tell me about this secret Irish pub?! You know I have a list of Irish pubs I like to venture to. As soon as I set foot inside, I closed my eyes and stepped back into The Ball Alley in Lucan. The only thing missing was some Dubliners, Thin Lizzy and the Cranberries. This pub is as close as I have been to being in an authentic Irish pub in San Francisco. Dark wood, brick walls, leather chairs, wood chairs and history all over the walls. The fellas pouring me Guinness were Irish too! Love....

I have sampled Guinness all over the world, the best place to have it of course is in Dublin. If you can't swing a flight on Aer Lingus, head to the Irish Bank for a delectable pint. This is the best head I have seen in SF. Sorry Napper, the Irish Bank has taken your place. You are my local so I still have love for ya. If stout ain't your thing, try one of the MANY choices of whisky, scotch or other spirits showcased behind the bar. They are in abundance. 

Though it was only a Monday night, I've been told that on occasion the pub blocks Marks Alley so bands can play for the crowd. Tonight there were tables set up outside for people to enjoy the still warm fall weather. Service was friendly and prompt, pints were $7.00 a glass. 

I wish this pub was in the Mission, I would totally go after work every night!
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Did you ever want to sip a beer in a dirty alley at noon on a Monday?... I do, frankly quite often. 

Stopped here for a quick beer while I was in SF for a recent work trip. I saw this place from my Uber ride window and thought to myself, "I need to go there". Irish Bank and Bar has that old school fisherman bar feel on the outside, a little dirty, with pigeons and random seagulls hanging around waiting for that coveted morsel of food to drop. 

The inside is what I imagine an old bar in Ireland to look like. Dimly lit with lots of wooden trinkets and old school photos from the Irish countryside on the walls. The bartenders here are a bit salty, but charming at the same time. Great beer selection with multiple craft beers on tap and from what I saw, a decent looking menu, but I didn't snack during this trip. 

I tried coming back with a few friends later that night and it was packed!, "Note to self avoid Irish Bank on Monday Night Football". Great bar and good vibes, if you're in San Francisco definitely worth the trip for a quick pint.
author: Nate M.

description: Awesome place great food friendly service. Dog friendly outside as well!!!!! Really fun.
author: Mike K.

description: Gets really packed but a great place to have drinks with friends or co-workers. Decent food.
author: Angela H.

description: Food is soooo good, even the simplest fish and ships, it is better than anywhere else!
author: Doreen L.

description:
I made a Yelp account just to write this review. Sat down for a beer on the patio on a beautiful day. A patron sitting in the patio (a regular, based on how all of the wait staff treated him) light up a cigarette, no more than 10 feet from the door, and smoked it brazenly, blowing smoke into the patio area as if he were smoking a cigar.

After a woman had to move closer to me, saying that she could not tolerate the smoke either (and also would not be able to eat nor bring her daughters to eat as she had planned), I went inside to ask a server to ask that they request the patron extinguish it. They made a cursory attempt to ask the regular to extinguish it, although he just held it under the table for the remainder of the cigarette.

As the woman could no longer handle the smoke still wafting into the patio area, she left abruptly. I moved to the only other open outdoor table -- seating for 10 or so. I sat at the very end. This was approximately 5pm on a beautiful Friday. While I was finishing my beer, a line formed for the patio, and I saw a number of groups leave in vain because there were no longer any "free" tables.

10 minutes later, when the man lit a second cigarette, I asked the waiter if they were going to enforce the smoking ban on the patio. The waiter said he "just got there" and did nothing. When I still smelled the smoke, this time from across the patio, I finally went inside, despite wanting to enjoy the fresh air of a beautiful day. I asked the manager (owner?) the policy for smoking on the patio. He said smoking it is "at your own risk", despite having signs prominently posted that say no smoking within 25 feet of any entrance (city law). I asked for clarification, and he said that if smokers get caught, that it's up to them to deal with the consequences. I asked if that meant the establishment makes any effort to operate consistent with city law, and he said (rather rudely) that "if we try to get them to put it out, then they just go into the alley and smoke anyway". When I pointed out that that would be perfectly legal and reasonable, so long they were removed from the entrance/patio area, he just walked away. I would not have taken the time to write this if it were not for the utter indifference and rudeness of this manager (owner)?

I would ask this restaurant, why do you condone your patrons breaking the law? Would you serve an inebriated person more alcohol "at their own risk"? What about the risk to the other patrons and employees who have to breathe carcinogenic smoke while they simply wish eat and drink?

IN SUMMARY, avoid this patio if you do not wish to have smoke blown in your face. Avoid the indoors of this establishment if the doors are open and you do not wish to smell smoke.
author: D. M.

description: This is the only bar where I can find Irish Coffee in this area. the rest you have to go to fisherman wharf for Irish Coffee that I know of. There used to be more place for Irish coffee around Union Square but, that when Gold Dust Lounge and Lefty O Doul had shut down.  The Irish bank reminded me of the gold dust lounge and/or lefty O Doul.  I like the Irish coffee at the Irish bank. I was going home from the Fluxos bar and hotel next to Irish bank and I came across the seating outdoor and indoor.  I asked the bouncer if there was Irish Coffee and he said he is sure but I should check with the bartender.  I was dying to get Irish coffee since it had been almost a year without Irish Coffee. I grab a drink before heading to BART. I am glad I did and I will be a repeat. next time I come I will bring my pet Just kidding I do not have a pet:)
author: Mat Z.

description: First impression, I love the outdoor seating and vibe of the bar itself. The drinks were relatively cheap and the mozzarella sticks were delicious. When we ordered drinks and food at the bar, they were quick despite the bar seating being full on a Tuesday evening. The Mule that they had on special was a hit with me and the local beers were for my husband. Lastly, the staff were friendly and professional and I would love to go back again!
author: Ally L.

description:
Pros
- Large space indoor and large outdoor patio
- Good for St. Patrick's Day 
- Though limited, there are some west coast craft beers available
- Take credit cards

Cons
- They do not split checks
- Service is mediocre
- Higher prices
- Food is mediocre
author: Dipesh G.

description:
I have lived in San Francisco for over 5 years and until tonight, still came to Irish Bank. This bar has no respect for patrons and choses to prioritize an early home exit from a homely bar experience. 

Come here if you want to pee and leave.
author: Kevin O.

description: One of my favorite places on earth.  I love sitting in the alley. The food is great, the drinks, the staff. We came for a quick bite and ended up having a long leisurely lunch. It was so relaxing.  It wasn't my first visit and it definitely won't be my last.
author: Yelp R.

description: Love this place!! Such a cool alley patio, and the drinks were outstanding. Totally the perfect place to stop after a little shopping. The only regret was that we didn't have time to eat because OH MY GOD the food smelled so freaking good. Mouth watering still the next day thinking about it. I want -slash -need to go back for a dark beer and something fried immediately.
author: Meredith B.

description: Went for lunch with a group from work. We ordered some mozzarella sticks and fries, both ok, your typical frozen bites. I wouldn't recommend this place for lunch or dinner, entrees weren't that good.  I had a burger and fries, ordered medium, but it was almost burnt and dry. Nothing special about it. I guess this place is good for a late night of hanging out and drinking and having some bites at the bar. Staff was very nice though, good service.
author: Lorely G.

description: Had a friend from out of town stop in there and the bartender -- handsome guy, 20something-- was a total DICK to them. As they said "we probably would have ordered more and drank more but the guy was borderline hostile."  Wouldn't explain what was on the menu and plopped down the check after their first drink.
author: Mark M.

description:
I found The Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant while doing my monthly ~3 hour iPhone photo excursion through The City. I happened upon the alley and was drawn in by the red lights glowing and the lively crowd of after-workers hanging out.  

The semi-communal tables set out on the alley provided a fun spot to grab a beer and enjoy the evening.  Large awnings produced a cool coziness and protection from the rain - unless you sit directly under the 6" gap between awnings (which I did) and it begins to drizzle.

The food?  I ordered a turkey club melt...and the cheese was not melted.  It was edible, but not amazing.  Actually, it was quite forgettable and had me wishing I had wandered to North Beach for some better grub.  However, the service was very fast, friendly and efficient, so I got over the food thing quickly.

The beer?  Cold and excellent.  Added bonus - I noticed the lovely ladies from Smithwick's Ale were working the tables and handing out cool bottle openers.  I asked the waiter if he could knab one for me and he returned in a flash with one.  Bro, you scored high marks for that move - thank you!

So, here's my rating: 5 stars for the alley vibe, 2 stars for the food, 5 stars for the attentive waiter (especially since he had several tables and it was BUSY) and 3.65 stars overall.

I'd go back again...for beers.
author: Patrick L.

description: After work hangout.  It's got a lot of kitch on the wall and noise inside can be loud.
author: Drew B.

description: Decent pint,brutal cheese fries and atmosphere of a wet fart...from a real Irishman born and bred.....no plastic paddy here
author: Martin C.

description: Let's get real. This is a place where an eclectic crowd comes after work or for a night drink with their friends. I am here alone people watching and it is super fun. They were friendly and made a good drink for me to enjoy. I like the outdoor area way more than their loud booming indoor area. Their is a happy red light making the patio area cozy and nice. The drinks are well priced too. I was expecting way more then $7 for my vodka soda! It is a nice place to unwind and relax for sure. They have food too that looks and smells better than normal "bar" food. I would get some but I am holding out for my sushi reservation next door!
author: Chelsea B.

description: Definitely the place to be for st Patrick's celebration. The long lines to get in were a pain but I had a lot of fun and it was totally worth it. Great DJ and scene. I would definitely recommend this place for St Patrick's.
author: Cindy L.

description: Their beer selection is pretty good, the food is regular good, and the liquor is over priced.
author: Joseph G.

description: I was visiting from out of town, and the staff was so nice and attentive. I would definately recommend the Irish Bank as a low key place to enjoy a brew.  The bartenders managed a busy bar like true professionals. I would bring my friends here!
author: Danielle B.

description: Great bar and great bar tenders. Come visit Decklyn, Owen and Conner!!! A very true Irish Bar near Union square.
author: Jose V.

description:
I think the main draw of The Irish Bank is it's location - which is in an alley. Jeez, I never thought I'd praise a restaurant for being located in an alley, but there you go. Lots of vintage and not-so-vintage tin signs advertising beer, motor oil. etc. Charming outdoor space. 

I do wish they would invest is nicer chairs. Those plastic patio chairs are kind of...wobbly.

The Shepard's Pie was just so-so, however, my dining companion had good things to say about his fish and chips.
author: Tara H.

description: I'm giving one star because the only good thing was the Shepard's pie. The banger was ok - the beans were awful, the sausage was ok, and the fries weren't cooked well. The fish from the fish and chips was bland, and looked overcooked, or cooked in dirty oil. The service was eh. One waitress took our drink orders and didn't come back with our drinks - it took about 10-15 minutes for our drinks to appear. She was supposed to come back and take our order, but didn't. So, someone else stepped in while she kept walking by us, ignoring us. To top the visit off, we could see part of the kitchen and it was dirty. That should have been our sign to just get up and leave, but the place was recommended by someone and we wanted to give it a fair shake.
author: Sarah F.

description: This place is a little hidden gem. The food is good, drinks are great and service is welcoming. Outdoor seating just needs the tables to be adjusted for sturdiness, I almost tipped my drink. But all in all it's a great place to unwind.
author: Cherie C.

description: The service leaves something to be desired. We ordered three Irish car bombs and 3 Irish coffees. They brought us 5 bombs. Ok, that's not the worst thing to happen. Whoops !! I'm more drunk that I was planning on! I know we had a little bit of a complicated party... but the waitress skipped over my boyfriend's father so he got his food late. I've had better food at Safeway's Signature Cafe. They left shell on my Deviled Egg. The best way to describe this joint was "lackluster."
author: KM N.

description: The only other time I've been to this place was on St Patrick's day two years ago for their Block Party and everything was fine. Came here yesterday (3/16) for a pre-St. Patty's craziness HH with my team. We orginally had a table inside and then moved to a table outside (second table right next to the entrance on the left if you are facing the entrance) about 5 minutes later. I didn't get the waitress' name but I'm giving this a 2-star because she was so incredibly rude to us from the moment we sat down. I used to serve so I get having a larger table of 10+ can be stressful but honey either accept it and smile or don't be a server. She was acting like it was St. Patrick's day and the place was packed and crazy. When we first switched tables, my coworker let our waitress know that he ordered a Shepherd's pie  with the other server and to transfer it out here. She huffed and got other people's orders and walked away. About twenty or thirty minutes later she came back with another coworker's pie (who ordered with her in the first place) and told the person who told her when we moved about his that she didn't get it and they didn't make it so she will have to reorder it for him which took another twenty to come out. There Shepherd's pie was amazing but probably won't come here again because of that service.
author: Alex S.

description:
Met a friend here to hang for a bit. Love that it's in the alley and there are cutesy tables outside- makes the dining experience fun (until someone smokes cigarettes while noming). The inside is kinda crusty.

Not sure how the food is, didn't look super mesmerizing. 

Would probably be back sometime to try whatever else they have.
author: Shereen A.

description:
I love this bar! 

First off, how is this joint the only place smart enough to make use of the alley space? I really like this neighborhood (although, that probably makes me uncool because nobody is supposed to like Union Square/FiDi. Mostly people scoff at you when you say that you want to come into this area. But you know what, every neighborhood has gems.) 

So this should be your first (maybe your third as well) stop when you come to this neighborhood. 

It's funny, my wife was a little apprehensive at first because I didn't do a great job of selling the place. She immediately fell in love when she saw the outside. 

We thought about taking some outdoor seating because it was a pretty nice day in February (way to go El Nino) but we decided to look around inside. Because where else would you rather be on a nice day than a dimly lit bar? 

We did stumble into the conversation booth. Which is pretty amazing. I'd like to imagine some high-level conversations going on in this booth. The reality is it's probably seen more "handys" than anything else. Our family split the difference by nursing our daughter in there. 

Which, by the way, the staff was really cool about. It's a restaurant, so it's not like we smuggled a child into a bar. Well, sorta. But it's a restaurant, so it's allowed. So we sat in this little booth having the time of our lives. This waitress kept walking by and looking in. Which made me nervous. This is our first child, so I'm all, "should we not be in here?" "Are we going to get kicked out?" "Are we parents of the year for this?" 

Don't answer that last one. 

But eventually we got up to leave. The waitress (she might have been the manager) came over and compliments our wee Irish lass. Which was a great relief. The girl (my girl, not the waitress/manager) was extremely complimentary. Which made us feel pretty good because we are trying to do the right thing here. 

If the right thing is spending hours in a bar (AND RESTAURANT) on a bright, Saturday. 

Hey, at least the sun was still up when we left. 

Oh yeah, a few other things. Get the Irish breakfast. It's great. And order a Guinness. The pour is amazing. So great. I like Guinness fine. But I don't order it a lot. I did here. I've never had a better pour outside of Gallagher's in Huntington Beach back in 1998. So that's good. 

Get a snake bite, too. It's amazing.
author: Adam R.

description:
A casual place to catch up with friends, the Irish Bank serves up hearty Irish food, a reliable beer selection and a full bar.

Staropramen is undeniably a crisp, refreshing light beer. Nothing beats the real deal from Czech Republic (best on tap!) but the bottle version is still ok at $5.50. I prefer cocktails so I ordered the Moscow Mule. It was disappointingly acidic and very weak, what a waste of $9! I gave it to my friend to not waste alcohol and got a Hendrick's and Tonic instead. 

Inside can get stuffy when the bar is packed, so if it's not too chilly, grab a seat outside where the ambiance is much better. The bartenders are always attentive so you don't wait long for a drink.
author: Janice C.

description:
Been here many times over many years. Most recently I had what was formerly a fine lunch. Fish & Chips and an Irish Coffee. 
Well.
Fish was OK, chips were soggy and the Irish Coffee was awful.
I suppose there was whiskey in it, hard to tell, and the whipped cream appeared to be barely steamed milk which immediately mixed into the coffee. And the coffee wasn't very good either.

Two stars because we've enjoyed it previously, and will likely return to see if this was an aberration, but based on this visit I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Michael F.

description: I found this place on accident when walking to my hotel, came in for breakfast and had the Wee Breakfast and a mimosa. Hands down best breakfast AND mimosa I've had probably ever. The staff was super friendly and quick! The food was to die for. I had to take a picture of the bottle of champagne because it was that good. Will definitely make a trip here again while on vacation and will make a note to come here on future trips and recommended to any traveling friends. Thanks for giving me an authentic taste of Ireland!
author: Savannah M.

description:
On our way back from Chinatown one late afternoon, a coworker and I discovered this place while walking up the hill on Bush St.  This place is a PLEASANT SURPRISE!!

First off, you don't even know it exists.  There's a sign on the road, but when you turn the corner into the alley, you are hit with a ton of tables, filled with people drinking!  Soooo cool.  The bouncers wait in the front of the alley, check your ID's and direct you in the joint.  

The inside is dark and mysterious.  Lots of wood planks everywhere.  Wooden bar, wooden stools, exposed wooden walls.  Definitely looks like my perfect impression of an authentic Irish pub.  LOVE THAT!  Bartenders are cool, drinks are affordable and everyone is there to just have a grand 'ole time!

If you're in the area, you need to check this place out.  Look for the small sign above your head.  You'll miss it if you blink!
author: Rockne H.

description: Late dinner and drinks, food came out quick and was excellent. Fish and chips were on point.
author: Cecily G.

description: This bar is really cool, and really take advantage of that alley on the side. I went for St. Patrick's day this past week. There was plenty of space and everyone fit pretty well, and the band was rocking. Due to SPD, I assume places feel justified in raising their rates; a pretty insane $10 cover charge and Bud Light aluminums were $6 (pre-tip, naturally). I liked there was a makeshift "bar" in the back (more of a folding table with beers on it) and a woman would walk by every once in awhile with a box full of fresh BL's at your disposal so you didn't need to go inside the bar to buy anything, which seemed impossible that day. Just the price point was pretty astronomical to warrant many future visits, if that's their industry standard.
author: Dan M.

description:
irish restaurants seem to be highly criticized everywhere i go, making me think they are either sub-par on the west coast as a whole and i havent been exposed to anything else... or people are just stupid and snobby for no reason. as far as i can tell, this food is simple, filling, cheap, pub-style food to absorb all the alcohol you are consuming. and for me, that is just fine.

we were strolling around the area deciding on dinner, and the lovely alleyway patio caught my eye. the tables are simple no frills patio tables and the lighting is red at night...making food photography terrible btw :/

i will keep this simple like the food and experience was:

app: blue cheese fries. yum. IF you like blue cheese which is plentiful

irish beef stew: for a warm night it normally wouldnt have been my choice, but i wanted something authentic and several people spoke highly of it so i gave it a go. i liked it a lot...even with a small appetite. i would have liked it a bit chunkier with the veggies but the flavor was good.

black n tan: i just have to get it anytime im at an irish pub. well made :)

dining partner got the reuben and it looked quite tasty. 

service was good...food came out quick...busser was VERY enthusiastic and diligent, it was sweet. no complains
author: Heather W.

description: Outdoor seating area in an alley is pretty cool.  Good after work spot if you're downtown.  The inside is a pretty standard Irish bar
author: Charles C.

description:
Seems silly to Yelp about a place that's such an obvious choice and happy hour staple for a ton of people, namely me, but I must say, it's da bomb.

Way back when I was fresh out of a long-term relationship and had somehow forgotten (or maybe never knew how to begin with) how to mingle, my lady co-workers half forced me to go drink with them at Irish Bank and showed me the ropes. It's relaxed, cozy, pub atmosphere helped me feel comfortable and, shortly after, get my drank on.

Outside in the alley also offers plenty of seating, though sometimes there can be a wait to sit down. I've often found myself perched atop a bench drinking while waiting to swoop on a table. The food is pretty legit for what it is: pub food. Filling, oily, satisfying. Cheese Fries and Fish 'N Chips are exactly what their description is, but still good.

Mind you, I've been back more times than I'd like to admit since I first popped my IB cherry. I'm still awkward, in part due to being home-schooled and generally sheltered in my youth, but maybe not as awkward as I was some-three years ago.
author: Crystal C.

description:
My friends and I found the Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant when we were roaming around San Francisco looking for a place to drink.  You kinda find this place if you walk through an alley. :P

Inside the alley, there are tons of tables and chairs where you can sit at and drink.  We were here for a good 2 or 3 hours just hanging out.  The whole time, there were always people checking up on us seeing if we needed more drinks or water.

There seems to be a lot of different kinds of beer here... I wish I could say more about the food but we didn't really eat anything.

The only negative I could find about The Irish Bank Bar is that since we were sitting in an alley in cold windy ass San Francisco, it got a bit cold because of the wind, and the cars driving by.

But this is still a cool spot!
author: Emily S.

description:
I get that it's a popular locals dive bar, so it's hard to fault that.  From my view point, it's an ok place, definitely been to much worse.  It's nice to hang out outside, and I've had better (and worse) bar food.

Still, for me there's somethong about this place which doesn't quite gel with me.  The menu does have a "vegan alternative", which at least is explicit (beans, rice, guacamole), but is hardly filling.  The vege burger *might* be vegan, but I wouldn't bet on it, and there's fries too.  

They have a nice selection of beers, but they've been out of some of them every time I've gone, so a little disappointed.

I've not tried the cocktails here, but I'm guessing the old school bartenders really know their stuff with mixed drinks.
author: Peter N.

description:
Tucked inside a Financial District alley, The Irish Bank has such a cool pub feel that makes you feel at home in Ireland. Then again... I've never been to Ireland, so how would I know? There are two sections to this place, the bar and the restaurant. When you sit in the bar half (even if it's at the seated tables) you need to order food from the bar. If you sit in the restaurant half, then a waiter will be at your service. Kinda weird but okay. 

I ordered the Corned Beef & Cabbage ($12.95) which comes with a side of mashed potatoes. You know they're not doing a great job when the mashed potatoes taste better than the main part of the plate. There was something off about the corned beef. Perhaps it wasn't fresh, or maybe it was the fact that the meat itself was not very flavorful. I was craving corned beef (weird craving, I know) but I was let down. The mashed potatoes were amazing though!

I also tried a little bit of the Shepherds Pie ($9.00) which tasted super beefy, but perhaps that's the way they intended it to be. Wasn't my favorite Shepherds pie in the world. 

The Bloody Mary was very good, and they have a plethora of other cocktail ideas if you need help deciding what you want to drink. The bartender was cool and friendly. This seems like the kind of place where someone can easily feel comfortable as a regular customer.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Can't get much worse and still be in business! Epically horrid!

Shocking in the terrible techno 'music' so outrageously loud that shakes the walls. No conversation possible.

Horrid, awful, terrible. Do not understand why they exist. This is not fun, this is not enjoyable, steer clear of this horrendous place!
author: LA O.

description: Cool spot  right out of the fi-di with a nice abbey seating area. Gets suppppper crowded on St. Pattys (obvi) but the drinks are what you can expect at an Irish bar. Nothing special except for the abbey in the back.
author: Brittini S.

description: The food was extremely mediocre and they try to scam you with the drinks. There's literally no alcohol in them
author: Jessica L.

description: Cool little patio in an alley between two buildings, adorned with old tin Irish signs.  Did not venture inside so I'll restrict this review to patio area.  Enjoyed a perfect pint of Guinness and some blue cheese fries on a fall afternoon. Would return.  Friendly, unhurried service with a smile.
author: John B.

description:
More like 3.5 stars. I've only been here once for lunch, and while I enjoyed that lunch, I haven't sampled enough here or come for happy hour to give it a solid 4 stars.

The restaurant/bar is tucked in one of those alleys in FiDi with outdoor seating, though it isn't as cute or nice as most of the other alley restaurants in the area. The inside smelled like a typical bar, pretty strong of alcohol, which is unpleasant for a normal lunch, but there's plenty of seating outside.

I came with a large group of coworkers and sat  outside. My coworkers recommended a lot of items on the menu, including the fish and chips and shepherds pie, but I didn't want anything hearty or heavy so I went with the GRILLED CHICKEN SALAD, no bleu cheese because I don't like cheese and dressing on the side. 

I know you're thinking..who comes to an Irish restaurant and gets salad..?? I was pleasantly surprised though. Chicken was lightly seasoned and everything was fresh. I always love salads that have some fruit in it for a little something sweet and this one had pear! Also candied walnuts. Good size and a healthy alternative if you don't want the typical Irish food. A little pricey though at $11 compared to other items on the menu.

I also had some of the fries that came with my coworker's fish and chips. They were just okay. Thick cut so they were soft fries, but not crisp/crunchy on the outside the way I like my thick fries.

The only thing I found inconvenient was that they only take 2 credit cards per table. We had 15-20 people and not everyone had cash, but the waitress was nice and let us put in 3 cards since we were such a big group :)
author: Jessie L.

description:
The Irish Bank has a great atmosphere. Despite being located near the heart of the Financial District, they've found plenty of outdoor seating by making use of the alley. The setting, including the ambient red lighting, made me feel like I was in one of Europe's many outdoor cafes. I'd definitely recommend going on a warm spring or summer evening with a few friends.

The food definitely takes a backseat to the atmosphere. I ordered the bratwurst sauerkraut, which, though still tasty, feels like something I could have whipped up at home. I also tried a bit of the Shepard's pie which was more flavorful (and definitely what I'll be having next time).
author: Lawrence W.

description:
Wow - I don't enjoy these reviews, but unfortunately this is it...

An out of town friend has been bugging me for some time to check out their mac n cheese; said it was fabulous. Well, after several months I finally made it today with a buddy of mine.

I must say, the ambiance does carry that appeal that comes with being located in an alley - not typically easy to get to - but thats as far as it goes. The beers were overpriced, service was so-so, but here is what ruined it for me....the food.

First, the mac n cheese was nothing special at all - tasted like it was massed produced for some elementary school. I honestly would rather have Kraft mnc at home - really much better.

Second, hoping the mnc was just a fluke, we ordered sandwiches...I had the reuben he had the cheesesteak. These were possibly the worst either of us have had...it's what I would have expected in a diner/cafe in the middle of nowhere. The corned beef was cheap, processed meat that looked like it was slid straight out of a prepackaged bag. I have never seen a cheese steak that used steak that was not thinly sliced meat, but rather cut up strips from a leftover steak that didn't get eaten the night before. 

Also, the people next to us didn't seem to care too much for their meal from what we could over hear - one of them had the shepards pie and it was about the size of 2 pudding cups...very small.

The fries were ok - 

So I called my friend and harped on her about her recommendation - she got a bit defensive and said 'well, it's been 10 years since I was there'  AH!!!!! thanks for that bit of information, something that might have been useful BEFORE we went there!

I must say if i was just going to have a beer, and I didn't care how much it cost, and I didn't care about having to try to find a parking space, and I wasn't planning on getting hungry, then I might go back.  Or not.
author: Tom C.

description: I used to go here basically every other day after work.  I loved the staff, enjoyed the food and beer. i need to go back in for lunch soon!
author: Giselle E.

description:
Stopped by with family after walking around SF for hours.  Shaded alley with plenty of seating in the early afternoon, and lots of antique signs for review.  We ordered Irish beers on tap and in bottles with a friendly and attentive wait staff.  An excellent place to relax and talk over drinks.  

You can't go wrong with a Guinness, or the local Anchor Steam!
author: Chris A.

description:
******AVOID AVOID AVOID.*****

Pains me to write a 1 star review after 2 consecutive 5 star reviews but truth has to be told.

I had a reservation for Irish Bank for a party of 14. The bouncer(I think) up front greeted us and seemed nice. We were then ushered in by the hostess who left us in this room without any communication. After standing around awkwardly for 10 mts, we decided to seat ourselves and we moved a couple of tables together. Out comes the waiter who very rudely says "NO NO NO". He then moves some other tables around. I guess you have a system which I can appreciate but don't leave guests unattended without any communication and don't be so f*^&ing rude.

We should have left at that point but I decided to stay since I was not sure if I could find another place for a party of this size and did not want to make a scene. The waiter said his name was Jeffy or Jezzy or something like that. Super rude guy and was very rude and curt the rest of the evening to the point where multiple folks commented on it. It ruined the evening for me. Perhaps this dude needs to switch roles with the bouncer. Actually on second thought, this dude should not be in front of customers, put him in the back. 

The food sucked and they don't serve beer in pitchers. I admit my view of the drinks and food are probably biased because of the service. There are way too many options in this area to put up with this S^&$. NEXT!
author: Sunil R.

description:
The Great:
+  A nice selection of beer and whiskey
+  Lots of seating in the alley and inside
+  Quality bartenders

The Average:
o  The food.  Typical Irish Pub Grub - nothing crazy.

The Poor:
-  The "frat boy" clientele the evening I visited.  Picture mid/late 20-somethings ordering shots at 5:15pm which led to a lot of singing of sh*tty songs. 
-  The trash smell coming from the alley.  Yum.
author: Andreas H.

description:
3.5 stars

The shepherds pie hit the spot, but I'm not sure if it was because: (i) I was hungry, and/or (ii) I had already slammed back an irish car bomb and snakebite on an empty stomach. Now that I think about it the next day (with a slight headache), the sauce may have been reminiscent of sloppy joes. I liked it at the time though! Decent drinks menu that included the major pub standards (e.g., Guinness, Magners). I took a sip of my friend's pomegranate martini, which was tasty. I was a tad surprised by how much shots were, but I guess we were in the financial district (if your goal is merely to enjoy a beer and hang out with friends, however, I can think of a few other bars that charge less, albeit not as nice and maybe not as many concoction options).

The patio area is really cute (I'm a sucker for strung-up lights). And even though we were outside in SF, the heat lamps kept us warm enough to cast aside our jackets.

All of the servers were nice and friendly.
author: J J.

description: Wonderful on-tap beer selection, excellent bangers & mash, and a real Irish feel.  You even have to walk up an alley to get there.  My friend and I can hardly wait to go back ...next time we are in San Fran.
author: John S.

description:
****4 1/2 Stars*****

Love that we stumbled on this place right across from our hotel!  
Tucked into a side street with seating outside...SCORE!

The Shepherds Pie is The BOMB!!  Flavorful and filling and perfect with a pint of Boddingtons.

4 pints, Shepherd's Pie and a quesadilla: $58...a little on the high side for lunch on a week day (minus 1/2 star) but the Pie alone was worth it!!!!

Also can get breezy in this tucked in alley so bring a jacket!
author: Liz K.

description:
If you're looking for a legitimate hole in the wall, I can assure you this is a place you'd want to stop by and visit.  It's literally hard to find, you'll be driving back and forth trying to figure out where Mark Ln is.  My suggestion, find a parking spot and walk.

Came here the other night after the University of Pennsylvania Wharton seminar.  I was a bit over dressed but none the less, I wasn't treated any different.  It was around nine at night and the chilly winter air was a bit rough but I was determined to find a pub, get sloshed, eat some fish and chips, and head on home for the next day's 12 hours shift.  

The alley way was filled with chairs and tables.  Lighting was at a dark red and the heaters were up to warm the bodies outside.  The decor is exactly what you'd expect from a whole in the wall.  Metal placards hung all over the wall, relaxing atmosphere, something I needed after a night of ass kissing.  

My boyfriend ordered the Ruben Sandwich, which was fantastic.  The meat melted in your mouth.  I almost felt like stealing his plate, but I decided against it.  I ordered the fish and chips.  Lemme give you the best word of advice that'll help you out tremendously, fork over the tarter sauce onto the fish and then shovel little nemo into your mouth.  Picking and prodding at it with your fork is senseless.  Fish is cooked so well that it'll melt right off of your fork.
author: Lea M.

description: A solid Irish joint. I originally found it while staying at the Hotel Des Arts back in 2007. It's in a dark alley, but never feed, cold pints, friendly people and hot food are on the other side of that door. Lots of awesome Irish beer on tap- including hard cider. The menu leaves something to be desired. But overall it is a great place to duck in and enjoy a beer with friends.
author: Alison M.

description: Loved this place! The bartenders were cool and the drinks were cheap. Good mix of people.
author: Chris L.

description: I've been to the Irish Bank a few times, either for lunch or just to grab a couple of pints and watch a World Cup match.   I actually came in yesterday for lunch and order a chicken curry, spicy, and a couple of Black & Tans.   The chicken curry was surprisingly good, though not nearly spicy enough for my taste.   The black & tans were refreshing and hit the spot just so.   I love the Irish Bank and it's definitely the place to be when World Cup fever kicks in.   This place will get insanely packed and they set up screens in the alley.
author: David O.

description:
It has been a long time since I have darkened these doorsteps... or shall I say Alleyway. We went on a long walk last night and found ourselves here for a few cocktails and tried out also the Mashed Potatoes with Gravy as well as the Smoked Salmon and Trout with Wasabi Creme Fraiche appetizer.

We added more butter to the potatoes because it taste like it was missing something and the Salmon and Trout plate was ok. My Lemon Drop was meh but you shouldn't come here for a Martini you should come here for Beer or an Irish Car Bomb, I mean after all this is a Irish Pub right? :)

Respectfully Reviewed
author: Pam S.

description:
So my dear friend Tugce is moving back to Turkey so she had her going away informal (Facebook invite only) gathering here. There were about 20 of us art students all sipping bank margaritas and vodka tonics. We didn't eat any food, but the drinks were good and reasonably priced. 

It appears that they close the outside after a certain time so one star deduction to the bouncer that told a few friends to go inside with their drinks or he'll "knock them out of your FUCKING hands and onto the ground". 

Geeeesh, Angry much?
author: Court S.

description:
Wow, first time I've ever been to an Irish pub that I didn't love!

Great atmosphere, hence more than one star, but food and service was really lacking.

Ate at the bar, so my beer came right away but the shepherd's pie took 45 minutes and I had to ask for it three times. Then, to make matters worse, this was by far the worst shepherd's pie I've ever had; it was dry and it tasted like vinegar. Yuk!

May be back for a pint or two but there are way too many Irish pubs in SF to put up with such mediocre food and crapola service......
author: Richard F.

description: We stumbled upon this bar on accident exploring San Fran  because there was a cute outdoor seating area that was very inviting.  We went inside pub and noticed it was kinda slow. Most customers were sitting at tables. We decided to sit at bar because just about every seat was available. The female bartender ignored us for a while and then finally asked us what we wanted??? Since this was a Irish bar I was hoping to order a Signature drink but the the bartender walked away rudely. She came back and asked us what we wanted again and I ordered a vodka redbull and my husband ordered jager redbull  because we felt rushed. We did not try the food because it was hard enough ordering a drink. We asked for our bill and it was about $20.00.
