I hate to rate this establishment so low but its mostly rated on the horrible attitude and service from the bartender.
author: Brooke N.

description:
Really nice spot, lovely vibe with the seats out in the lane . 
I had the sausage chips and beans and didn't leave a crumb !
Highly recommended
author: Eddie C.

description: Been to Irish Times a few times for happy hour during the week and you could never go wrong with it. I came on a Saturday later afternoon during a non rush time and I am so glad I did. James the bartender makes a killer Irish Coffee! He is such a fun character and really took the time making your drink to perfection but most importantly that you enjoyed your time at the pub. Hilarious guy and will definitely come back to have another drink while chatting with James!
author: Adrian G.

description:
As far as a bar or pub goes, The Irish Bank ain't bad. The venue itself is divided in half, with the bar occupying the initial half of the venue, and the restaurant, the latter half. Coming here for a birthday party this past Saturday, the bar was bustling, but not crowded, which I suspect was mostly due to the holidays.

They have a decent selection of liquor and beer on tap, but don't expect "klassier" liquor like 151 to be on hand. And while they have a number of specialty cocktails, including nightly specials, that are made fairly stiff, don't expect the quality and craftsmanship you'd get at a place like Rickhouse or Zero Zero.

Prices aren't bad either, with most cocktails running around the $8 price point, and service, while more "all-business", is not unfriendly either.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - So, contrary to the business details as of this writing, The Irish Bank is NOT wheelchair accessible, as there are a good 3-5 steps to traverse at the entrance, without any alternative way to get inside the venue. That said, the bouncer was kind enough to help lift me up, with the help of another friend at the party. Once inside, expect the usual accessibility challenges of a bar, with high bar counters, crowds, and small spaces. That said, their tables are all at normal height, so be quick to snag one if you need it.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Stopped here for lunch our last day in The City. Great little relaxed pub down a quiet alleyway.

Seat yourself style bar and front of house. 15 draft selections plus many bottled. Food is various pub fare, very decent and FAST turnaround after ordering.

Basket of fries is generous. Removed a star for bartender being too chatty with one customer and making us wait over 5 minutes for our check after we asked for it.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Yesterday, I was with a large group of people following a professional club meeting. There were, maybe, 20 of us in an inside room at the Irish Bank. Other than our group, there was only 1 couple in the large room. It may be that the inside bar was also busy and the outdoor patio busy as well.
A waiter came by to take orders but I was indecisive as to whether I was hungry or not so I just asked for water. Later on as the evening progressed, I started getting hungry and flagged a waiter to ask for an order of fries.
I waited and waited and waited. I felt as if my group would leave soon and I wouldn't get my food, so I got up and walked towards the doorway of the kitchen. Before I got there, there was a waiter also approaching the entrance of the kitchen planning on going in.
I asked, "Is it possible to check on my order of fries?"
The waiter peeked into the kitchen and said, "Yes, it looks like your fries are on the counter. We'll bring it to you." Okay, I just went back to my seat and continued my conversation.
A few moments later, a man in a vest (who I presume was the manager) came over and said," Lady, don't go to the kitchen and ask for your food. We're really busy here," he waves to the large group of tables we've put together for my group,"and we'll bring the food to you when we're ready." This in a very angry tone.
I've never had someone (a restaurant manager) try to chew me out in front of friends in any situation. I value politeness and courtesy. These are values that I grew up with and so, for someone to do this in a setting that is "supposed" to be geared toward customer service it is T-O-T-A-L-L-Y unacceptable behavior. I understand the wait staff was stressed. I understand I was in a large party of 20 people - for which we were bringing business to this establishment.
Unfortunately, because of this experience, I will N-O-T ever return to the Irish Bank Bar. And I will not recommend it to any of my friends or acquaintances. Ever.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Hidden gem!! I don't know how I walked passed this place after many visits to Chinatown. It is located in two joining alleys and the alley I walk by is the one without seating and just dumpsters, so it would make sense to not be seen! Unless, you really look for the Guinness toucan. Once you look down the other alley there's no mistaking that there's a bar here! 

Usually pretty busy every time I go there, but I never had to wait more than a couple minutes to get service. This is mainly because I'm alone and can pony up at the bar. I can't say what it's like for large groups! Sorry that I'm a loser and can't help any future large party seekers trying to find a place to hang. 

They have a pretty strong selection of beers and I'm very impressed with the menu. Not bad pricing on most items. Don't know about wine selection. 

This is the first place that I have been to that takes your credit card to hold on file while ordering food. Can't blame them with the crowd. I can only imagine how many walk outs they might've had in the past. 

Sometimes I walk there after work from AT&T Park. That's how much I enjoy this place.
author: Donald S.

description:
The Irish Bank is a popular meeting spot among my circle of friends, for times when we're waiting on shoppers at Union Square or grabbing a drink before going to nearby venues in the TL or SOMA.  On tap beer selection is OK -- it may not appeal to everyone, but I'm more than happy given that there is Magner's(!!) on tap as well as Leffe, Lagunitas and Mirror Pond.  From what I remember, their wine selection is terrible.  Mixed drinks are strong!   I've eaten here but it didn't leave an impression.. not sure if that's good or bad, given that it's pub food.

Service can be a little slow sometimes, weirdly, I've had the best service when it's been crowded, and the worst service when it's slow.  The outdoor seating is covered and open even in poor weather.  Nice for groups if you've dressed warmly.
author: Heidi M.

description: If I could give 0 stars, I would. My friends and I were out late looking for a place to have a drink and eat a bite. We were rudely kicked out by the Irish bartender for a few of us bringing in food after 10:30pm. When we came back in after a few minutes, a couple of us still looking to have a late night bite, he proceeded to tell us the kitchen was closed and was out of Chimay (the drink of my choice). So he kicked us out for having food when actually the kitchen was closing in the first place a few minutes later. And was also SUPER RUDE in telling me I was the rude one for coming in with food in the first place. I, btw, had no food and had wanted to eat and drink here. Then, even worse- after serving a few of my friends drinks- they closed the outside bar area and we needed to suck down our drinks. Never coming here again.
author: Angela G.

description:
My friend started her birthday shin-dig here and by the time I arrived, they were already a few drinks in, so I ordered up a wine along with the birthday girl. They ordered some food, but from what I saw, they had a sandwich that looked like someone could make from the stuff in their kitchen. Nothing special, nothing even particularly appetizing about it. My friends confirmed this fact.

The service, however, was good, and our waitress was attentive and friendly. Go for the drinks and service, not the food. They have a cool little alleyway :)
author: Leana L.

description:
You must go now!  (trust me on this)
Went to the Irish Bank for a lite dinner and drinks and was sooooo happy to find this LEGIT Irish gem waiting for me down a dark alley.  True story.  The food is casual and good.  I had the chicken strips and the order was HUGE.  It's def enough to split...FYI.  Seating is great inside AND fantastic outside.  Who new that a bunch of tables and chairs would look so inviting in an alleyway once white lights were strung above?  Unexpected and very cool.  The service was crazy fast and the overall experience was amazing.  I will definitely be going back.  Two snaps up for The Irish Bank.
author: Alisa W.

description:
I love the atmosphere and the food. I came back from England and was craving some Fish and Chips. Their Fish and Chips were so good! When I walked into this place, I really felt like I just teleported over to an English Pub.

Definitely try this place out!
author: Megan C.

description:
Food: sausage tastes like frozen fatty nitrate sausage. Shepard's pie was crap, had a strong underlying ketchup taste. Sweet.

Only come here for beer.
author: Greg B.

description:
I dropped by here for a quick drink while waiting for a show to start in Hotel Nikko. I like how this place is tucked away in an alleyway only for those who look to find. I came in and found a seat at the bar. I ordered a Smithwicks beer. When I had this beer in South Korea, the pour was amazing with the creamiest head. Here, it was nothing like that and I was pretty unsatisfied. With that said, If you're going to buy some brew here, get the Guinness since it comes from a "special tap" and they serve it in the Guinness glasses. I probably would've been 100% better than the Smithwicks.

Inside is pretty cozy without that many seats/tables. Service seemed pretty crappy but I expect that from any Irish pub. This is one of the few bars I would prefer going to in downtown SF--everything else is too touristy.
author: Marlon T.

description: Good place to meet friends for a drink and hang out. The food is alright. There's flies/ bugs hovering over the tables every time we've been year over the years- possibly attracted to the sticky beer tables. Would be better with a better cleaning routine.
author: tureg u.

description:
WORST CUSTOMER SERVICE I've had in years from the waitress and the owner. 

I had an open tab at the bar and so did my my coworker. We were one drink in and our blonde waitress asked if we wanted another drink. We let her know we had tabs at the bar and she kindly agreed to take our orders for a second round saying if it was only maybe two beer rounds including the one we ordered with her, we were fine.

We ordered food and were enjoying our drinks, the ambiance of being off work and being able to relax after a 11/12 hour day when a dark haired waitress came to our table to take our order. She let us know our blonde waitress was on break. She asked my coworker for her drink and my coworker let her know we had an open tab. She reluctantly took the order and then asked me if I wanted a drink. I too ordered and then let her know I also had an open tap at the bar. The waitress made a face, said "oh no. You can order at the bar!" And walked away abruptly.

The waitress walked away from my table. She made a face. She also refused us service for no reason. 

I went into the bar, calm and collected and reasonably asked for a manager. While I waited for the manager to appear, the dark haired waitress came up to me and said I have your drink (a margarita). I let her know it wasn't my drink (I was drinking an IPA) and she said "your friend ordered it." I let her know I needed to speak to her manager and told her to please go get him. She continues to try and argue with me before I told her to please leave me alone and get her manager. She ran off. 

The manager came up to me and asked what was wrong. He was a tall Irish man and I was told HE WAS THE OWNER. I explain the situation and he said he had issues with the dark hair waitress before. He went off to inquire with his waitress. 

All the while the waitress had gone back and given my coworker the drink she had previously tried offering me inside the bar.  She apparently profusely apologize to my table and gave my coworker the drink telling her she put it on her tab. Only 5 minutes ago she had refused service. 

While I waited, I figured I would buy another beer. Why not, right? I was merely going to explain the situation to the manager. My drink arrived and the "owner" returned. His words were the worst. "So your friends accepted the drink. What's your problem? Why are you complaining. You're the only one that has a problem." 

FIRST the dude never went to our table to inquire with my coworkers. He merely spoke to his pathetic excuse for a waitress. 

SECOND he basically blamed me for his bull SH!? waitress' HORRIBLE customer service. 

I asked for this man's name and he replied with, "you don't have to know that." My response was "you're the owner and you're not going to stand by your bar? What's your name?" He repeated himself. So I handed him my beer and told him I would like my money back. He got angry with me and told his bar tenders to void my open tab. I NEVER ASKED HIM TO DO SO. He them asked me to leave. 

This man escalated the situation and blamed me for his horrible employees customer service who was trying to cover her ass. This "owner" asked me to leave and said I threw my beer at him which I did not. I merely went in to convey the HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE. This man was angry. Why? Because I said I didn't want my beer anymore and wanted my card refunded for the beer after he tried giving me cash? WHAT KIND OF OWNER DOESNT GIVE HIS NAME AND DOESNT STAND BY HIS BAR? 

Our company will not ever return to this bar and I'll make sure they don't. I'll spread the word to avoid stopping here after work and having other fiends stop here. This place can have their HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE. I'll keep my money.
author: Chris D.

description: Good food and service. Bloody Mary's were good and Alley atmosphere was great. Meals were enough to split, but they will charge you to do so. It was perfect for a quick bite, would have liked to experience the night time crowd there.
author: Christina L.

description: I love this location to sit outside and enjoy a beer.   Today it was very cold,  so I headed inside and got the beef stew.   It had 1 scoop of mashed potatoes,  but it needed 2.  It didn't come with soda bread,  and the stew was a little lacking in flavor.    I knew I should have gotten the fish and chips.   That was the only dish I saw at lunch that looked filling.   The shepherds pie looked like an appetizer,  not priced that way tho.
author: Michelle R.

description: Very good veggie cottage pie. If only they knew the difference between sheperds and cottage pies..
author: Tim D.

description:
VEGAN review: paid about $9 for their Vegan Alternative, which was a medium sized plate of jasmine rice, salsa, beans, and avocado. The beans were pretty good but the whole thing was bland for what I paid for. 

I'm sure this place is better suited for non vegans so I wouldn't say it's not worth checking out! The fish and chips that everyone else got, for example, smelled divine.
author: Dorothy T.

description:
One of my long time favorite for work lunches, and happy hour.

Being a child of two British colonies, I am a huge fan of British and Irish pub grub and especially anyone who can do a good shepherd's pie, or fish and chips. They also have curry chips (fries)... all very well done at the Irish Bank!

Even if it's an overcast day, I still recommend sitting outside as they'll have the heat lamps on.

Great place to grab a pint and some grub in FiDi SF, away from the frenzy outside.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Friendly atmosphere. Great location. Bar-quality food.

I don't go to the Irish Bank for a culinary experience. I do go for a fun atmosphere and a wide selection of spirit and beer - both of which they have. Their outdoor patio is always packed ... because this is a great place to go, especially after work.
author: Zachary H.

description: Nice outdoor seating and solid inside pub. Good chicken fingers and sauces, solid beer selection. Slow service.
author: John W.

description:
I arrived at this place on the arm of a Londoner and he had already been here and seemed to really like it. Any place that will pour me a solid tequila shot (or a shot that resembles half a glass of tequila rather) is OK in my book. 

The bar has a lot of space, and a jukebox which unfortunately was being hogged by a fellow drinker. You can't hear the music from the other room which was a bit bothersome as I love my tunes, but overall the place was pretty legit. 

I'm not sure I would come back however as nothing really jumped out as amazing or spectacular. There are enough other bars in the area that I'd probably give those a shot first.
author: Samantha J.

description:
On a scale of 1 to Dublin, Ireland, my experience felt like that of maybe the Chinatown in Scotland. I don't understand. Why did my Irish Beef Stew taste like canned sardines?? My beef stew, which the waitress highly recommended, not only came out barely lukewarm, it also  tasted like it came out of a can. Pub food is, by definition, delicious, so it was entirely disappointing that this occurred. And of course the stew would be as hot as the surface of the sun after it was reheated... 

If you're here and have to get something, go for the Shepherd's Pie, Fish and Chips, or Calamari. Avoid the Irish Beef Stew!
author: Jason T.

description: Waited for 50 minutes during lunch hour to get a steak sandwich.  Almost an hour wait for a meal! The sandwich itself is slices of meat and grilled onions between two buns.  No sauce or au jux or anything - dry taste.  I am disappointed with your kitchen, Irish Bank.  Two thumbs down.
author: Ivan S.

description: Divey bar down a little alley.  Plenty of tables although it got really busy fairly early.  I don't get proper bangers and mash everywhere, so when I'm in an Irish bar it's usually a given.  The mash was delectable - light and fluffy (I could practically feel the butter clogging my arteries!) but the bangers were slightly overdone, which was a shame.
author: Vikkie N.

description:
Great food, great service, AWESOME atmosphere! 

The shepherd's pie and fish 'n chips were so good. The seating is legit pub style, there is outdoor seating that is pretty cool too. The fact that this is an ally restaurant should not deter you in the slightest, in fact you should go there because it is. The place is a hole in the wall.

Would I go here again? Heck yeah!
Should you go here? Hell to the yeah!
author: Daniel C.

description: Had a hankering for some fish & chips so I stopped in for a bite. Well, it was probably the worst fish & chips that I've ever had. And that's saying a lot as I have had fish on the darkened streets of Bangkok. The fried fish was bland and soft with a soggy breading. Absolutely no crunch to be found. Fries followed suit with a flavorless soggy mess you might expect at the ballpark. Then the coleslaw existed to further paint a below average picture by again being soggy, overly soupy and bland. So, this trilogy has led me here, in stall number one of my office bathroom to exorcise the demons that are now trying to be released from my body. I just hope I don't also throw up just thinking about that horrific lunch massacre I just survived.
author: B W.

description:
Make a withdrawal at the Irish Bank, and drink! Just eat elsewhere beforehand.

We looked up the Irish Bank ("the safest bank in the world!") on a GPS and were led to a slightly uninviting alleyway lined with dumpsters. Was this the right place?

It was! Nestled around the corner of this L-shaped alley was the Irish Bank's charmingly-lit, outdoor seating area - turns out the other end of the alley is where folks are expected to stumble in from! We seated ourselves inside (next time, I sit outside) in a side room, which we had to ourselves practically the entire evening.

Service was good: server Jessie provided an iPod to keep us entertained, and he kept us plied with beer, a round of Irish car bombs, and several kinds of shots.

Food was standard fare, sadly. We shared odd-breaded wings, fried chicken fingers (with a honey mustard sauce), and an Irish Bank burger (cooked medium rare) that a deep pour of HP sauce helped, but I left a bit unsatisfied. Thank goodness I was too buzzed to care at the time.
author: Dave L.

description: Great service. Choice of indoor our outdoor patio. Great selection of food. Would highly recommend the shepherds pie! Yum. And the pomegranate margarita was delicious! Great for late night food too!
author: Courtney S.

description: Loved my Bangers and Mash. A wee bit quiet on a Saturday morning but relaxing and fun.
author: Aileen B.

description:
We have been in San Fransisco 3 days and have been here 3 times, AMAZING!!
My husbands favorite place  - the bangers and mash and fish tacos are to die for. Bartenders are great , bar is exactly what you want in an Irish Pub. A plus, great shopping is close on Grant for the ladies who want to leave their hubbies drinking while they shop.
This is what my husband said to me after the first 10 minutes there - "this place is the greatest place on god's green earth.  I love you so much that maybe you should enjoy a little time to yourself."  Case closed.
author: Key Hole A.

description: I've been here twice both positive experiences. Reasonably priced and delicious food and drink. Great service, and traditional Irish pub feel. I will will be back.
author: Cheryl B.

description:
You walk by a mural of a beautiful fish, proceed to the cute alleyway patio and a lovely lady welcomes you and takes your order. $6 Lagunitas with a ciggy in between and when you leave a large but gentle bouncer will express his regret regarding your departure. I always have a wonderful time here, especially when I order snacks on the side.. (calamari, anyone?)
Also, you should check out their bathroom! They have really old beer menus and adverts that are historically intriguing + a cute faucet.
author: Carolyn K.

description: This place was a blast during a recent SF getaway.  They close early, but worth checking out for sure.   Probably one of the best Shepard's Pies I've ever had and the Harp was very reasonably priced.   I was surprised that they close so early (expected that this sort of establishment would be serving until 2am or close to it), but hey just show up a little earlier and you're good to go :)
author: Scott M.

description: Good guiness at this establishment, it seems better than most around Union Sq, and it's a bit hidden so people cannot find it, which means less tourists. The service is normally pretty decent at the bar, and the outdoor seating is cool overall. I haven't eaten here, but I'd assume isn't not that great :)
author: Jonah K.

description:
I think potatoes come with admission. 

Lots of decent food but it is bar food after all. I've been here a bunch at all times of the day and night and can honestly say this is a great spot although getting help can be hit or miss. I'd love to give it four stars but I'm not made to feel important.
author: Justin S.

description: Good food and drinks. The fish and chips was a bit bland. But the fish was cooked and battered really well. The fish was like falling off. Really nice. The place is really fun and busy. Our service wasn't great but anytime we asked for anything, we got it. He just wasn't waiting on us hand and foot. Which wasn't bad. He didn't hover or rush us. Good place overall.
author: Erica J.

description:
Told the waitress that our daughter has coeliacs disease and checked that the grilled chicken would be OK for her.   The dish arrived and after eating several mouthfuls we found macaroni in it.  Apparently they drain the pasta in to same colander as the vegetables. Given that we had explained that my daughter has a medical condition rather than a lifestyle choice this is inexcusable 
The rest of the food was average
author: Jon R.

description:
This place really impressed me. Located conveniently in an alley right off Bush Street, their outdoor seating area is like a little a little slice of Europe right outside of San Francisco's Union Square. A few blocks away is the crowded, touristy, Union Square chaos (can be fun for shopping if that's what you are into, but not a favorite destination for many locals), but the Irish Bank stands as a little oasis from the mayhem. 

Here you can sit outside on a pleasant evening, have a beverage of your choosing (we didn't try the food), and get the ambiance of a European outdoor cafe like the ones in so many plazas.
author: Mike G.

description: I just really like this bar. Cant explain why, but I enjoy coming in whenever I visit the City
author: Ricardo G.

description:
Sorry to say I wasn't too impressed with this place. 

BF and I came here on his birthday (we didn't let anyone know it was his b-day, and I doubt it would've mattered). It was around 6:45 on a Monday, but it was strangely full, especially in the bar and the front patio. 

The bar was insanely loud. Like, rock concert loud or gaggle of tween girls at the mall to see Hannah Montana loud. I was grateful we got to move to the dining room area of the restaurant, because it was a bit quieter. 

However, there was only one table available and it was used as the servers prep-work station, so we had to have a large bin of silverware removed otherwise there were no other options (the patio area was packed).

Our server was really uninterested in our table and towards the end flat out ignored us. My BF had to literally wave him down, but the crowd had thinned out and we weren't hard to miss, having to sit right next to the only entrance to the kitchen and all. I was told he had an offensive odor, but I didn't smell anything, so take that as you will. 

My food was rather disappointing. I ordered fish and chips, which I assumed would be great coming from a pub. I've never had a bad order of fish and chips from a pub. Until now. 

My fish was breaded and fried maybe hours beforehand. The batter was soft and gross, the fish bland but fresh at least. However, the nasty breading totally turned me off to eating it. I left most of my plate uneaten. I would've asked for something different or ordered dessert if my server had checked on us even once, but that wasn't the case. My fries were boring, and slightly soft/undercooked as well, although much more edible than said fish. BF ate his meal and said there wasn't a problem, but he didn't seem to be very enthusiastic over it, either (bangers and mash). When he tried my fish he agreed that it didn't taste right.

The restaurant itself is clean and well decorated. The food and service was lacking and I don't know if I would hurry back if they can't bother to get fish and chips right. Maybe this is just a place to come and a pint.
author: Bianca U.

description:
My friend and I ate here on October 9th, 2011. It was a late lunch and both of us were quite ravenous. We were sorely disappointed with quality of the food. Allow me to be more blunt: the food sucked. The most simple of food was bland and unattractive.

The fish and chips was bland, the fries soggy, the so-called sauce was little more than mayonnaise in a plastic container. My friend ordered the prawns. They too were bland; the accompanying salad was drenched in a bland dressing that pooled at the bottom of the platter. The vegetables were undercooked - the "chef" didn't even bother to blanch the carrots and broccoli, nor even salt them.

Ok. Now the positive notes, of which there are few. The location is superb, just off the beaten path of Union Square. The outside tables in the ally way are comfortable and welcoming. But that's it.

We learned something that day: Don't go to the Irish Bank for the food. EVER. Go there for the drinks. Go there for the location. AVOID the food.

Food at the Irish Bank? Bad Idea. I just want to make it very clear about the food.
author: Frank L.

description: The smoked salmon and smoked trout appetizer at $10.95 was absolutely delicious and made a great lunch-sized portion. It is one of the best deals on great food I've found here in San Francisco.  I ate it too fast to take a picture.
author: Steven P.

description:
I like that this bar is tucked away back in an alley and I think it's pretty cool that you can hang outside.  Anytime we have family visiting we prefer to take them here vs. Johnny Foley's Irish House.  

The food is good for bar food and they have a pretty good selection of draft beers.  

Service from the lady bar tender is pretty hit or miss.  I've been there a few times over the past few years and sometimes she is really nice and sometimes she seems like she's having a pretty bad day.
author: Evan G.

description: Authentic.  Love that it's hidden away in an alley and you have to search for it.  I've been here plenty of times - usually when I have a craving for fish and chips. Nice beer/drink selection. Perfect collision of locals and visitors.  I like turning on my friends to this place (friends that don't venture out from their neighborhood scene).
author: Adam S.

description:
I lived for 6  1/2 years in Europe and so I feel like I have a pretty good idea what a good pub, a traditional Irish or British pub, should look like and feel like.

I recently moved to San Francisco from Arizona and so I'm on the lookout for good pubs here as well.  Since I work in the financial district a couple streets over from two of the well-known pubs in this area, I decided to check them out.  

You can check out my review on Murphys to see what I thought of it, here we'll just talk about The Irish Bank.  I went twice to each place.

Décor-Excellent.  One of the other posters made a tongue in cheek comment about it being "standard, boilerplate" décor for a pub trying to look authentic, and that's true, but it isn't a bad thing.  Pubs that go out of their way with the wall paraphernalia and signs and the choice of woods and chairs and tables and so forth get an extra nod from me.  This place TRIES very hard to look like a place in Ireland that has been around for 200 years, and guess what?  They succeed.  The result is a place that is warm and inviting, and a place you'd like to have dinner.

Food-Here I will virtually copy and paste my review from Murphys since it applies here as well.  Good, traditional bar food.  Nothing that would make you frown, and nothing that would make you alert the media and throw a ticker tape parade.  I won't go into details on the food because the review would basically be echoing what I just wrote.  It is good food, not spectacular, but not bad either.

Service:  Decent service on the food, but the bartender my first time played hardball with the $10 minimum credit card rule.  I get following rules, especially if you're not the owner.  I also get the fact that MOSTR businesses in the city take either cash only or have a rule like this because of the charges that come with accepting credit cards.  I get all that.  What I don't get is the attitude and look of irritation on the face of the person, seemingly annoyed that I'm even asking about it.  "How much is a cider, then?"  I ask.  "Not $10" he responds.  Ok, thanks Gomer.  How about we lose the snarky attitude and just answer the question?  "How much is a cider?" I repeat.  "$7" is the answer.  So, ok, I get it.  There's really not much on the menu for $3, so what ends up happening is it becomes a two drink minimum if you want to use plastic, a $14-$16 adventure.  OR, you can get an $11 or $12 mixed drink, but that's not what you really want to drink anyway.  So it's an inconvenience for customers who only have plastic, OR you can use the ATM on site and pay another $5 between it and your bank just to pull out the money.  So basically--plan ahead and bring cash, or use your card for multiple drinks or people.  This is all well and good.  I guess my point is I really appreciate folks who relax and take into consideration the fact that it's someone's first time (as I indicated it was for me) and make small gestures to communicate "you're important to us, let me figure out a way to help you out".  The Murphys bartender "got" this concept.  The Irish Bank fellow apparently not.

And before you feverishly jump on and start pounding away on your keyboard at me, Mr. Angry Irish Bank Yelp Reviewer Manager Guy, lol, relax.  :)  I didn't take any stars away because I realize this is the rule you guys established and it is also common in the FiDi.  You still got 4 stars.  I just wish the bartender wouldn't have looked at me and spoken to me like I had just asked him for his mother's  checking account information.  That was unnecessary.

Location:  Really cool that it is down an alley.  Also a cool table/chair set up out front that makes you think Oktoberfest or festival or something.  Very cool..


Final analysis:  The Irish Bank is a good place to go sit down with a group of people and eat or celebrate something.  Good atmosphere, decent food, great environment.    For one or two pints before an event or if you're just going in for a quick drink?  I'd probably stick with Murphys around the corner.

Both are solid, however.
author: John B.

description: Just got around to reviewing this joint. We came here after a holiday party for a few beers. Love the environment, loud and jovial just like I like. Perfect pub/tavern vibe with a nice back room that houses the restaurant portion. Can't beat lagunitas on draft, mmm! Got an order of fries and those were delicious as well, perfectly salted and crispy. This a great place to grab a beer (or two....or three) after work with friends, we'll be back!
author: Evin C.

description:
I've only really stopped into this bar for one thing -- to accelerate the useful service life of my liver.

On a birthday it was a sneak attack -- a quick double shot of tequila to keep the alcie flowing.

But on other nights it's been to bond with coworkers over carbombs and ciders. I can always trust an Irish bar to carry magners.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Cute little hole in the wall bar! I absolutely LOVE its location- it feels like you found some exclusive, underground bar that only the cool kids know about. This is actually my brothers go-to spot after work or if he's meeting people up around town because at least if he gets here early he can get started on a drink.

They have a great beer and cocktail selection. I felt like being girly and going light so I got the Magners pear beer and it was good! Service is great and there's a lot of different things you can snack on so I would highly recommend venturing out to find this place. Since it is in an alley, it might be a little hard to find so just bring some friends and call it an urban adventure.
author: Serena H.

description:
Great place when the weather is warm. You might have to stand for a few minutes before finding a seat. If you have more than 5-6 people then it may be hard to find a seat. Love the outdoor seating area and there are places to sit inside as well. 

Definitely get the fish and chips. Very delicious. Nachos not so much, but this is a Irish bar so why wouldn't you order the fish and chips.
author: Ryan C.

description:
If you're around Union Square and want a pint, this is the place to go. Unlike nearly every other bar in the area, it's not over-priced or touristy. This probably has to do with its discreet location down a little alley off Bush. The interior is pretty much your typical Irish pub aesthetic (and that, of course, is a good thing.) They also have a bunch of seating outside, which is great to enjoy your beer on a nice day.

On a final note, check out the fries!! Soo good.
author: Jon T.

description:
Just ate there about 2 hours ago and I feel sick as a dog

Firstly, and keep this in mind because every restaurant goer should know this.. If they give you a menu with food stains you know there's something wrong.  That's such a huge glaring error that you know their practices are poor.  Never accept a dirty menu and if you can avoid eating at the restaurant you wold be well advised to fill your tummy elsewhere.  Such was the menu I was given, a crusty red stain on the plastic of the ragged old menu screamed to me "get out!"  

But my girlfriend, knowing my rule, was enamored by the cheap ambiance so we remained. 

The Reuben I ordered was absolutely inedible, the corned beef was cut not only  too thick, but also sliced with the grain.  Then it was either steamed or poached. It was rubbery and impossible to bite without the contents of the sandwich pulling out..  Such preparation is absolute culinary incompetence.  I want Gordon Ramsey to yell at them for me. 

My girlfriend got a fish and chips.  The fish was bland,  The fries were fine.  The slaw was little more than damp cabbage.  Nothing was seasoned. 

They were quick and complient when I sent back my Kosher shoeleather.  I just said "give me what she's having" just to be done with it.  

But my fish and chips weren't just mediocre like my girlfriend's.  The dish was greasy, over-browned and had a slightly burned flavor.  

I've been a cook for decades.  I know exactly what it looks and tastes like when you take a cold plate of fries and fish and reheat it in the fryer.  Even tried it for myself to make a quick meal out of an extra plate that never went out.  What I believe is that they had this extra fish and chips lying around, flashed it in the fryer and put it on a plate for me, probably thinking that I would be happy it came out so fast. 

I spoke to my sweet and helpful waitress.  At my behest she rushed the plate away so it would no longer offend me with its odious presence upon my table of dining.   I gave up on eating and had a nice cigarette on the way to the car.

Since I started to write this review I've been to the restroom twice.  The churning in my gut is telling me that reheated fish and chips is a lot frelling older than I thought.   How repulsive and dishonest, it's shameful that they were going to try and charge me 12 bucks for the shitty mess they brought to the table. 

It's two hours later and I am still quite unwell.  I'll probably never eat again.  I think it's mostly the sheer amount of oil I consumed.  When you let fried breaded foods get cold they turn into sponges for more oil.  

Avoid this overpriced, disgusting little rat-hole.  Real talk from the pit of my aching gut.
author: J P.

description: So we are walking down Bush Street looking for somewhere to eat dinner and across the street we see an alley full of tables and people eating and laughing and it just looked like fun. We crossed the street and looked at the menu to find Irish comfort foods that we could not walk away from. We sat outside on one of the warmest nights I've seen in San Francisco and it was just a lovely warm atmosphere. We ordered the Shepherds Pie and Irish Stew. They were both delicious! The service was pleasant and the food came out quickly.  If you find yourself walking by, give this place a try!
author: Marlyn S.

description:
OK, first off.... I have been to Ireland so I have MAD street cred here.... haha!!

This place looks and feels like it is an old school pub from Ireland!!! Not sure if they had the heat cranked to mimic the surface of mars but wow it was a warm one in there... we ordered on the patio but unfortunately we got there when the patio closes....
(earlier than the bar due to the people living upstairs, [side note, you don't want to hear a loud bar below you then don't move above a bar]) 
I digress....
So started our drinks and moved into the bar but couldn't stand the heat so we got out the kitchen. 

Would have stuck to a solid 4 stars but the waitress was kinda bitchy and maybe it was just because it was the end of her shift but we didn't appreciate it and then the million degree interior was a bit much.

I will go back though cause I love me a good Irish bar!!! :)
author: Mike H.

description: The Palace Hotel concierge recommend this place when we asked her for a bar that had good food. She described it as a pub feel and I agree. I like spots like this and could totally see it transferred directly to the streets of London. It's down a little alley. There is a sign on the main road with an arrow to indicate the alley. There are outdoor tables, obviously a bar, some tables inside, and then some stools around barrels. I ordered the shepherd's pie and really enjoyed it. It was served in a bowl having been baked lightly. The meat and veg mix was sweeter than I've had other places, but was good. It was stopped with mashers, lightly toasted from being baked. There was no waiter service that we got though I saw other tables being served. I ordered at the bar, though a bus boy did frequently come around. Fun night out; the place was pretty busy, but not uncomfortably packed.
author: Ben S.

description:
Love the location and atmosphere.

Good history. Irish friend took me here and shared some amazing stories. Highly entertaining place if you keep your eyes and ear open. 

Bar-quality food as expected. Loved my Reuben!
author: Arthur C.

description:
The Mac and Cheese is so good.  It's not heavy or what you would expect but delicious.  I love this place for lunch.  You can't go wrong with the Turkey Club.

On a cold day, the room with the "fireplace" is perfect
author: Amanda K.

description: Great little alley way Irish pub style spot in the middle of the bustling financial district of SF! Love to come here especially on an above average temperature day and sit outside. Love to come here on a week day when it's quiet and calm only steps away from the busy mess that is SF.
author: Anthony M.

description: Get the blue cheese fries...awesome.  Best place for lunch in union square.  I've been here at least 30 times and it never fails.  It's such a great place to take guests too because it is down a cool alley.  Very unique place.
author: Greta R.

description:
One of the best Irish Pub in town, the Guinness is poured perfectly, for a coinisseur it's really important.
The food is also reaaly good, service is quick and friendly. I highly recommend the smoked trout and salmon, it's light and fresh. With a Guinness of course :)
author: Tom L.

description:
Decent beer list - forgettable steak sandwich, portion was tiny, fries were overcooked and the shock top wasn't as cold as it should have been.

Menus on outside sitting area had mold on them... Shoulda left right there but I was hungry and a bit jet lagged. Pass on this joint
author: Fernando D.

description:
We were in San Francisco over a long weekend with friends visiting from overseas and decided to pop in here for a quick lunch. After taking a table outside, we were promptly brought menus and our orders taken quickly. This was the last time we saw our waitress throughout the rest of the meal.

The outside dining is nice and the location is great! Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for the food. Two friends opted for burgers that ended up being cooked well done instead of the medium they'd requested. I ordered fish and chips that were very bland, a bit soggy, and had batter that fell off the fish. Our other friend ordered a BLT. She was satisfied.... after all, how do you screw up bacon, lettuce, and tomato?

 We sat for about 30 minutes after finishing our meal. I saw our waitress duck behind the building at the end of the alley to have a cigarette and when she returned, we STILL waited another 10 minutes to be checked on.

All in all, mediocre food and horrible service. I could honestly never recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Bre S.

description:
Haven't been here in years and so glad we stopped by! 

What a lively little house of ear-splitting Guinness and whiskey imbibery (new word for licking your lips after guzzling dark booze). The cavernous back room where groups of young professionals scream to each other across a void of weathered tables filled with fish and chips is not for sensitive ears. 

Catherine and Meg serve the sober and drunk with sweet smiles and sass. The walls are filled with framed images of Ireland and Irish heritage. Lots of laughter and decent music flowing around the communal tables and crowded barstools.
author: Helen K.

description:
6+ years later  and I"m quite the regular here, at least 2x per month, usually with work colleagues.

I could write a book based on some of the fun times that I've had.  The food and service is excellent for bar service.  I think I'm on a first name basis with some of them now.  

Very fun San Francisco institution, but I would steer clear on sacred Irish days, like St. Patty's or Bastille Day (yeah I know it's French.)

The chicken tenders are the best of all time.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Found a space, had planned to eat at Oz but we were told they were closed after we sat down, got comfortable and started looking at the menu...looks interesting though so we'll give it another try.  Since we already parked, we walked around to see what else is available - what do we see but Irish Bank...we walked inside and came upon the confession booth.  It's empty and the perfect spot for a late lunch.

Like the ambiance, jukebox with interesting mix of CDs, back dining room can be "private" with curtains drawn.   Our waitress was friendly.  

What we had:

smoked salmon and trout with creme frache (horseradish) over toast w/ mixed green in balsalmic vinagreitte $10.95? - the salmon is better but the trout was good too but a bit salty so much better w/ the toast.  the horseradish creme frache helps tone down the saltiness and adds a bit of freshness and a slight kick

The Bank Burger - choice of cheddar, swiss, or jack - $9.95 - we chose Swiss and asked for medium rare but it came out medium.  A bit small, ok, came with steak fries that were not bad 

Hubby had the Kilkenny beer - $5.50 - not bad but flat

I had the Irish Coffee - Tullamore Dew whiskey, heavy cream, Cafe Trieste coffee -$7.00? - cream was super thick and sweet but generous on whiskey
author: Gloria H.

description:
Awesome atmosphere inside and outside in the alley. Great service.  Perfect Guinness.  A very easy place to hang out for a while.  

Guy at the door was friendly and funny.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Abysmal service, meh food.

I hate to write a one-star review but the there is no option lower so I will have to stick with one star. I went the night with my ten year old son to grab a bite-our hotel is around the corner. He was excited to go to an Irish restaurant as there are a number of good Irish pub/restaurants in our hometown. However, we walked in the door and no one spoke to us. We stared at the waiter and waitress who were deep in conversation, glanced at us, and continued to chat. Eventually (after about five minutes) the waiter looked up and told us to seat ourselves. We did so. After another 10 minutes later (while the waiter and waitress continued to chat) , the waiter eventually deigned to bring us some water. When my son asked what was on the nachos, the waiter sighed as if he had never had any question the nachos before-certainly not a 10 year old boy. When the nachos arrived, they were exactly what I might have concocted in my microwave-store-bought chips, some cheddar strewn over them, and nuked. My son got fish and chips which arrived burned and I got irish stew which had an odd, sour taste about it. The food was brought to us by the busboys. I called out to the waiter three times (and I tend to be quite patient with wait staff-it can be a hard job) but there was no other way to get his attention. I called out for drink refills and for the check. Then when we received the check, we realized they had charged us $2.50 a person for tap water. I was surprised because the waiter had never mentioned this when we asked for water. The entire experience was sub-standard on every level although the decor is a lovely if typical 'irish pub in a box' sort of decor.
author: Marceline W.

description:
Moderate Prices.
Extensive Beer list.
Extensive Whiskey list.  (only 4 japanese ones tho.)

Their food is par for the course for a pub. Nothing great, but good enough to eat with drinks.

Get;
Fish and Chips: Just some decent fish and chips.
Chicken Strips: These taste like the frozen kind, but they give you a lot and we all know we still eat the frozen kind.

Other notes:
Their Fries are steak fries.
author: Steven F.

description: Classic SF spot, you must visit at least once.  Great Irish Pub hidden in the alleys of downtown and dripping with old time awesome.  Pub grub is good, both authentic and well executed.  Beer selection is a major selling point as is the atmosphere.
author: Patrick S.

description: Meh- after a long day of walking we saw this place near China Town. The atmosphere is pretty cool. Our family ate in the patio area. Our first server (woman with shaved side of head) looked less than pleased to serve us....after waiting about 10 minutes for her to acknowledge us. She looked even more disappointed when we only ordered an iced tea. She must have gone on break because the other waitress (green hair) took care of us. She was much sweeter and attentive. We were kind of glad that surly shaved hair chick was on her break. The food was just ok- typical Irish faire, nothing really to brag about. It was nourishing comfort food after a long day of walking. Walk on....you can find something better.
author: Jasmine T.

description:
Holy MACARONI... and cheese! Just one of the many reasons this place is amazing. Seriously though, the mac and cheese is super cheesy and baked so It's golden on top mmmm!

The Mac and cheese isn't the only amazing thing on their menu, actually everything I have had there has been great. They have some classic Irish dishes like corned beef and cabbage, Irish beef stew and Sheppard's pie. Of course, they also have a great selection of beer.

The inside of the bar definitely feels like an Irish pub, even the bartenders are Irish (accents and all), but I prefer sitting outside in the alley. It's great for groups.

If you are in SF on St Pats, this is THE PLACE to be! They close off the entire alley and have a huge street party. Live music, DJs, tons of Irish beer and tons of people!
author: Jennifer W.

description: Awesome place! We took our two children (ages 4 and 2) here after a late night walk in China Town and this place was an unbelievable find! Great food, good drinks and amazing company. Would come back here, any day of the week!
author: Julie S.

description: Mark was our bartender and he was amazing. The food was great too. I would highly recommend this place, look for Mark.
author: Missy G.

description:
I came here this week for happy hour with my co-workers. To start the table ordered a basket of fries. The fries were really good, big, thick cut, and well salted.

I ordered a Smithwicks and an order of the macaroni and cheese. The Smithwicks was a little flat, but wasn't undrinkable.
The macaroni and cheese was pretty decent. It was creamy and was topped with bread crumbs. I only wish that it had been baked in the oven for a little while before it was served. 

I want to come back here and try their curry fries, I hear they are good...
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Where pints, elbows and boots come to rest.

I met up with a friend of mine here during one of those wet and gloomy SF days for an early lunch and with my new boots strapped on (second day of breaking them in) I stomped my way through puddles and around potholes to meet up with him.  Once in, it reminded me of what a true pub would be like:  dark, dark woods, benches, and mostly men were present.  I was right at home  ;o)

The Irish Bank has paid many a time homage to St. Pat's day and the special evening where places are packed to the gills with people making merry in addition to the flasks hidden in their pockets.  Ah, the days of celebrating.  

Today was different, although my usual excuse of not being able to down a pint was made short when a 1/2 pint was brought around.  I normally can't drink more than 1/8 of a beer (really can't handle it) but this little thing was so cute and so good.  The perfect accompaniment to the Irish Bank Burger, at my bequest, medium rare.  This came topped with the best bread bun I've had in a while.  It was puffy, rounded and soft: the only thing ladylike about my meal.  The fries were stubby renditions of the usual steak fries, but the salty crunchiness was the perfect balance to my savory hamburger.

My friend had the stew which came with massive chunks of stewed beef and a hearty scoop of mashed potatoes.  I would have elected for that dish, if I had not already made my mind about the burger.  The fish and chips selection was volunteered, but if I ate that much fried stuff, I would have been taken out on a stretcher!

I like this place because there is nothing frilly : you come in, order your food, get your pint and carry on like a bunch of men.  Just leave your high hats at the door.  Not allowed.
author: Miika M.

description:
Overall, maybe a good soccer bar??? it definitely has the ambiance for it. But other than that, I'll probably not be back again... The cocktails just didn't cut it for me. Ladies, this is definitely not the place for a girls night out. 

1. Service was meh. The server looked impatient because we had a big group and he was annoyed that I put in another order at the last minute. Despite me taking the effort to get out of my seat to find him and give him my order. Come on! More drinks = more tips... why so sad buddy??? 

2. My cocktail underwhelmed me. I had the pomegranate margarita that tasted way too sweet!!! You would think they were making a cocktail for a 6-year old! 

3. Food (bar food) 

- Fish tacos - meh. No idea why they decided to serve steamed fish instead of fried ones??? come on, it's bar food. It's meant to be greasy, unhealthy and tasty!!! 

- Fried Chicken wings - ok. The buffalo sauce was good :) 

- Thick potato wedges - ok. Not as good as the fries in Mc'D though.
author: Amanda L.

description:
The lady and I retreated from a noisy-ass nightclub to something more up our alley.  A place with decent priced beer, good music that's not on too loud, and space to move our elbows.  The Irish Bank saved us that night, as we had a lovely time with the wonderful patrons that made lovely single-serving friends and a visit from our old friends, Jameson and Guinness.  The decor in the bathrooms are very interesting, the bartenders are friendly, and they played The Doors, The Clash, The Stones, and The Beatles while we were there.  

Thank you Irish Bank.  You saved our evening!
author: Thai D.

description: One of my favorite alley resturants in San Fran. Awesome to hang-out outside and have a pint of five!
author: Greg F.

description: Cute little Irish pub with alley way seating. This place is perfect for hanging out with friends due to the large amount of seating and large selection of beers, food, and cocktails. I highly recommend coming here if you don't want to deal with the crowds at other bars! Cheddar fries and fried calamari were delicious and service was excellent!
author: Jenann P.

description:
Authentic! As in, full of Irish people! From Ireland!

The location down the alley is very charming as is the interior. This is not too much of a scene-y type place and has an "everyone is welcome" atmosphere (although, I imagine due to the downtown location, probably attracts a lot of finance types). If I lived in SF, I would become a regular. Food looks like legit pub grub, can't wait to come back and try it.
author: Crystal J.

description: My favorite place in San Francisco. Food is exactly what you'd expect from a pub and the atmosphere is right there with Killarney.
author: Trev W.

description:
The first time we came here, it was fantastic, loved the food, service was good, fairly quick, and we left full and satisfied with our meal and experience.

Second time here, our server REALLY sucked. After our food came we were abandoned, no water refills, no asking if we were ok, and we had to ask for the bill eventually when we realized no one was watching our table any longer. The food was still great so we will probably give it another try but if we have another bad experience we will likely pass in the future.
author: Jim B.

description: Had a fun late lunch outside in the ally. Super friendly service and had a decent bar food menu. Although, not completely traditionally Irish, it was still tasty. Would be great for a happy hour or a place to start the evening. would suggest for a casual hangout session.
author: Ernesto M.

description: Five years later, our group met again -- this time for our tenth anniversary -- and the proprietors of the Irish Bank were once again helpful in setting up our arrangements and taking care of us during the event. Much appreciated!
author: Dave S.

description:
Love this place. Fabulous outdoor restaurant/seating area. Over 100 seats. Tables for 10 and 2-4 people. Crowded to mellow depending on time of day. Eclectic crowd.

Big afterwork crowd. 

Excellent Pub food. Never disappointed. Love those Blue Cheese fries.

Incredible selection of drafts. Love their CA and OR IPA's.
author: Anthony A.

description:
Unimpressive in every way. 

Fish and chips...fish nice sized but breading was soggy and seperated from fish, cold flavorless fries.

Reuben had alomst no flavor. Kraut was not even noticeable. 1000 island was not homemade. Cole slaw was wet and bland. 

Wait staff looked as depressed and uninteresting as the food tasted. We were waiting to leave...

:(
author: Samantha B.

description: Just finished a late lunch. The burger was great and so was the long islands! Our waitress Jen was awesome.
author: Jay M.

description: I went to this place the other day with my family and the food was just awful! I ordered a pomegranate margarita and it was mainly filled with ice. It was so watered down it was like drinking from a juice box. Another member of my table ordered a cocktail and it was also super watered down. I tasted it. It was like water with food coloring and little syrup. Then, our food comes out. I ordered a cheeseburger medium cooked. That patty was so over-cooked that it was hard to chew. My jaw was hurting after finishing the burger. It was so burnt that I was able to scrape the bottom of the patty and watch it crumble. That patty was dryer than the California drought. I didn't want to return it because I hate wasting meat, though that meat was already wasted. Finally, the fries were way undercooked. I asked for some new fries, so when the waitress returned my plate with hot fries, she told me those were completely fresh. I could tell they were not fresh, because the one fry I took a bite out of was still on the plate and though some fries were softer, some of the fries were still undercook. Don't even get me started on the steak that another member of the table ordered. That person too asked for a medium cooked steak and it was obviously well done. I will never go back to the Irish Bank. And the worst part was that my family paid over $100 for this garbage!
author: Eric M.

description:
Beer in an alley. What more needs to be said.  5 Reasons to like this place:

1.  Great spot for meeting friends
2.  No Fuss Wait Staff
3.  You can smoke
4.  Cool mix crowed
5.  Best place to start your St. Paddy's Day drinking
author: G R.

description:
I really would like to give the Irish Bank more than three stars, but they automatically lost a star for service and then another for an abysmal draught beer selection. My boyfriend and I came here for a late night drink and decided to get a scotch. They had quite an impressive scotch selection (as well as whiskey and bourbon) and we had trouble narrowing down which one we wanted to have. I settled for a Balvenie 12 Year and my better half went for the Glenfiddich. We both were happy with our selections and slowly sipped on them while we took in the bar around us. It seemed to be mostly tourists, which made sense given it was a Sunday night and there are more than a handful of hotels within walking distance.

If you're looking for an Irish beer, they had a few on draught, but their American craft selections were pretty terrible, ranging from Shock Top to Lagunitas IPA (I love this beer, don't get me wrong, but it was the ONLY beer I'd drink there). By California being such a brewery laden state, I would have expected a bit more than their 8-10 beer offerings.

Lastly, the bartender was pretty indifferent towards us, barely acknowledging us and seemed to be put out by us asking for the scotch list. He didn't ask us if we wanted another drink after we finished, and took forever to get our bill. This was ridiculous considering we were one of three parties at the bar and the restaurant was pretty dead overall.

Regardless, if you're close and looking for a drink or two, The Irish Bank will do the job.
author: Megan K.

description: I like the Ruben. When it's not too crowded it's a great place for some pub grub and beer.
author: Harris H.

description:
2 of us walked there after having lunch@Kuletos. Loved the outdoor seating and even the inside though wished they hadn't re-done/polished the wood floor which gave it a "new" look which didn't sync with the rest of the decor. 

Had an IrishHoney whiskey and a Pisco - both at $6 each. 

Extra star is for the fact that you walk down an alley to get to it and it was a nice reveal!
author: Renuka V.

description:
I went here for dinner with a friend.

It has a cool location in an alleyway. The food is mediocre bar food. The fries weren't very flavorful, the burger was standard fare.

People smoke in the outdoor alleyway which sucks.
author: Max H.

description:
Great after-work place to get a few drinks. I had a really pleasant experience at this bar. It wasn't too crowded and we came on a Friday after work. There is outside seating, as well as inside, but we sat inside and it has a really nice vibe. There are plenty of tables as well as bar seating. The bartenders were semi-attentive, but the drinks were definitely a good level of strong :)

They also have food - we ordered the calamari and the fries. The calamari was so yummy! Definitely a place I'd like to revisit.
author: Junel S.

description:
My girlfriends and I were lucky to accidentally spend a few hours catching up in the "confessional booth."  We had martinis and margaritas, and after a couple of those, I don't think we really cared or remembered much about the quality of the drinks. In terms of food, the only thing we ordered were some fries that came with a curry dipping sauce. I guess it was good-we ate it all!

The waitress didn't make us feel rushed and checked on us regularly. The place was packed when we went in, but the crowd was dwindling by the time it was midnight, which is when I think we left.

I'd definitely come back here when I'm in SF again.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
This was my first time here and since they're right around the corner from my work might not be my last, but all I can see getting here is a beer.  Can't fuck that up.

I ordered a manhattan which expected to be good since this is a place that should know whisky but it when it came out, I already knew it was wrong, the color was clear almost like a martini and the maraschino cherry in it was just wrong!!!   

I asked for a beer instead al though the waitress seemed surprised that I didn't like my drink.  

Then we ordered the salsa and guacamole which she said was fresh.  What she failed to say was that it was just some mashed avocado and some tomatoes in a bowl, no seasoning of any kind.  And to top it off the pit was in there, when we asked about it she took it back and removed the pit, no apology, no extra guacamole.  Enough said.
author: Inga W.

description:
Certainly a pub to be visited, somewhere nice and warm.

Well, this is a place I will remember fondly when I return home after my holiday. 

Lets begin with the location, FANTASTIC! The pub is located on mark lane all by it's self and it helps to create a feel that you are away from the hustle and bustle of the financial district. The decorations of the pub help to make you feel right at home, it has a rather nice cottage feeling & the amount of TV's are not overwhelming.

The selection of beer is great, although it is a great shame that they have no local beers on tap. The price as well is reasonable, and the soda fountain with free refills is a nice touch. The food as well is a great selection of some local area ideas and traditional food. The Potato Skins are a must for anyone wanting a cheap main meal!

The staff are what really make this pub one of the best in San Francisco, they are fun and remember any one who goes in. They offer helpful advice and if you go by your self, like moi, you end up chatting away to them. I would recommend the staff be allowed to have a drink or two behind the bar, but each owner to his own.

A home away from home, and a must no matter what!
author: Simon Lester B.

description: Very cool place. It is loud at happy hour on Friday. I bet it is an awesome place for a mid week stop by for a pint
author: Padre C.

description: Hands down our favorite pub to play the juke box and enjoy the true service of a bartender that enjoys his work and creating a fun and memorable experience for his patrons. Just go, you're going to live it!!!!
author: L L.

description:
It's a pub. They have beer and cider and liquor and bar food. If that's what you're looking for, you can get it here.

I went to meet up with a gaggle of anthropologists, and the staff was accommodating of our group. There were Jameson promoters there, giving out samples and trying to upsell us on buying some Jameson at the bar (most of us were drinking beer after a long day of conferencing). The bathrooms were adequate. All in all, there's nothing to which I'd object.
author: Bria D.

description:
Irish Bank! Its magically delicious! This is our go-to whenever we're in Union Square, its a bit hidden - you have to go through an obstacle course just to get in - through an alley, dodge the homeless and the dumpsters, but once you're past all that - you're in! It's quite charming here. The staff is nice and friendly - the bartenders are very nice, quick, and personable. If you're unsure about a particular beer or a drink, they will allow you to sample.

I've never had a bad experience here, and the service has always been absolutely amazing.
author: Wenda T.

description: If you want good drinks and what you'd expect for good Irish pub food, go here!! We got the Reuben and side salad and were satisfied! I got a lemon drop shot that was delicious and then Deep eddy lemon vodka and soda which was also good! It's surprising hard to find a nice little dive bar in SF. This place makes the cut!
author: Rose K.

description:
Got off work early and stopped in for a quick Gunness. i asked the bartender if this was real Irish Guinness or San Francisco Guinness. just stares at me. maybe its the accent so I repeated the joke. I do not think he gets it what is with that her?

maybe its all the cold weather but we like to make a lot of jokes and tease where I am from. the food smelled good but I wanted bar banter after my shift.. and one last thing there are lots of big strong looking men in suits up this alley ladies. good and burly like our Southern gentlemen but with suits on!
author: Agatha K.

description: First stop for my St. Patty's day fun-day and i did not have a good experience!  The bartender was snobby and somewhat a bitch!  I guess that's what happens when Asians tried to have fun on St. Patty's day lol
author: Katie N.

description:
Guinness on tap....good ass chicken wings....thick, garlic steak fries....OH...it's party time.  

Good, hardy food to cushion your stomach for a night out drankin...OR just to satisfy your guilty cravings for classic fried/unhealthy food...OH but they have huge salads if you want a lighter something... (it's your choice...)

Chill, plenty of seating, friendly waiters/bartenders, reasonably priced (better than some upscale restaurant that gives you half the food/half-ass food for double the price) ... 

CRAVING the fries and chicken wings with a nice, cold beer.

CHEERS
author: Kat C.

description:
Looking for a snack and a beer in the SF heat, then I recommend you get over your fear of dirty alleyways and grab a stella and nachos at the Irish Bank. A pleasant surprise. Especially when you consider that an Irish pub has some decent nachos. what compelled us to order nachos is beyond me, not my decision. but it worked out well. We ended up coming back later that night with some more people and we all had nachos.

Price: all very reasonable.
Service: very nice wait staff both times i've been there. No eye rolling, just beer and nacho serving.
author: Alex F.

description: Nice setup: a cosy hidden little alleyway right in the heart of the financial district. They have a large outdoors seating area that's perfect in the summer time.
author: Edwin C.

description: The last time I was here was a year ago and I've been craving it ever since. I'd drive the hour and a half just for the shepards pie. The beers are good, guiness perfect poured. I really like the alley way and also the old fashion sewing machine turned into a table, Hella bad ass
author: Holly C.

description: Stopped there for an appetizer. What we got were amazing chicken nachos and amazing fresh brewed iced tea. With the cute outside seating in the alleyway they have taken over I highly recommend it.  Kind of tucked away so you do have to hunt for it.
author: Melissa C.

description: We walked into the bar/restaurant through the ally where all the trash bins were, not a very good impression but once you passed that I really liked it!  The table outside looked like a really fun and wild atmosphere.  We went in the middle of the day; we will go back some busier time!  I liked!!!!
author: Man S.

description:
I LOVE Irish pubs. 
I've been drinking at them for many many years.
Probably since before the tall, blonde snotty ("snooty") barmaid has been breathing air.
Yet she refused to make my Jameson as I ordered it, and insisted I try the more expensive brand. I obliged.

Why? Why try to steer me away from my beloved Jameson?
Why give me attitude? 
Why ignore me 15 minutes later when my drink was bone dry?
author: Bonnie B.

description:
The 5* is for the service, ambiance and location.  4* for the food.

We stumbled over this place after a long day walking in San Fransisco sightseeing (okay, I've been sight-seeing in SF for over 20 years, but still....) on an unusually warm October day.

The restaurant opens up into an alley with outside seating.  Soft white lights are hung across the alley, and fun old signs are attached to the walls, so it is a great visual feast.  The lighting gives a soft reddish glow and the murmer of friends chatting provides great background music.


Our waitress told us she'd like to get our order in sooner rather than later because she was just about to put in an order for a large (20) group and didn't want us to wait. Sweet and thoughtful.

We drank beer and chatted while we waited for our food to arrive.  I ordered the burger, my friends ordered fish & chips, bratswurst & saurkraut.  Burger was good.  The brats that I sampled were fantastic!  

Definitely one of the nicest meals and locations I've had.  Loved, loved, loved the ambiance.  It's like in Sleepless in Seattle...,You don't want to be in love, you want to be in love in a movie.  That kind of ambiance.
author: Susanne R.

description: Great Shephards Pie and Mac and Cheese! Awesome atmosphere and great service. A really good find at the end of an alley.
author: Bubba M.

description: It's a fair place to sit down and have a drink. Not the top of my list, but not the bottom. Right around the corner from work.
author: Doug R.

description: I must admit I only stop for a drink and the Irish Stew is sublime.  It has a lot of atmosphere and defiantly posses that old world charm of San Francisco.  Its a must on your list if your new here.  It reminds me of England and Ireland with their narrow streets, in this case an alley, same thing though.  The company is great and you can go alone at happy hour because there are so many to talk to in the bar area you don't feel alone.  You can smoke outside and the staff is great, when it's not jammed.  An excellent place to stop and have a chat and something to eat and you will come back for more.
author: Allan R.

description:
Irish Bank
SF: Union Square
Saturday January 1, 2011
2 Stars

This place is pretty authentic i.e. smelling of piss and serving crap food.  I am glad this was a stop over until the Rick House opened.  I drank a mediocre Vodka Soda and ordered the Vegetarian Shepard's Pie which was small and way too watery.  Plus I ordered cheese on top of the pie and they just put a Slice of American Kraft Single on top.  Not Good.
author: Leonard L.

description:
Now I remember! As I walked out of the girls' bathroom, I had the timing spot on to catch the door of the guys' bathroom being opened simultaneously, so I could totally see some guy piss away his last few beers. 
That's unfortunate.
Even w quality Brogue.
author: Meg W.

description: Classic Irish pub. Good atmosphere and vibe, great beer selection and damn good food. This is the kinda bar that just makes you feel at home
author: Phillip F.

description: My bar away from home. Whether it be pregaming before I go out robusta nightcap before bed. This is my downtown watering hole
author: Anthony H.

description: The fish and chips can run hot and cold.  The last time I tried it, it was a soggy mess.  I should have sent it back: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-irish-bank-bar-and-restaurant-san-francisco?select=Wy2i-nc5lIoPvgOBaNhlXg#Wy2i-nc5lIoPvgOBaNhlXg
author: Scott F.

description: Great place for a pint. Good location. Heated outdoor seating. We had a beer in an old confessional which made for a nice, private place for a chat. Will definitely be back.
author: PT D.

description: I always love coming here for a Guiness. Food is decent too.
author: Kimber C.

description: Great bar. We were hungry and 3 of us ordered the fish and chips which are fabulous and came out in less than 10 minutes. Another had the stew and said it was great. We had three rounds of cocktails, everything from a Negroni to martinis to Moscow mules and finished with Irish coffee. All were very good and the bartender was great. Get the Irish coffee! Reasonable prices, tucked into the alley that is Mark Lane.
author: Carolyn R.

description: Before finishing up an accomplished evening of boozing.  Our group got sick of a cocktail bar we were at when it became insanely crowded.  We decided on another drink and stopped at the Irish Bank.  It was a Wednesday night and we practically had the place to ourselves.  One would think that would in turn equal excellent service.  Unfortunately, that was not the case.  The bar keep seemed annoyed that we decided to even patronize his place to the point of actually being rude.  Not that he even had to do anything.  We ordered drinks and sat down at a table.  We never saw anybody after that as the staff was too busy cleaning and trying to get out of there.  We finished our drinks and moved on.  Unimpressed.
author: Scotty C.

description: It's a fun place to go with a rowdy group on a nice day if you want to sit on the patio. The servers are friendly but they're always overwhelmed with giant mobs of customers. As a result you'll sit at a crowded table for hours getting a couple drinks at a time, drinking way too much beer and wishing you ordered more blue cheese fries.
author: Laura W.

description:
DRINKS:
Regular full bar drinks


SERVICE:
Regular


ATMOSPHERE:
Ah, casual little Irish Pub tucked away in an alleyway - chose this place because it had open seating outside in the alleyway thought it'd be good for group of friends to chill - - but they didn't have them out that night I forget why, because forecast looked like rain?
author: Angela L.

description:
I used to go here when I worked in the FiDi. Normally, it'd get 3 stars. Decent food and good but inconsistent service.

But a few weeks back, I witnessed a class act from the folks at the Irish Bank. Props to Miguel and crew for handling a trouble maker so professionally. Let's just say, that dude won't be coming back anytime soon. So I'm bumping it up another star.
author: Art O.

description: Causal little bar! Bartenders are pretty cool they socialize with the guest. Beer selection is okay I would suggest to get more liquor. They have a jukebox with some of my favorite bands ( flogging Molly, drop kick murphys) I would comeback here when I visit San Fran
author: Kid C.

description: Great pub like atmosphere to just sit back, relax, and have a cold beer.
author: M M.

description:
I live in Chicago and the whole city thinks they are Irish, which means there are more "Irish Pubs" than folks that are actually from Ireland.  Don't get me wrong, those bars are always a good time, but for the most part, they are just a place where fraternity meets burger and is washed down with a pint.  

I'm happy to say that my preconceived notion did not apply to the Irish Bank Bar.  The place was dark, smelled of rich mahogeny and there were thick accents coming from all directions.  My friend suggested with order chips with bleu cheese, which turned into one of the best decisions of the day!  A mound of fries covered in bleu cheese (see photo) and then sprinkled with vinegar over the top.  As soon as they arrived on the table, I told the waitress that I didn't need anything more than a beer to wash it all down with.  DELICIOUS.
author: Angel S.

description: A bit pricy even for San Fran and the food wasn't the best. It was later in the night and fairly busy but I was expecting a little more.
author: Jer S.

description:
My second visit here and decided I should finally write something. 
An ideal place for dinner, I dont think so. There are many other options around the area. Now if you want some bar food, this may be okay. I had the fish and chips which were not that great, the fish had no flavor. The service was just bad. No water upon arrival, had to ask for it twice. The server was just in a pissy mood (it seemed). 
Granted I should have never done this, but I did. I ordered coffee! Yeah yeah yeah, you might say who orders coffee at a bar! I do! The coffee was cold!
author: Brendan J.

description:
So ventured here with the co after work the other day because we decided eh lets go into the city and grab some grub. Granted our mid set at the time was demanding we get munchies asap so this seemed like a brilliant idea.

Ended up at the Irish Bank... now It may have been my slightly altered state but we learned a few things.

1. there is a sign on the street (one of those sandwhich boards) in the alley where you walk in. The door next to the sign is for a sushi bar
2. wheny ou walk in you walkinto a bar area. The resturant area is acccctually towards the back.
3. you order food from the bar when you sit in that first area. Outside and in the returant area serving is normal style.

Food
