Co got the mac and cheese, I got the sheppards pie. We were in heaven. The food came out hot and was super quick given how busy this palce was. I literally wanter to bury my face in the food. It had nothing resembling low calorie about it but my gawd were both dishes delicous.

Oh note for the ladies, delicous eye candy strewn all over the place. Def def coming back here again for drinks!
author: Meg N.

description:
The Irish Bank gets my 600th Yelp review because I never thought I'd find the place again... let me explain.  

Waaaay back in the day, we're talking 12 years ago when I was barely 21, I came to SF for vacation.  I was a younger, more naive girl then but I was still very adventurous.  Unfortunately, I was with a group of friends who were quite dull and only wanted to do the top touristy stuff.  Well, I split off from my party to explore SF in my way.  On my way around town I met these 2 local kids who, after a glass of Chianti and long conversation on Italian Hill, drove me around SF on their cool retro motorcycles.  It was fun times.  Later that night when my friends didn't show up at our motel and the pre-arranged meeting time, I called the boys again and they came and took me to a hidden Irish pub that I never knew the name of, where I enjoyed my first Guinness.  I thought I'd never find it again... 

Fast forward to last Saturday...  I met a group of friends at a hidden lil Irish pub that Crys B had picked out randomly from Yelp reviews and, you guessed it... it was my mysterious pub from a decade ago!  Yay!!  I can't believe I found it after all these years.  Good times and good memories... 

That being said, the drinks were strong, crowd friendly and there's a room in the back that had plenty of seating with a fireplace.  

My bacardi/diet was 7$ and my friends Stella was 6$.  Don't know the rest of the pricing but that seemed fair for SF.  

The place got packed for a while but was still manageable.   The only problem was the bathroom.  It was durrrrty when we arrived at 9:30 and already had only 1 toilet because the other way way out-of-order.  It'd be nice if they had checks through-out the night or at least before the drinking hours begin.  Ok, we'd also have liked a lil music in the backroom. 

I liked the outside patio they had when we first arrived too.  It was closed later in the night though so I'm not sure what time they pull the tables in for that.  

We'll probably be back since this is a fun Irish pub with Smithwick's, Murphy's and such... and good seating options.  

See ya there!
author: Susan D.

description:
I've been here a couple times and everytime I come I want it to be better, and its not. For starters, they have weird rules about the outdoor patio, that include you can't be standing and drinking? Coming from New Orleans I get really confused when you can't just enjoy a drink outside. Second, its ALWAYS crowded when I go. 

This place could be the most amazing, they should get some more outdoor tables and block it off or something so there are less stringent rules around drinking outside.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Wow this place was sure a find. 

 Get the bratwurst and sauerkraut. You will NOT be disappointed. The mustard they served with it was to die for and everything was cooked to perfection. 

I love coming here although I always order the same thing. Just try different beers everytime.

They have this outdoor patio that you can eat at and smoke! But even though my dream is to live in a world where we can smoke and eat in the same place, I still feel super weird about smoking around people who are dining so I just excuse myself and walk away from the table. 

This place is a gem! Look for signs pointing you down an alley way. You'll love it here.
author: Christina S.

description: I finally went to Irish Bank after all these years!  Good selection of beer.  Food is a-ok (you know, lots of yummy fried food that goes oh so well with cold beer).  Service is good.  Pretty easy to come and go.  Good for groups.  A-ok all around.
author: Maile N.

description: Good food, nice atmosphere. Kind of poorly lit and a but loud for a corporate lunch but a nice place overall
author: Mel P.

description:
I've been here a handful of times. Each time I thought the beer was overpriced, the servers were slow, and the last time I went the waitress tried to steal about $100 from us.

Our bill was like $190, and we gave her about $225 in cash [not a bad tip for just drinks, right?]. Then she came back with a bill for $110 or something. It was incredibly confusing, and was eventually rectified, but I swear on my mother's tits she was trying to pocket that money.

Actually, the only reason I went there was because I was dating a girl that liked to go for a drink there with her boring workmates. But she dumped me, so fuck her and fuck this place too.
author: C D.

description:
Conveniently close to our hotel, my group headed here to knock a few back after our dinner up the street. You walk down a little side alley to enter the bar, which has an adorable outdoor patio area. 

The bar is quaint and cute, this is not one of those corny, tacky "Irish" bars with cheesy names like Paddy O'Leprechaun's or Shamrock McGee's, this is an Irish bar done right. There's an eating area in the back, cordoned off by some curtains, but since we were there to drink we sat in the main bar area. There's also one little booth that reminds me of a little wooden stagecoach. 

The have a decent beer list, more weighted to the European imports, and decent prices too. We were tired and only stuck around for a few drinks, but it seemed like the later it got, the younger and douchier the crowd got. 

Bottom line: Cute little spot that I would return to if I were in the area again.
author: Mary T.

description:
This is your standard neighborhood irish bar.  The vibe was decidedly divey, which I like, but if you're looking for a fresh (smelling), hip bar, this probably isn't your place. 

OK beer selection, plenty of whiskey's and a pretty neat outdoor seating area that could be good for larger groups (up to 10-15 i'd think.  All the tables were full on Tuesday around 7, so might want to call ahead if possible. 

I didn't have any of the food so I can't comment.
author: Nathan G.

description:
Quick rundown of the place:

The Good:
- The outdoor seating in the partially-covered alley is fantastic. The indoor seating is also cozy and comfy. 

The OK:
- The food and beer is what you'd expect at any pub with a more extensive food listing. 

The Ugly:
- Service was robotic.
- I left my credit card there and called the next afternoon to ask if they had it. The bartender who answered the phone said he was the only one there and asked me to call back in 3 hours. Yes, it was my bad for leaving my card there in the first place but having worked in a bar, you know to expect people to forget things at a place where alcohol is served. If you're debating which is more important (a) confirming whether or not a customer left their credit card (which all usually get stored in one place and takes about 2 minutes), or (b) making sure that someone else gets their beer 2 minutes faster...I'd choose "a."
author: Jennifer P.

description: For when you want to really party....
author: Em L.

description:
This is always a favorite.  First off the food - Love the Ceaser, and the Mac & cheese.  The fish and chips are Always good and the Ruben is yummy too!

Second - love the drinks!  Reasonable, great selection

Third - love the tables inside made from old sewing machine tables.

Service at times is so-so, and although the bathroom is clean (a plus) the tables are usually kinda icky. 

But that of course isn't enough to keep me away!
author: Samanta V.

description:
Another one of those places that I frequent and somehow forgot to write a review for. That should be a bit telling that I actually might like this place. (I do, by the way).

The wine is hit or miss at times, but the appetizers are always spot on. Whenever someone suggests this place, the first thing I think is: "YES! Calamari!" Don't forget the chicken tenders either, because those are damn tasty too. 

When ordering your drink, it's best to throw in your order for an appetizer. This place gets packed quickly.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Our table was in an alley
Drank beer
Ate Pub style food
Crowd was very cool, no problems
LOVED IT
author: John R.

description:
I really enjoyed this bar, though I think I'd like it even better when it's not packed with people.  Maybe it's always this way -- the place is definitely popular on Friday nights.

To get there, we walked down a grubby alley  that was filled with dumpsters, only to find another (nicer looking) alley with tables full of people.  It was a rare warm evening in SF and it was a real treat to sit outside at 6pm and not freeze your ass off.

The Irish Bank has an interesting variety of beers on tap.  I chose Czechvar.  It may not be the greatest beer in the world, but I'm part Czech, so I had to represent!  We didn't try any of the food here, but our group enjoyed our beers very much.  The service was good, too, in spite of the fact that it was very busy.

The bathroom situation is the one downside to this place.  There are only two stalls in the Ladies' room, so the line often extends out into the bar, right in the way of everybody.  The wait can be long, so be sure to get in line before it's too late!
author: Raina S.

description: Stopped in for dinner.  Caesar salad, shepherds pie, and draft Guinness, consumed outside in their patio / alley, made for a lovely meal.  I'll be back the next time business brings me back to the Financial District.
author: Spencer F.

description:
I signed up for yelp to leave this review.  I used to love this place, until they gave my debit card to a stranger, then tried to overcharge me for food the same night.  I tried to give them another chance only to be treated like garbage like it was my fault.

So, moral of the story, if they make a mistake, it is your fault.  You are no longer welcome.
author: John D.

description: Very cool spot, especially the confessional seating near the bar. The service was great, our group needed a larger table and the waiter offered to move us before we even asked. Reasonable priced. We ordered appetizers and they were great.
author: Tal E.

description: we love coming here for company happy hours. this place has outdoor seating as well as a private section that is big enough to accommodate for a large group. great staff, great service, and delicious chicken wings. it's a great place to have drinks after work!
author: Ava F.

description:
Came here yesterday night around 10pm to celebrate my friend's birthday. It is in some alley-way. I have never noticed it before and I walked around that area a billion times. There was outdoor seating and when we got there, there was a slight line to get in. The bar itself is kind of tiny but it was pretty lively. The birthday boy was already there and had gotten a corner. The people were really nice and friendly. Right before my friend and I arrived this group of people sang happy birthday to my friend. 

I went to get three drinks, one for myself, my friend, and the birthday boy. It was kind of hard to get one of the three? bartender's attention because they were rushing around pouring drinks. The people in the immediate area helped me. =] I ordered a Wagner's, a shot of vodka, and a white Russian. The total came out to be 19 dollars. I was surprised. I gave a twenty. 

I would have given them 4 stars but the bartender messed up my order. Instead of giving me a shot of vodka, I got a shot of tequila. And I did not get a straw to mix my white Russian. 

Around 11, more people started to leave so we were about to obtain a table and seats. Later I got a sex on the beach. I didn't like it. 

The atmosphere was really lively. I liked it. Also the bathroom was really clean. Theres two stalls in the women's bathroom. The bathroom itself is kind of cramped.
author: Sarah C.

description: I have a lot of good memories at Irish Bank. Its perfect to go with a lot of friends, late at night and hang out at the outdoor seating they have. I came here after work many times. They have a surprising menu with a lot of different kinds of food; perfect for drunk munchies. I wouldn't say the food is amazing, but it does the trick. I am definitely a supporter of Irish Bank. Good times.
author: Dexter H.

description:
I love this place, we sat in the confessional. 

We were hungry and the portions were on the small side so we ordered another entree to split between us. So I can review 3 things, the beef stew is good and hearty but just not enough if you are hungry in need of a hearty meal. The shepard's pie was good too but too small and not worth the price but the fish and chips were delicious, better then some that I have had in the beach town where I live!
author: Liz D.

description: One nonalcoholic beer & some tasteless cheese fries + tax & tip = $15! All for the chance to walk down a dumpster-lined alley to find the place -- and be deafened by drunken braying and choked by American Spirit smoke?
author: Lisa T.

description: Came here for St Patricks Day! Two words to describe it FREAKIN AWESOME! I have come here for lunch and its been okay. But the event they threw for St patricks day with the block party and live band for lunch until late night was awesome! I will definately come back here next year for St Patricks Day!
author: Kyle W.

description:
On a nice day, they set up the tables outside in the alleyway. 
It's a great place to have lunch and grab an Irish beer or an Irish whiskey or both. 

It's a fun place to be on St. Patty's since they close down the whole alleyway and fill it with music, people and dancing. 

Overall, best Irish bar I've been to in the bay and a favorite of mine.
author: Christina C.

description:
One of my favorite Irish bars in SF if not in the us!,  I've probably been here over 10 separate times.   I've been to Irish bars all over and several great ones in Boston and back east, but I always find myself thinking about Irish Bank. Is it that it's a small intimate place? Where you can go to easily engage in conversation? Or that the bar staff are mainly from Ireland and make no nonsense drinks. I always get Guiness but my wife loves the Bloody Mary's!

Overalls we go to SF several times per year and make it a point to stop by Irish Bank each visit. The feel of it is just homey and friendly. A true gem in the city.
author: Aaron A.

description: Such a good bar! Dined early on a Friday evening and it wasn't too busy, lots of free tables inside. Staff were quick and attentive without being annoying. Highly recommend the vegetarian shepherd's pie - they are hard to find!
author: Laura M.

description:
If I could pick a bar that I could inherrit after someone died, it would be this bar. It's very chill, and the food is good. Somehow the Guniess is better here than anywhere else. 

If you go, you gotta try the chicken strips with a side of curry. It's something, that's for sure!
author: Anthony G.

description:
Since I was on a vacation that was supposed to be about having fun and exploring somewhere new (ok, so that is all my vacations - and hopefully yours too), the husband and I decided to use our first day exploring the Financial District, the very neighborhood we were staying in. After wandering around for awhile, drinking sounded like a fantastic idea, so we scuttled back to the shaded alley/patio of the Irish Bank.

We opted to go inside, where I was instantly transported back to my travels through Ireland and its many pubs. One thing I learned about San Francisco, and part of what made me fall so hard for it, is the way a neighborhood or business can totally engulf you in its culture. A cozy bar with dark wood and dim, warm lights, walls coated in pictures and paraphernalia, Irish bartenders and a great selection of beer on tap, I pretty much never wanted to leave. The prices are average, they have TVs to watch sports (they were prepared to show all of the Euro tourney while we were there) and the menu looked great, we just happened to be drinking our dinner that night. I need to go back and get some bangers and mash and some Heniz beans - yum! FYI: that is how you know they are  legit - they have THE beans!

This was a perfect start to our trip and I know that if we lived around there, we would quickly become regulars. Must-do for anyone that loves everything I have been praising about this wonderful pub.
author: Josephine S.

description:
This 1 star review is based on just the burger & fries. 

Awful. Probably one of the worst burgers I've ever had. Completely bland, dry, overcooked and altogether flavorless.

It's the kind of burger you would find at the concession stand of a zoo. Or if movie theaters served burgers, this is how it would taste. The fries also tasted pretty blah. 

To put it into perspective, I haven't eaten a McDonald's burger in 8 years. But if I had a choice between the Irish Bank Burger and a Big Mac, I would choose the Big Mac. 

On the plus side, I love the outdoor seating area here, and the fish and chips that other people were ordering looked delicious. I'm just saying, if you love burgers, avoid the ones here. You will be disappointed. And out $9 to boot.
author: Hannah S.

description:
As someone who is perpetually on the lookout for a good Irish pub, I was happy to learn there is one just a few blocks from my work!

I say come here for the beer and cider selection, the greasy delicious pub food, and the cozy atmosphere inside and around the outdoor patio.

There's a lot to like, but if I had a complaint it would be the service. Slow, minimal, not very friendly. Service aside, this place is a hit!
author: Alyssa G.

description: Was here on Saturday - the day of the st. Patrick's parade - they handled the crowds really well, beers in trays and proper order keeping an eye on people. Band were good too - even if the lead singer did punch someone!
author: Tracy O.

description:
This venue is not accessible. 

Yes, there's outdoor seating - after a fashion, meaning that they may or may not have placed a long table across the entire street in such a way as to prevent ramp users from getting to a seat. (It's also dark and hard to see in the alley, bad for vision-impaired folks.) 

But the loo is inside and up several steps. Inaccessible loo means I can't drink here, and won't be doing so. (Yes, at some locations I will stagger to a potty on my cane - but the indoor part of this place is usually so crowded that it wouldn't be safe to do so.  And most wheeled people don't have that option.) I'll get my Irish fix at the Chieftain or Foley's. 

Food's not bad, booze selection is good, so I'll be generous and give 2 stars. Disabled folks who end up here by accident should know that there are several major hotels within a few blocks; sneak in and use their loo instead.
author: Anne K.

description: Great bar scene in the Financial District. Great staff with Irish hospitality. Only sampled liquids, people say the food is great
author: Steve G.

description:
Points of interest

1. It's hidden in an alleyway off the street in union square. I like that you have to know where it is in order to get there. 

2.  Shepard's pie is alright. 

3.  There's a smoke cloud billowing outside because you can smoke there. Even cigars.
author: Allie O.

description: Great place to come with coworkers or large group of people especially for Happy Hour. On a beautiful day you can sit outside, albeit in an alley but its still fun and casual.
author: Kristan B.

description:
Went last night after we left Barrett hall. Well after about  an hour here.... We went back to hall, we went inside and got drinks but then realiZed inside was stuffy air so we asked if we could start a tab and go outside. He said sure no problem and waitress will be able to add this all together and we left a credit card with him. It ok 22 mins to get her attention and order, I literally was waving my hands in the air. And she yelled out " I see you be ther shortly. We order nachos and chickens strips. Both were decent and good size portions, neither were great but they were good. She advised they she was only server for inside and outside, seriously that was not smart. UGH! When we asked to pay including drinks she advised she was food and we would have to go back in to get card and pay for drinks, we were so done here, we did that and went back to other bar. They weren't kind. The Cosmo I had was good and beer the men had they liked. 

BIGGEST ISSUE they had people lighting up cigarettes on patio. 15 feet from open doorways and windows and others eating, right next me man smoking, she asked him to stop when I said something but it wasn't allowed in the first place. FOLLOW THE LAW PLEASE! Other better and friendlier places. Choose one of those.
author: Barbara L.

description: Overpriced. Bad service. And bland food. Stopped here with some friends while we were walking around the city. And were defiantly disappointed. Irish pub with bad pub food. The waitress was not attentive at all. And the drinks were all watered down. Look elsewhere.
author: Angela C.

description:
I've had better Irish/British pub food. I got the Irish Beef Stew, and it was nothing to rave about. The meat was too dry and there wasn't too much flavor. 

I will say that the service is fast and they have a good selection of pub foods--but definitely not the best.
author: Alice W.

description: Stumbled on this place one day while exploring, what a find! Friendly service, great patio seating, and bleu cheese fries. Had the shepherds pie, perfect comfort food on a chilly day. We will be back!
author: J B.

description: My boyfriend and I were in San Francisco for the weekend and were searching for a good place to eat and have some drinks and the Irish Bank was the perfect choice! The food and the service were great! Great atmosphere we will definitely come back if we are in town again!
author: Em W.

description: I'll be honest, I was at Beer 39 and Rogue Ale Public House for many hours before arriving at the Irish Bank Bar.  I recall very attentive bar tenders, a couple good ales and way too many Jameson Irish Whisky's.   I was a wreck leaving here and vaguely remember the walk back to the Intercontinental Hotel.  I had a great time (I think) but paid dearly for it the next day.
author: Mike N.

description: Cool location but I have to be honest the bartenders are unfriendly....the guy that looks like a washed up Lance Bass is particularly rude.... Long story short, not a good local watering hole.
author: Angel S.

description:
I feel like I am the last one to know about this place, but went there for the first time last night. It's a solid pub with a great mix of after-work & generally local people. The beer on tap is good: Guiness & ciders included. I really liked the low key, welcoming feel and the bartenders were really good at being attentive without overdoing it. 

It has a great selection of hearty bar food too. Arriving starved, I got a big bowl of beef stew. Everything includes mashed potatoes on the dinner menu. Score.
author: Merrill S.

description: For me this is the best kind of place to really enjoy friends and good food/drink.  If you go I suggest sitting outside in the alley for a great experience
author: Ryan D.

description:
This is my kind of place. Relaxed, casual, non-assuming.

Maybe it's because we're packed so tight in this concrete jungle, but doing ANYTHING outdoors makes an activity feel so special in this city. I personally love eating outside, but thanks to microclimates and living in the Rich, I hardly get to do it. I either spend my whole meal making sure my napkin doesn't fly away, swatting gnats, or catching hypothermia. Not fun.

The Irish Bank is located in an alleyway between two very tall buildings, which means no sunlight, but it also means NO WIND. CanIGetAHallelujah?! (I've just realized I should never move to Chicago)
You'll definitely need a sweater, but if you're not packing one of those anyway, you shouldn't have come to San Francisco.

I've only been in the afternoons, when it's fairly quiet but not dead. The bartender has always been super attentive, even though we're sitting outside. Our glasses have never hit bottom, and I never feel bad for hanging out.

The burgers are consistently good, I LOVE the Shepherd's Pie, and my bf orders the Fish N Chips. Irish Bank offers a pretty good selection of beers and ciders, and it would take me days to get through all the posters, signage, and Kennedy photos in the place. 

All in all, a nice little (emerald) gem tucked away in the heart of my favorite  city!
author: Sachi T.

description:
Nice beer selection and pretty good food. I wish I could give 2.5 stars.

Slow, fairly inattentive service. The outdoor seating is nice in the alleyway, and is a pleasant respite during the day from the generally touristy area surrounding it. 

Would recommend going to grab a few pints with friends. Try the mac and cheese and the blue cheese fries!
author: Meg L.

description:
A tough week inspired my friend and me to go for a mid-Friday mac 'n cheese and beer.  Genius idea?  I think so.  Congratulations, self, you're officially smart.  Really brilliant, if I may.

So, we headed to Irish Bank for some good food and a heaping of great company.  It was a windy day, so we chose to sit inside.  Since we arrived around 11:45, it was empty, but as we sat and waited, the room slowly filled up.  We each ordered a beer (love that they have a cider on tap, whee), and my friends had the BLT, mac 'n cheese, and vegetarian shepherd's pie, while I opted for the Irish Beef Stew.

Totally a fan of the mac 'n cheese, although I'm glad I only tried a bite, since ordering it would've instantly put me in a food coma, thus rendering me unproductive and unable to function for the rest of the day.  My beef stew was really delicious too, with a large dollop of mashed potatoes on top.  At first I was concerned that there were too many juices for the stew portion, but the potatoes soaked it up nicely and my bowl was cleaned off pretty well.  Again, congratulations, self, for having such a big appetite.  You're officially a fatty.

One of the pricier lunches for the area, although it's definitely not your typical grab-and-go deals in the Financial District.  Perfectly cozy for a cold day, nice breezy alley to sit outside when it's nice and warm.  Definitely a fan of their selection of food and libations.

And for those of you wondering, I still ended up being in a food coma at work.  Luckily, it was an early day for me.
author: Tori S.

description:
I'm rating this place 5 stars despite really not remembering much of my time here...

On a random Tuesday night, with an out-of-town friend visiting, we happened upon The Irish Bank in search of somewhere to continue our post-Thirsty-Bear drinking and reminiscing of times gone by (when we were probably out drinking).  Considering the tucked away location, it was a miracle that we found the place.

I clearly remember the drinks being reasonably priced, the music being just the right shade of loud and the liquor selection being quite extensive.

Fast forward 3.5 hours and I vaguely remember spending half an hour trying to find my way back to MUNI, giving up, and eventually cabbing it home.

Definitely on my list of places to hit up the next time I'm drinking in the area and need a proper bar that stays open until the very tip of 2AM to service those very specialest of drunk bastards of which I am clearly a member.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Still an excellent pub!  I was feeling predisposed to warm feelings because this is where yesterday's drunk set in.  It was one of those good, long, soaking, all-day sort of drunks that started in the first-class cabin of American Airlines flight 451 at 11am central time, continued through early happy hour at Harry's Bar, and peaked here at the Irish Bank before cruising through AT&T Park and finding its denouement at 21st Amendment.  Good day.

Friendly folks here, with some attitude to make it interesting.  Not "attitude" like your principal always chastised you for, but more like "personality."  Like the waitress who gave me a sad, exasperated look and head-shake because I haven't seen Gone With the Wind, or the bartendress who gave us a good-natured hard time for ordering our second round from someone else.  She switched the TV to Wimbledon for us though.

Pints are $6, but they have Leffe Blonde and pour a pretty fair Guinness, so it's okay.    There is outdoor seating too for nice weather like yesterday, but there's more fun to be had inside.  Light crowd for a Friday after-work period, but it was a holiday weekend after all.
author: David R.

description: Stopped in for a drink while visiting for a business trip. Small inside, but nice outside seating.
author: Shelley M.

description:
Came here to celebrate a co-worker's birthday, there was a group of 8 people. I HATE HATE Irish carbombs so I passed on the first two but indulged on the last round. still HATE them! anyway i had the Calamari, and it was really good! We sat outside, it was a little chilly but they have a few heaters out so it wasn't too bad. I like the ambiance, we're outside with a bunch of random strangers. It's pretty cool. The best thing about this place is probably the Chimay =) Our bill came out to about $400, YIKES!!!!! They added 20 % gratuity!!! UGH.... thumbs down for how expensive it came out to but thumbs up on the experience.

Will definitely come again.. plus it's down the street from my work place =)
author: Penelope V.

description: The food was decent enough (chicken curry) to warrant this place 3, maybe 4 stars. However, the customer service is severally lacking. I have been here about 5 times in the last 6 months and have always had an issue with the people who work here. The last straw was when I attempted to take some visitors/ clients from Ireland here for a nice meal and a pint. However, they thought this time that I was too young to serve, despite having my state issued drivers license with saying I'm 28 years old.. "We can't risk it" is what I was told. There are better and more genuine places to get a proper pint in this city. Cheers.
author: T C.

description:
Man! I Can't Wait To Go Back!
My wife and I were recently in town for the Giants/A's preseason games. On our walk back to our timeshare from AT&T Park we came across this lively alley known as Mark Ln. Hungry from our long walk back we decided to stop in and grab a bite to eat. Unfortunately, upon arrival, Tom, the former Army soldier now Asian bouncer (well he's always been Asian from what I can tell but now a bouncer. This normally wouldn't matter but tonight it did) told us that the kitchen was closed. Bummer! However, he told us that if he were off he'd go to this place down the street called Sauce. So we took his suggestion and headed that way. We were so pleased with our experience at Sauce that we made a point to stop back by and thank Tom for his awesome suggestion. He was happy to hear we liked it and invited us in for a nightcap. 
While I am originally from the Bay Area, my wife is a native of Las Vegas and was totally amazed at how everyone in the bar interacted with one-another and acted as if everyone had known each other for years. She said, "you'd never see this kind of interaction in Vegas". I simply replied, "welcome to San Francisco!"
Immediately, the bartender  served our drinks, who seemed to be rather a happy chap who spoke with a charming Irish accent. You knew it wasn't faked either for ambiance. While at the bar we met a young Swede in town for an electronic gaming programmers convention. The conversation with this guy was extremely fascinating. I was shocked to hear how clean he and his coworkers found the streets to be in America. I figured Europeans would laugh at the state of our streets. I guess everything you hear about Europe being better isn't always true. Our conversation with the swede rolled into a conversation with two Irish brothers who were reunited this day after eight years. One brother has lived in SF for the last ten years, and this was the brother from Ireland's first trip to the States. The Irish brother attended his first baseball game. He didn't understand a thing about the sport but declared it was now his favorite. He was mesmerized by the game and atmosphere. We had to explain to him AT&T Park and Giants fans were a rare bread. He was even more shocked that getting to first base, second base, third base, and home originated in baseball. He'd always thought it was solely in reference to how far you got with a girl. Utterly hilarious! Witnessing these two reminiscing along with the bartender about their homeland provided our entertainment for the next two hours (we learned that the one brother living in SF was known at the bar as DJ Pat who spins at the Irish Bank for special occasions). What was even more comical was the fact that they were drinking Corona after Corona because they had spent the entire day drinking Guinness and needed to "flush their system". 
So it's places like the Irish Bank where you can meet an Asian bouncer named Tom who is a U.S. Army veteran, A Swede who found it remarkable how clean our streets were, and Irish men drunk off their butts praising their love for baseball. "Just another night at The Bank", we were told. In the words of a famous Austrian weightlifter/ actor turned governor, "I'll be back!"
author: Tom O.

description: We live in the East Bay and the Irish Bank is our go-to place to eat when we are in the city, kids and all. The food is good, the atmosphere is fun and, most importantly, the staff is tremendous.  Last night, on a busy Friday, Tommy and Shannon went out of their way to accommodate our large group. It is staff like them that differentiates  between a decent place and a great place.  The Irish Bank is a great place.  Thank you!
author: Sarah H.

description:
This place is old school and awesome! Everything you could want in a big city bar!

I found this place waiting for a show near by. Not only does it have a old cool brick interior, but it has wonderful alley way seating. I image many foreign bars to have this cool urban look with the tables outside under the awning. I have been abroad, and I haven't been to this bar more than once, but for a single experience I was very pleased.

Great atmosphere!
author: John S.

description: Fabulous atmosphere and delicious Shepherds Pie! Hard to get a table but well worth it once we did!
author: Linda M.

description:
Oh Danny Boy! 
Irish eyes are definitely smiling, especially on St. Patrick's Day, and all roads lead to the Irish Bank! 

IB is one of my favorite Irish bars in SF. It's an annual tradition (3 of the past 4 years) for me to celebrate St. Patrick's Day at the IB! They always decorate so festively with the massive green, orange, and white balloon arch at the alley entrance, and streamers and shamrocks galore. Also, all day entertainment is provided with live music and traditional dancers. 
Of course, the crowd is jovial and energy is awesome, especially if you've had a few cocktails. (For me, it'd be an Irish coffee to start and then the rounds of Guinness, the bombs, etc.,) 

Last year, my friend, Amy G and I woke up at the crack of dawn to head over to the Irish Bank to catch part of the Alice 97.3 live morning broadcast of the then 'Sarah and No Name' show. It was a wild and crazy morning of complete drunken chaos, but so much fun. Here is how crowded the alley gets http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/QkZfMbklsq8nHAtRbVfIJA/l 
and here's a pic of No Name with his samurai and ginormous stein of beer http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/IJF40IKQSDQP7buX3nichQ/l 

Aside from hitting up the IB for St. Patrick's Day, I've also attended many Happy Hours and birthday celebrations (including my own). Of course, the best place to be seated is outside, especially if the weather is lovely. Even if it's a bit nippy outside, well, all you need is one drink (Irish coffee, Guinness) to warm you up! If you choose to sit inbe indoors, I recommend sitting in the confessional with a few of your closest friends. This is the only bar I know of with a confessional. Once you confess your sins, they'll be absolved with a shot of Fernet or Jameson :) 

BTW, the IB food is actually quite good and reasonably priced. There's a wide selection of sammies, hamburgers, salads, and other entrees like steak and  corned beef and cabbage. A few of my favorites are the cheddar cheese fries and the mac and cheese (Yes, I'm a cheesy type of gal)! I swear this mac and cheese is one of the best I've ever had! No joke! As for the fries, halfway through this year's Chinese New Year Treasure Hunt http://www.yelp.com/biz/chinese-new-year-treasure-hunt-san-francisco#hrid:u67xlsNqasyZLyRPjw9nQg my team and I decided to make a pit stop at the IB for those tasty fries and beer. They were thick and crisp with the perfect amount of cheesy melty goodness on top (as we ordered the cheddar fries and the blue cheese fries). The plates were practically licked clean. 

Service is decent here, and never had any bad experiences. Can get slow when it's super crowded. Ladies, the bathroom only has two small stalls, and allows for maybe 2 people tops to wait inside if stalls are occupied. Otherwise, you'll be waiting outside the bathroom doors, just across from the Men's room. 

Of course, I'll be back at the IB! The Irish Coffee and Guinness are calling my name in the morning..."McGilly"... 

Sláinte!
author: Gill C.

description:
I work in SOMA, but I have found that the Irish Bank is a great place for a nice cold Guinness. The outdoor seating is nice and enjoyable on a weekend day. They have tv's and play the baseball games as well as the world cup games (when that is going on). 

The staff that works there are all very nice and personable. The service is always great and the atmosphere is fun during the week.

I always have a great time and will definitely be back :)
author: Lisa S.

description:
Step into this place and immediately be reminded of Ireland.  The road-signs plastered on the outside are still glowing from the bloke who ran off with them on the side of the road.

Pretty fabulous pint of Guinness and Harp here, It can be hard to find a good one here in the city.

The waitstaff is significantly untraditional.  For this place to be a tad more authentic, I would have expected a bartender who was half cocked and shouting expletives at us as we ordered. 

Overall a great pub.  I'm looking forward to trying some of their food.
author: Mike C.

description: Neat little bar tucked away in an alley. Service was prompt and courteous. Decent beer selection includes a good mix of both domestic and imports. I had the Shepherd's pie and it was just ok...a little too sweet for my tastes but filling.
author: Z E.

description: Got together with some friends for some drinks after work. Cute outdoor seating and chill place to relax and chat
author: Zara S.

description:
I enjoy the Irish Bank but have never found anything too special about it. The bar is pretty chill and laid-back and it's nice if you get to grab an outdoor table when there is good weather.

They boast several beers on tap including, of course, Guinness. I've had a couple of beers here and a really good vodka gimlet. Its not my first pick of bars but I will go if someone else picks it...
author: Meghan P.

description:
It's a SF tradition.  For St. Patty's day, you start at Irish Bank.  No brainer.  The lines are ridiculous, I think we waited about 40 minutes, but that's just part of the Irish charm.   Inside gets pretty packed, as you can imagine, hordes of people dressed in green, sloppy, high-fiving, loud, laughing, standing around conversing with random strangers, picture taking, drinking heavily.  I think we stayed for at least 4 hours, or until our words became really slurred, our voices really loud from not being able to hear our own thoughts and our faces bright red from all that jameson. 

Good times indeed.  The entire time we kicked it near the porter potties, but it really didn't matter because it started to rain, and per usual St. Patty's day was a sh*t show!  Woot!
author: Soo Jin K.

description:
Irish Bank has a lot going for it, but doesn't really deliver a great experience.

It's got a decent location, with a ton of outdoor seating.  On the other hand, all the tables are on cobblestone, and wobble every which way.  The tap's great, but the prices are a buck too high.  The dishes are reasonably priced, but are hit-and-miss (my friend ordered a very carelessly-made Caesar Salad, but my bratwurst and kraut was delicious).

Given the food, I'd definitely go back if I was hanging out in the neighborhood and hankering for a filling meal.
author: Bill H.

description:
This is my office's go to spot when we want to go out and sit down for lunch.  They have a good selection of pub-style entrees and, if its warm, you can sit outside in their private alley!  The wait staff are always friendly and accommodating which I really appreciate since we tend to roll in with a group for 7-10 (somewhat disorganized) people.  I usually get the chicken sandwich with fries (which is great) but I can also recommend the Monte Cristo or the regular burger.  They have a great list of beers on tap and they make sure we never leave thirsty :P.  

I have stopped by after work a few times as well and find the crowd friendly and somewhat more casual than what you'll see at other FiDi establishments.  You can stop by to watch whatever game is on that night or for special events, like Mardi Gras or Saint Patrick's Day!
author: Liz H.

description: Fine place.  Sat directly at the bar based on other reviews about slow service.  Clearly they've had a few dine & dashers since they asked for my card relatively quickly. Had the fish & chips - so average, even a disappointment after all the other amazing places I've been this week. The owner was friendly enough, enjoyed his vernacular "thanks love" but his treatment of his coworker/bartendress/girlfriend whatever she was bothered me. Even if that's their joking, I didn't jive with it. All in all exactly what you'd expect from an Irish pub. Note: you do indeed walk into a sushi shop if you think the main door is on the street - you do need to go down the alley.
author: Marissa C.

description: Late night stop for some beers and vegetarian Shepards pie.  The first small dining area is served only from the bar, so don't sit at the table a wait for a server.  The staff was quite friendly and quick with service once we figured out what was going on.  The Shepards pie was the resin that we went looking for this place.  It was pretty enjoyable.  Decent beer selection And "Irish" atmosphere...read as dark and dingy!  :)
author: Candace M.

description:
Went to Irish Bank for a friend's going away party and it was great! The atmosphere was amazing. If you sit outside, it's basically in a little side alley that's been converted into an outdoor room. The heat lamps are good so I'd recommend sitting outside. The decor is all vintagey Irish stuff, and at night it's like a special oasis, completely apart from the ultra commercial shopping area that it's in. The beer selection was good, the server was attentive, and the atmosphere was great!

Food was good, not amazing, but good and reasonably priced. I tried Leffe for the first time (a beer) and it's the bomb. Try it.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
I have this thing for Irish pubs - they are one of the best when it comes to inviting, warm atmospheres and real comfort food.  Anddd, you can always depend on the Irish to have quality beer and liquor. 

Pros of the Irish Bank: 
* Outdoor seating. You have to walk down an alley to get to the entrance of the pub. And they have filled the alley with benches and heat lamps. It's the perfect way to drink and enjoy the outside even as it gets late into the night. 
*  Indoor seating means you get exposed to the old, rustic dark wood that makes up the tables, the chairs, the walls, and the counter at the bar.
* They carry Guinness and Harp - two staples.  No Murphys unfortunately. 
* This might not mean something to all of you - but the space reminds me of Becketts (a Berkeley Irish pub that sadly closed a year ago).  With a Guinness in hand, the beer memorabilia, and old wood paneling, I feel at home just like I did at Becketts. 

So-Sos:
* Fish chips were good - not amazing, but still satisfying. 
* Also, ordered the vegetarian quesadilla, which was okay (I probably wouldn't order it again). Though this one could be entirely my fault...who said the Irish were known for their veggie quesadillas? 

I would be down to go back for a couple drinks.  It's an Irish Pub after all...that is to say, it had me at Irish.  In the terms of the food, I wasn't in love, but would definitely give the menu another shot.
author: Kimya P.

description: This place is fantastic. The kitchen is great and the crowd is typically cool, laid back people.
author: Eric A.

description: Really nice place. Attentive staff, good vibe, good food and most importantly, good beer
author: Eric S.

description:
The Irish Bank Bar is not for people who like to drink alone in a quiet desolate space (can you hear me dad?) This pub gets the asses and the masses to flow within it's small interior.
A big happy hour scene can be found. The food is edible and the pints are gold!
author: Alexander R.

description:
Came here the day BEFORE St. Patty's and it was already packed. My friends and I enjoyed some good drinks and decent food.

I myself had the Irish beef stew and it was fairly tasty. Service is pretty good even with it packed like crazy. Our waitress was attentive and was prompt with everything. We were being pretty long with ordering and didn't even order that much for staying that long so she was being extremely patient with us.

I like how there was outdoor seating since the inside is super small and its all under an awning so no worries if it rains. Just wear a jacket and order some whiskey.
author: edward k.

description: I just came here for lunch with a couple of friends and this is a cool place.  Looks like a hole in the wall from the outside since it's at the end of an alley, but it's really homey feeling inside.  Staff is really nice and they are quick, so having an hour lunch here is no problem.  You don't feel like you're rushing the staff.  I didn't have a drink since I had to go back to work, but I had the turkey club.  It wasn't the best turkey club I've ever had, but it was pretty good for bar/pub food.  This would be a good place to go for drinks though.  I think I've been here before and sat at the bar, but I don't really remember.  Maybe I got really drunk?  LOL!  I'd definitely go back for drinks.
author: Elena N.

description: Outside seating area is great for an afternoon pint on a nice day when in the city. Definitely gong to make my way back there.
author: Paul G.

description:
Thank you for indulging all of us who got laid off today. For the mac and cheese, and the beers, and offering us a kitchen job. Also for playing "another one bites the dust" right when you opened.

You have my heart.
author: Nikki M.

description:
So I came here the other day for Saint Patrick's Day. Yeah, it was a little nuts.

The DJ was decent. There was a huge mob of people. And it was helpful that there were waiters carrying around trays of beer for sale. Cause it was absolutely impossible to get to the bar.

Fire hazard? Definitely.

I think if you come here with the right crowd of people it could be fun. Rowdy, very drunk people. That don't mind hanging out in a grimy back alley getting sloshed.
author: Tony L.

description:
The drinks are strong, the macaroni & cheese is absolutely delicious (I've been on a mac & cheese kick lately), the bleu cheese fries are decent and the service is okay, but...the sandwiches and everything else here leave me somewhat underwhelmed.  I've been going here on and off over the past few years and now that I live nearby, I go a bit more often out of convenience.  Weekend afternoons are typically chill (unless there's some sort of sporting event on) and it's my preferred time to go when I do.  Evenings are typically a combo of the FiDi work crowd and striped-shirt wearing men who will eventually yell "woo!" outside my window at 2am or so.  The indoor area is small and poorly laid out, though the outside is nice on a sunny day, and I haven't tried their brunch yet so maybe I'm missing something there. 

I know I'll be back because it's in the neighborhood, but not for the personality or sandwiches.
author: Sus... B.

description:
I've never really been impressed with this place besides the fact that you can sit out in the alley and look up at the night sky while tossing back a black and tan. 

The drinks-$$

The service- 2 stars because it's only one bartender and he's always too busy to take a drink order.

The seating at the bar-non existent

Old men breathing down your neck-Quite plentiful

Entourages of greaseballs-Also plentiful.

Hey a$$holes, if I want to get picked up at a bar, I'll go to Ruby Skye, hike my skirt up to barely legal and giggle at your lame jokes then. But when a girl goes to an Irish pub, it's usually to drink. Take notes.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Service was decent. Food was decent. Prices not outlandish for the area. 

Wouldn't recommend but wouldn't tell you not to go.

Oh and bartender and waitress were cursing up a blue streak which doesn't bother me but if I was older like the people sitting at the bar I would have been bothered.
author: Sarah C.

description:
When you're finally stumbling into bed at 6 am you've either done something HORRIBLY wrong or Crazily right.

Not sure yet which of the two I was, but it was due to the foocking Iiirish Baank, I can tell you that. We started with an impressive act of being so veeery civilized and proper at Gitane, and still hungry, the act was dropped and the debauchery was full on just a couple doors down on our barstools at The Bank.

When one is after no less than 6 Irish Coffees, and really closer to 8, this is a great place for them. Not sweet, heavy on the whiskey and just enough cream. Sit at the bar and get calamari, the chicken wings are breaded AND fried, the potato skins are crispy, the veggie quesadilla is cheesy and surely your speech will be so slurred by the time you are eating all of these things - will you REALLY care? 

Sit outside in the heated patio, yell, laugh and all is right with the world.
Until the next morning anyway...
author: Katie W.

description: I entered famished and thirsty and found what I needed here.  Had a couple of pints of cider and one amazing shepherd pie.  I will definitely be back.  The space provides so many options - sit down dining, stand up ba space and a spacious patio/alley.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place is a TRUE Irish pub. Often imitated, never duplicated... I would travel back to SF for St. Patrick's day just to be here! The fare includes your typical Irish fare- corned beef, bangers with mash and Irish stew. I had the stew and it was DELICIOUS. My husband had the bangers which he also enjoyed. 

Of course, they have a ton of beer on tap. Me? I just got a bloody mary and bud light on tap. I know.. you can take the girl out of Long Beach but, well, you know the rest.

Most of all I love the ambiance. They have seating in the alley and the walls are covered with memorabilia de Ireland. 

Had a great time, will definitely come back when I'm in the city again!
author: April E.

description:
Ended up going here twice.

Once, on my own, just for drinks.  Sat at the bar.  A fine bar selection with fun and friendly bartenders, and all the appropriately Irish decor.  Rather hazy recollection on the bar tab, but I think everything was reasonably priced.

A second night, came with friends for dinner.  Sat in the inside dining room (outdoor seating was jam-packed).  Tasty pub grub, no complaints whatsoever with the food quality.  Our waiter, however, clearly wasn't interested in doing his job that night - after waiting a solid 20 minutes for the second round of drinks to come out, I decided to pack it in.  Which was really a shame; this really does seem like the kind of place you could hang out all night and have fun, but this waiter sort of blew it.

Everyone has a bad day though, so I'm rating based on the food, drinks, and ambience alone.

And I'll add - for some reason, I really like how the outdoor patio is basically a dingy-looking back alley.  It looks a little scary, but it really makes the place feel even more cozy and authentic.
author: Jameel A.

description: Who's that cat on Kitchen Nightmares? He'd be unhinged. But me? I was just fine. Pour a good Guinness and I'll forgive most all else.
author: Corey H.

description:
Cool scene.  I like the outdoor seating.  It reminded me a lot of my time in the UK.

But drinks are EXPENSIVE.  I bought a pint of cider and a double whiskey = $24.00 at happy hour on a Wednesday! 

Also, there seemed to be a large contingent of the Marina crowd hanging out here.  Approach at your own peril.
author: Rao P.

description: I had not been here in ages, but we took my friend Ann here for her birthday after dining at Gitane. What a hoot we had , three funny girls, awesomely entertaining bartender Jeremiah aka Joaquin Phoenix serving up our tequila shots and doleing out manly wisdom , and crazy stories . Fun crowd not too yuppie, not too hipstery. Good music, and had on basketball which is always a YESSSSSS for me when I'm out . Shout Out to the bouncer who is related to every Tongan I know from San Mateo you are very great .
author: Lauren V.

description:
It's a decent enough Irish pub.  If you're not sitting at the bar, the service is abysmal.  

The crowd, as far as bar crowds go, is pretty good...a tame group, no BS.  Heck, I even saw some folks bring their little kids in there, which may or may not indicate a particularly questionable parenting style but then hey, who am I to say?  At least they're not sending the little tykes up in homemade weather balloons, am I right?

At any rate, I didn't have any food, so I can't comment on that, but as far as a bar goes, it's a "standard Irish pub".  If you love the "standard Irish pub" then you will love the Irish Bank.
author: Ben G.

description: Nice heating area outside, but the food was terrible. Not only was it terrible, it's expensive. Most boring and bland nachos ever for $10. It was literally some salsa on chips. Vegetable quesadilas, 0 flavor. To top it off, our waitress had a piss poor attitude the entire time. Stay away.
author: Spencer H.

description:
Only in San Francisco would you find a Japanese conversation group meeting at an Irish pub, having Bass (UK) over curry chicken (Malay style). O'Shieh or is it oishiideshita? Kind of a mixed up cultural night...but it doesn't matter. It was nice to hang out at the outdoor patio or inside and Nihongo o hanishimashita-ing away. A nice choice of beeru...Guiness (of course), imports on tap like Harp or Smithwick or bottled imports like Red Stripe or Becks. There's pub grub like Irish stew, shepard's pie, Bratwurst and Sauerkraut or burgers. The  pub food wasn't too bad...but theoperative word is *pub* food.

To add to the cultural mixed up night...in between my Magners Cider or was it Boddingtons, this hot looking Korean-American girl, a new member of the group, walks in late. Asked if she wanted to practice Japanese. She says no, she didn't speak Japanese...huh? You signed up for a "Japanese converstion group", right?  Yes, but only to meet Asian guys. How refreshing. Hey Filipino-Canadians, count, right? I really must have been in a cultural vortex because isn't it a given that the cock-asian bro's always win the Asian girls in the city? Not that night...for once the Asian guy won...*does endzone crazy Shillelagh dance*... probably only happens in an Irish pub, when the  leprechauns are dancing under a new moon, or something.  I like this pub....I think I'll have more Stout....

Top of the morning to ya! (O' ha you go za i ma s')
author: Reyz A.

description:
I mostly liked this place.
When our large group came, they were polite and to the point.
Loud drunk people are annoying when you are sober.

They were nice when they asked us to keep it quiet and to not sing. They got our orders in quickly and efficiently.  You don't really go here for the food -- while very filling -- it's just bar food.  Big portions, great with beer!

I did like the place though, sitting outside, drinks came out quickly -- and while I only tasted one mixed drink (a white russian) it was made well, so no complaints there either.

So I say good job to the wait staff there on dealing with the obnoxious drunkards, tip them well.
author: Van W.

description: After a morning and early afternoon of sight seeing we happened on this place. At first we almost missed it because the sign announcing we had arrived led us into a sushi bar instead of an Irish pub. We quickly realized we needed to venture down the alley. Our bartender was awesome and the regulars were great. The food was above average for bar food. I had the macaroni and cheese and the philly cheese steak. The bread was soft, the steak was well-seasoned and the peppers and cheese completed this yummy goodness. I will definitely be visiting this bar again!!
author: Meghan L.

description: Great place to meet friends and catch up! I love the outdoor area where you can relax and have a good beer and great food.  I enjoy the fish and chips and Guinness.  Everyone there is very friendly and the service is great. No rush to leave, you can sit there and meet new friends and drink good beer!  I work around the corner and often refer tourist there. It's a great experience and not just a one time place.
author: Aura C.

description: A great place to go for a drink or two. We went late at night so the outside seating had closed. We ended up seating in the booth, there is a booth seating 4 comfortably. The alcohol list was impressive but the front bar had a beer stench. We didn't eat but fish and chips looked good!
author: Sunny E.

description: We ducked in her randomly for drinks and had a great time. It's a bit of a neighborhood bar that reminded me of the places i frequented in college, except with a better drink list.  There was a great selected of microbrews and I found a new brew that I enjoyed.  Great service, too, even on a bustling Friday night.
author: Kelly M.

description:
*meh*

I went here for DYL last friday, and even though walking there from the Bart station was easy, everything else was a bit...weird. 

We couldn't stand on the sidewalk.
They don't have Patron Silver (wteff!?!?)
Good selection of beers, however
Lost an arm wrestling contest with Chris
Table situation was awkward
Took a tad long to get my cc back...or to get noticed at the bar.

But seriously--WHO DOESN'T HAVE PATRON SILVER?! Oy. 

Other than that, I don't think I would come back again unless DYL suggeted it. 

*meh*
author: Jaime L.

description:
I checked out this bar recently because I've heard so many great thing about it from friends. My friend and I got there around 4 before happy hour and we had this awesome waitress who really knew her beer and was so attentive. 

When happy hour started we got a different waitress who took hella long to give us our drinks and didn't know anything about beer.  This didn't bother me too much, because she might have been new. It was not until she asked if we could hurry up because other people were waiting to sit down, that I got bothered. Even a new waitress would have common sense not ask that. 

I would give this place 5 stars, but due to that crappy waitress I have to give this place only 3.
author: Michelle C.

description: This is a great Irish Pub! Tucked away in the back of an alley, you would be hard pressed to find another pub downtown with such a cool vibe and a hardy helping of Fish & Chips!
author: Ray K.

description: What better place to go for lunch on an uncharacteristically warm summer weekday in San Francisco than Irish Bank?  I "grew up" at this place, eating the perfectly-crisped fish/chips or the wonderful shepherd's pie, washing it all down with good Guinness.  Happy to see that it is still kicking, hidden back in an alley away from all the hustle and bustle of downtown SF.
author: Chad T.

description:
We also came here during St Patrick's Day and it was so crazy busy that we went somewhere else, but we went back last night and I'm glad we did.  The Alaska Cod fish and chips were awesome, the Irish stew was very good with huge chucks of beef, and the bratwurst and sauerkraut was delicious.  

Overall the food was very good and the Guinness was amazing and flowing.  A little stuffy inside with the temperature yesterday, but the alley was cool and prefect.
author: Tony M.

description:
I came here with a drunken horde of revelers celebrating the birthday of a friend of a friend. I'm just glad they only told us to keep it down and didn't kick us out. Part of the restaurant is inside, I think; it was just a snapshot that I saw on my trips to the bathroom. We were in the outside area, which was one of those SF alley deals. Yeah, funky, but cool enough.

I'll be back.
author: Ken L.

description:
One drunk bartender = failed experience. Barely serviced our group yesterday even though bar was barely busy as it was a sunday night. He kept forgetting our drinks we ordered. Mr Drunk tried to make us pay our tab twice as well (sheesh). 

But we should have taken it as a sign when my first drink was poured in a chipped glass. Apparently pouring whats in the glass into a new one with an extra splash is supposed to solve the issue. Lucky for this bar i didnt swallow glass that night.

 On top of it all due to our bad experience he kicks us out early because he was unhappy of his deserving tip. Poor drunk bartender couldnt even figure out how to lock the door. Good thing he didnt swing any punches as he yelled in our faces while kicking us out or he might have stumbled to the ground in his drunken stupor. 

First bar in the city for me and my experience started off with a bang. Good job Irish Bar... What a way to treat your customers
author: Kinsey P.

description: This place looks amazing to hangout at! It has really cool decor and lighting, plus eating in an alley way for some reason makes me feel adventurous.. Anyways the food is alright, more importantly the selection is limited. I'd suggest ordering the typical bar food appetizers, and sharing. A little to expensive for me in terms of the dishes they are offering. The drinks weren't the tastiest for me either. If you're into having a different alley way experience, as well as a beer, I'd say check it out..
author: Bianca H.

description:
If this place had apartments above it I would move in. It is the best happy hour bar in the Financial Dist and maybe in all of SF. 

I take all my out of town friends here and used to go a couple times of week when I worked nearby. Not just because Jesse, my fav waiter is hot. He is also super nice  and knows my drink (Harp, thank you) when I walk in. 

Stop in, grab a seat on the patio, order a Harp and the blue cheese fries....
author: Steven C.

description:
Had a drink here with some friends visiting from out of state on a slow Sunday night.  The beer selection is very good, and the decor is pretty cool with the vintage photos on the brick walls.  We walked in and just grabbed a table in the dining area; the table top and one of the chairs was a bit sticky.  

The waiter brought us menus, but we told him we were just there to drink.  He brought our drinks to the table pretty quickly, but damn he spilled some of my Lagunitas IPA on the table top.  Not once during our visit did this guy show any facial expression - straight faced throughout.  There were a few other tables with diners and drinkers, but overall the place was pretty quiet and a great place to have a conversation.  

That was up until the kitchen guys decided to turn on the music in their area.  All of a sudden loud Hispanic radio filled the rooms, and this place didn't seem so Irish anymore.  That was our sign to pay the check and get out of there.

I was told that the Bloody Mary was to be avoided - just lots of Worcesterchire and Tabasco and very little alcohol.  Honestly, by appearance it looked like chilled brown gravy in a glass.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I love this place.  It's small and cute.  The food is good and the Bloody Mary's are awesome!
author: Kristin G.

description: Good beer, awesome food, and great staff; what else do ya want from them?  the interior is quite charming  and love the patio! I'm a smoker, so outside seating area is perfect!  their fish and chips is yummmm
author: Patricia N.

description: Cool patio. Might give it another try because this time was a total fail. I think only one server for the entire (large) patio. Maybe someone called in sick, I like to give the benefit of the doubt. Never did get the drink I ordered. Then took 20 minutes for the check.
author: Rachel L.

description: What's cool about The Irish Bank is when you are in the restaurant, you feel like you could be in Ireland.  The decor is great!  I went there today with 2 friends for lunch for the first time and we were impressed.  Though we were at work and couldn't have a pint, we had a great lunch!  My one friend had the fish & chips and loved it, my other friend had the reuben with blue cheese fries (yum!) and I had the non-Irish grilled chicken salad.  It was all fantastic and we had excellent service. They also had a great jukebox with the best tunes (Journey, Guns & Roses, INXS, etc).  Great place, great decor, great food.....what more do you need?
author: Sandra P.

description: unpolite staff smoke outside - even if u tell them it annoys you they will ignore you
author: Jose B.

description: I love the idea of this place. The out door patio is huge. It's dive-y without being dirty and the bathroom is decently clean . The food is awful but really its what you should expect from a pub. The beer selection is okay. Sit outside order an import and don't over think it. You'll probably fall in love with this place.
author: Kim K.

description: Fun little pub. Not a lot of wine to choose from but it is a pub so didn't expect much. My boyfriend loved his Bloody Mary. We didn't eat here so can't comment on the good. In an alley of the street but loved the feel of the place.
author: Melissa C.

description:
EDIT: 

Email from Stephanie:
"Perfect! I appreciate your putting my response on yelp! My manager and staff said they had ever come across such a rude and ignorant group of people - and you can put that on yelp too.
Your business is not welcome here! So we are in ageement!"

Very mature response received by the OWNER of the restaurant. This is undoctored email that is a testament to The Irish Bank's inability to accept responsibility for their actions and also their lack of maturity. Instead of trying to make amends and apologize, they resort to ad hominem attacks - because they know they're wrong. 

Yelpers, please keep this in mind when you decide which establishment to give your money to!

~~~~

We organized a large reddit meetup here, and our experience was not pleasant. 

Management nagged us continually through the night, complaining about our under-21 guests, even though we had cleared it with them beforehand.

They also complained that we were taking up too many tables - all of us were buying drinks and food; this is the first time I've heard management complain about CUSTOMERS.

Speaking of buying drinks and food, waitresses did not come around nearly as much for a large group. There would be half-hour intervals when no one would come by to service us. When they did service us, they were not very friendly.

There was also a portly waiter who kept on giving my 2 friends and I the stink eye. We were standing up, but not in his way at all. Instead of saying anything, he just remained passive-aggressive the whole night. 

Perhaps the worst part about our group experience at The Irish Bank was their Enron-style accounting. We had no idea what was happening with the tab - and neither did they. In the end, after many of us folks left (and paid!), the final tab arrived, and it  appeared that we owed around $130 more than we thought we owed! To be honest, we have no idea what happened, a $130 excess is crazy. I'm not saying anything about The Irish Bank's honesty, but I will say that they offered us poor explanation for it and did not cooperate as well as we thought they would.

On the flipside, the Bank Martini was tasty, and the Reuben sandwich was all right, but nothing "Famous" like the menu suggests.

This place does have a 4 star average review, so it might be a totally different experience if you're coming here with one or two friends, but I can only speak about my experience. I would not come here again or recommend this place for any large groups. 

tl;dr - Overpriced drinks, poor service, rude management - no thanks!
author: Ralph N.

description:
Short story: Rude, disorganized and unprofessional.  As to quote the owner "You cannot just turn up at a restaurant and expect everything to be fine".

Long story: Keep in mind this was a group of polite internet nerds (reddit)....  I contacted the Stephanie Perry, the owner I think, about renting out the function room. After a few emails back and fourth we agreed not to rent out the function room because it was a casual meetup and I couldn't guarantee we would hit the $1000 minimum. She said we could still use the room  but it would  not be private. However it was very clear that we expected closer to 40-50 people. We agreed to come in and grab tables as needed.
I have organized a lot of meetups and have had nothing but good experiences in the past. The Thirsty Bear and  Rouge are two awesome places for groups.

The day of the event we got there and no one knew we were coming. Instead of welcoming us and apologizing the bar manager was obviously irritated.

Throughout the night the bar manager  complained we were taking up too much and when we had about 30 people, also known as paying customers, he told me not to take up any more tables. Those tables sat empty the rest of the night. There were quite a few other issues which have already been highlighted in other reviews so I will jump right to the emails Stephanie sent me.

Two days later I get an email from Stephanie asking me how it went. I ignored it.

Two people from our group posted their opinions on Yelp. This morning I got this email from Stephanie: My points are starred*

I am deeply offended by the allegations made on Yelp by name removed  and name removed - giving us one star each.

You did NOT have a reservation. You cannot just turn up at a restaurant and expect everything to be fine - you expected anywhere from 15 to 50 people - how can we, as a functioning restaurant, plan with a spread like that - that was the reason you didn't make the reservation - you couldn't guarantee your numbers.  You said "we will just grab seats as they come up." You prevented us from putting our best foot forward.

*She knew we were coming, she knew the group would be large and yes, you should be able to walk into a restaurant and expect good service.

If you had made a reservation the dining room would have been cleared.  If you had made a reservation, there would have been ample staff on to accomodate you.  If you had made a reservation, my staff would have been ready for you and therefore the "Enron style" accounting would have been clear.

*Once again, she is confusing what reservation and paying for the private room. We informed her of a large group. We declined her offer of a private room.

It took 1.5 hours for you guys to figure out the bill, costing me staff overtime. Obviously it was not clear to everyone that there was no tab and that they actually had to pony up.
*This doesn't even make sense. We were out around midnight. We never planned to skip out on a bill.

If you order 9 carbombs - that's $90 - I personally went through every drink check and food docket - not one person was overcharged.
*She wasn't there and already admitted to Enron style accounting.

We are a hard working threesome.  We strive to make everyone's experience a good one - I feel we were victimized when you showed up without a reservation, and again when two of your people yelped us.  We take this very personally.
*Victimized by paying customers?!?

I would really appreciate your talking to name removed  and name removed and letting them know the status quo.  This just isn't fair.

I replied back with:
No one said we had a reservation, ever. The emails I sent you to inform you of a large group are below.

I organized a meetup for a website, I have forwarded your email but I can not control the opinions of others. Your wait staff was awful, rude and disorganized. This is one of many meetups we have had and we were very unhappy for the first time ever.

I don't even use yelp and didn't know what it was until you messaged me. However I did sign up and I will post your email to me as a review of the irish bank; I think it speaks for itself.

She asked me to include her reply:
Perfect! I appreciate your putting my response on yelp! My manager and staff said they had ever come across such a rude and ignorant group of people - and you can put that on yelp too.
Your business is not welcome here! So we are in ageement!
author: Amy L.

description:
Many folks have said this a place to check out... maybe they  didn't know there was an insect and roach problem, in addition to Bartenders needing some major customer service retraining!  Also, some major issues which ABC would have a field day with.  

Arrived here one Saturday night and saw a fairly slow bar. Two bartenders stood around chatting and goofing around as the lady and I waited 3 minutes to get their attention.  After placing our drinks, it literally took another 3 minutes to get the drinks served as the bartenders spent more time goofing off.  

GROSS: They had a whole tray of lemons uncovered and it was infested w/ fruit flies.  The lady pointed this out and the bartender got snarky, even saying the bacteria would be killed by alcohol, but they wouldn't give them out again (he made several drinks later using those lemons).  We later saw a roach crawling across the bar, which non chalantly the bartender smashed with a cleaning rag and went back to personal conversation w/ another bartender.

There was a patron who was BLASTED drunk and kept stumbling on stools, people and slurred out his drink order.  I was afraid he'd knock someone off a bar stool.  They ACTUALLY SERVED him more alcohol!  TWO drinks later, he fell off his bar stool and they SERVED him ANOTHER drink.  At 1:30 last call was yelled and by 1:50a, folks still wanted drinks and were served.  

If you want a dirty place that has staff more concerned w/ making extra tip $ than keeping a safe bar, Irish Bank is your place!
author: Jason N.

description:
It's an Irish pub without Killian's.

I went as part of a big group, and the wait staff stopped by once in a blue moon. I had to stand and gesticulate like a palsied mime to attract a server's attention and get a drink. A lot of us paid on our own, and we all contributed to the group tab, but ultimately their bill was way, way above our calculations. 

Overall not a very pleasant experience - I expect we'll be taking the group elsewhere next time.
author: Andrew E.

description:
four starts for the bar and an extra one for the beer.  the staff was friendly and helpful explaining the beers on tap, providing a sample and inviting us to return for bastille day. BASTILLE DAY? WTF. since when does an irish pub celebrate a french NATIONAL holiday.  there is an explanation ... since the bank is surrounded by french restaurants who celebrate bastille day ... they joined in.  i'm not sure i'm satisfied ... but at least its something. 

i won't be back for bastille day but i will certainly be back for the Boddingtons (Manchester) - it was quite possibly THE BEST beer i've ever had.  I'm ready to jump on a plane and fly to manchester to see if the beer tastes better there (that's how good it was).
author: Cori D.

description:
I will write more later.  Only quick anti-reccomendation: DON'T order a Margarita!  We asked for salt and very little stayed on the rim.  It ended up being saltier than salt water.  BLECH!!!

The food is pretty good.  I really like the atmosphere.  I don't really want to complain about the place but that drink was worse than it being watered down.  Sloppy, sloppy, sloppy.

I get that it's an Irish pub.  But if you can't pour the drink, get the fuck of the bar.  BLECH, I can still taste it.  Months later!!!
author: Augie S.

description:
After a long hard days work, my boyfriend and I strolled up and down the streets downtown. Looking for what? Who knows...All I know is, he kept suggesting dingy bistro after dingy bistro, when I thought to myself, "I could go for some Irish fare" when suddenly, The Irish Bank appeared in front of us! Its not so often your cravings are answered. I had to answer fates knock, so we made our way into the restaurant.

It looks like your typical restaurant/pub except there is cute outdoor seating, probably nicer at night, but cute nonetheless. We wandered to the back, sat ourselves and waited for the fabulously flustered waitress to take our drink order. We could tell they were busy, and we were in no rush, so we didn't mind the 10 minute wait. After the waitress took our drink orders the service was very prompt. The only reason I gave this place 4 stars instead of 5 was because the drinks (Pint of Guiness and Pint of Pear cider) tasted a little watered down. for 3 bucks a pint, I probably wouldn't mind, but for 5-6 bucks, I expect it to taste like it just came outta the bottle, not watered down. 

I ordered the Shepherd's Pie and he ordered the hamburger(typical guy food). He wolfed that thing down faster than I could finish though, that's for certain. When they brought my food I was surprised because I'm used to shepherds pie being in a long shallow plate, not the souffle looking bowl they brought. After I sunk my first spoon into the meaty potatoey delicious souffle or brule or whatever heavenly thing this pie was, I was hooked! So yummy and comforting, the dish I've needed since I moved here 6 years ago! The Mash was cooked on top just so much that it created a slight fry/cheesy crust around the edges, and I feel like the depth of the bowl locked in all the juices. I would go here again for sure! And I plan on it soon, maybe after some drunken brawl when I could use a pint...
author: Heather T.

description:
It's a little weird having to walk down Raper's Alley to get to this place... but when you do, it's like finding that pot of gold.  A traditional Irish pub with great beers, great whiskey, great atmosphere, and great people.

Two separate rooms, one up close to the bar and a second room with low tables good for putting together groups and having great conversations about the world.  Also lots of outdoor seating when it's really crackin'.

Good location for me.  About 3 blocks away from Bart, so a good last stop before heading back to the East Bay.
author: Shannon C.

description:
