If you're into the Irish pub experience, The Irish Bank is for you. It has got lots of photos of Ireland, Nuns and Priests on the walls, wooden floors, barrels and kegs, etc. They also have outdoor seating, which would be pretty nice when the weather's warm. I took a friend here, and it was really crowded and loud inside, so we went to go sit outside, but after just a few minutes, they started tearing down all the tables and chairs and putting them away, and told us we needed to go back inside. Bummer. Even though the pub is open until 2:00am, they close down the outdoor seating around 11pm.

It eventually calmed down inside, so we were able to hang out for a few hours at a little table, having a nice conversation and drinking Cranberry Tonics. As you approach this place, fight the urge to turn around and run for your life. You have to walk down a side alley to get here, and all your instincts will tell you that you're in a dangerous place, but don't worry. It's a lot of fun.
author: Ron S.

description: Nothing special about the Irish Bank. Yah, it's cool that it is located in an alley, but their drinks were only ok.  They have a $10 minimum charge when using credit cards and they don't split the bill if there is a group of people.  Overall experience was blah.  I think Rickhouse is a better choice which is just around the corner.
author: Chloe A.

description:
Let me preface this review by a few things. I have been going to the Irish Bank since 2000 (that's ten years). While I was working in San Francisco (from 2000-2006) I went there to eat no less than once a week. So I very familiar with the place as well as the people who work there. I am also aware that since I have been going there, there has been an ownership change. I can say before my last visit I would give this place 4-5 stars easy.

So I am back in the States for a while and went to watch the England/USA World Cup match at AT&T Park on Saturday (12/6/10). After the match we decided to head over to the Irish Bank for a quick lunch. (We were a few home sick Brits looking for a place that we know in the past has always helped squash some of the homesickness.) 

(I had not been there since 2009 but its always been a known entity so I was expecting a great experience.). The first thing I noticed was that the wait staff just flat out ignored us, so we sat ourselves down. (Before the wait staff had always been super friendly and VERY welcoming).  We got ourselves a menu and a waitress came up and asked us for our drinks order. 

The next thing I noticed was that the menu had been greatly expanded which seemed great to me at the time. There were more vegetarian options and more hip selections than there had been in the past. The Irish Bank for many years has been known for its fish and chips, It even won a award once as "best in SF" and I had ordered then many times in the past, so I ordered them this time.  

At this point I was still a little disappointed in the way the staff treated us but after half a pint of so I was feeling better. My friend and I were sitting there deep in conversation and I think sometime during that someone from the kitchen brought out my fish and chips. We were so busy talking we didn't notice him. He must have been annoyed because he basically shoved the plate in my face and said "here!" and marched off. (He was rather unkempt and had a really unprofessional bushy beard as well.)

I was really annoyed at his behaviour but I again let it go. But then I looked at my plate. The fish and chips were totally different than what I had had before. The fish used to be in a very nice, flaked batter, very similar to what you get in Great Britain. The fish in front of me was in some type of hard, dark brown cocoon that looked more like something you would get from the store. The actual fish was tough and rubbery and had a batter to fish ration of like four to one. It was really horrible. I was so disappointed. And the chips? They were so dark from being cooked in dirty grease they were as brown as leather! And so gross! 

Also, I should add almost the whole time we were there our waitress disappeared for most of our experience.   

I just am still gob-smacked. What the hell happened to this place? It used to be my favourite place to eat at in all of the Bay Area. I can tell you this woman will NOT being going back. 

It's not just how bad everything was, it's has far it's fallen. So sad...




.
author: Gaelic F.

description:
This place is usually very crowded to the point where you have to wait in Disneyland-type lines to get to the bar or bathroom. This place feels a little too popular for its own good at prime times, often stretching the capacity of the hard working wait staff to keep up.

Popular? Yes.
Relaxing? No.
Food? Authentic.
Urinals? Three in remarkably close proximity to one another.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I hadn't planned on doing any St. Patty's celebrations until the actual St. Patty's Day but after a morning of bottomless mimosas at Lime, I was primed for more partying.  (Thank you, inebriated Karen.)  

Irish Bank was having a St. Patty's Day celebration after the parade so the lane was closed off and a stage was set up for live music.  Waitresses were carrying various beers around to hydrate the party-goers and everyone was in a pretty jovial mood.  The outside party section was pretty clean and so was the inside of the bar.  Actually, the inside of the bar was pretty romantic.  It had that classic Irish bar setting with the dark wood, gold metal bars, and photos of Irish people.  JFK portraits hung by the ladies room.    

Overall, I had a great time enjoying the company and the ambiance of the Irish Bank.  Looking forward to going here again.
author: Karen N.

description:
..was here on a game night one night (Giants)..The crowd had good energy and they seemed to be enjoying themselves. 
We sat at the isolated booth area (was the only table avail) and i actually liked it - it was cozy and private=)
I had the fish and chips and a glass of hef. AND i loved it! I want to go back! 
The best part, of course, was to be at an Irish bar w/ an Irish! haha! We had a great time...
I would go back to this place- nice irish pub decor , friendly staff, good crowd..
and good fish and chips! heuheuheu.
author: C A.

description:
A solid Irish pub. Great selection of pub style beers, including of course guinness, harpers, boddingtons, murphys, etc. The place knows how to pour a legit pint of guinness, which according to the masters requires the "double pour technique", clocked in at 119.53 seconds. It makes a difference - I've had a straight pour and its a glass of foam. The bar snacks I've tried are good and I like how you can order from the bar at night - helps keep an even keel whilst imbibing your third pint.

The ambiance is typical Irish pub, but done well. There is a church confessional tucked in between the two rooms - I NEED to get that spot someday! Needless to say you must be quick because people jump on it faster than an open spot at the bar. 

I love the Irish bank on weekdays, or weekends during the day. Weekends at night this place can get super crowded and the bar can't handle crowds very well. Due to the prime real estate on which the Irish bank sits (off Union square) prices per pint are around $6, so not the cheapest. 

The breakdown: 4.5 stars for atmosphere
                           4 stars for drink and food
                           2 stars for price and crowd
author: Jon L.

description:
After my fifth time here, I figure it's time to finally write my review for Irish Bank? Besides I think the waitress knows our work group and our drink orders by heart now.

My usual Maker's and Ginger is quite refreshing to absorb into my bloodstream, while watching people wander in and out of the cool and breezy alley way on a hot summer's day. And heavenly for those days when I'm craving a Smithwicks - even better being on tap! Plus their bathroom has a good feel to it (yes, I know it's odd to say that, but it's very true!) 

Their fries come with a delicious curry dipping sauce and their mac 'n cheese is a creamy delicious puddle topped with bread crumbs in just the right proportion that surprisingly was pulled off very well.  Seeing as how I have an obsession with finding places with good mac n' cheese and nice bathrooms, Irish Bank is a definite work night excuse to relax and have knock a few back.
author: Alita M.

description: Oh Irish Bank, I do love you. You are reliable with seating for the post-work drinks even on a Friday, but goodness, I lose my voice every time I come here. You can't control the volume of the place, I get that. But if it weren't for your proximity to the office, not sure if you'd get my business all too often.
author: Raina B.

description:
I do not spend much time in this neighborhood and I am really not sure what I was expecting but this place was neither blowing me away or completely disappointing me. It was just okay. 

The menu was pub fare and with a good selection of beer and booze it made up for the lack of creativity on the menu. They did have a nice little alley way to sit outside in and there were plenty of people there to give it a busy feel. 

The services was great and ultimately made it a place that I would go back to... Okay only if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Ryan B.

description:
This is a great pub - especially during Bastille Day or St Patrick's!
When I'm hungry I usually order either the curry chips (so good!) or the bangers and mash (SO good!).
author: Ed P.

description:
Ahh, the Irish Bank!  The quintessential San Francisco Irish bar.  I love it!!
It has all the elements of a great bar: Outside seating (which, can be hard to come by in SF for some odd reason that I could never explain), plenty of great tunes on the jukebox (the Irish greats like the Pogues, Flogging Molly, etc), standard pub food (burgers, fish n chips, etc.), a really nice extensive selection of scotch and whiskey and plenty of good beers on tap.
author: Bethany D.

description: Full of Irish Americans drinking late into the weekday night. Great Guinness pour
author: Ryan K.

description:
Please Note: This review is for Guinness and bar area only

My friend suggested we go here to taste the best Guinness in town. Apparently it takes great care to pour a Guinness correctly and it needs to be poured often in order to reach its full potential.

The Guinness was GREAT. PERFECT HEAD and super smooth. The bar area was PRETTY SMALL but looked like a fun place to go to WARM UP before hitting the clubs or other bars. I noticed they had on outdoor patio that seemed like a fun place to sit during warm days. It sounded like the bartender had an Irish accent which always add to the experience.
author: henrik T.

description:
What's not to like?  They've got beer, hard liquor, and food.  
I love this place, especially on the weekends.  I often have to be in the office on the weekends, and it's nice to take a lunch break and get their full breakfast before heading back for another few hours.  It's tough not to feel comfortable in this bar.
author: Ken M.

description:
Oh, internets, sometimes I need to trust you.

Whilst in SF, I was in search of a place to watch some World Cup Soccer. So many resources existed to give me options, but they were very poor about narrowing them down. I do not want every place that happens to have a television, I want a good soccer pub where I can enjoy a hearty beer and the company of many like minded fans. But no, I kept being overwhelmed with options.

I ended wandering the streets and asking the first person I bumped into wearing a soccer jersey where he was going. He pointed me to the jumbotron at the commons, which was pretty cool (even if I had to brown bag my beverage).

However, later in my wanderings I learned I made a mistake.

Odd options would come up in my search. For example, the German Cultural Institute. I understand they might show Germany games, but I don't think they would have a bar, so they were no good. Across from them was a place called "Irish Bank" which I assumed was actually a bank, and likewise ignored it. 

That was my mistake. The Irish Bank is in fact a wonderful Irish pub, and had a good crowd for the Third Place Game. Wait service was a little slow, but overall I really dug the place and wish I could have spent more time there.

SIDE NOTE: I understand you have the habit of throwing a Bastile Party (which is already a little odd for an Irish pub), but given what France did to Ireland this year, I'm surprised they didn't cancel it.
author: Ralph M.

description:
I LOVE this place!!!!

They serve up an awesome fish & chips, but one must try their fries with a side of curry sauce --- Yum! Super FiDi spot with a great crowd and tasty beers.
author: Lisa R.

description: I like the Irish Bank a lot.  The Guinness and the food are good! and the atmosphere is real San Francisco.  It isn't trying to be something that it is not - a fact which I think contributes to many of the negative reviews from our friends in Southern California.
author: Stan M.

description: Ive deposited a lot of money at this bank, with outrageous returns. They have a great St. Patty's Day block party.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Fantastic pub bangers, mash & beans - subtle, satisfying flavors. Fish & chips were standard fare. The blue cheese chips were a delightful surprise - literally large pub chips covered in flavorful globs of real blue cheese...especially delicious after a few pints.
Appropriate beer selection for the venue. 
Feels like a 'secret' watering hole tucked away in a small alley. Interior was classic Irish pub style. Warm and friendly atmosphere to meet friends.
A bit pricey and did find the hand written, multi-page check a bit confusing at the end of the evening...but who doesn't enjoy a little math puzzle when you're buzzed on Smithwicks?
Would return for social gatherings.
author: Kim A.

description: This place came highly recommend from a bartender down the street....so I wonder how bad THEIR food was. I suppose if you were only looking for a place to have some beer with friends, this place works. Do not go for the food. Irish pub food? No. Elementary school cafeteria? Yes. The Irish Stew tasted suspiciously similar to canned Dinty Moore Beef Stew with instant mashed potatoes thrown on top. And the "bangers and mash" was pretty much Van De Camps beans, more instant potatoes and a pretty horrible brat that my husband didn't even finish. Top it off with the "mystery drink ingredients" (energy drink and vodka...waitress had no clue which energy drink or what vodka???) and it was a very disappointing $65 dollar dinner. I can't imagine traveling all the way to San Francisco and think you are getting some authentic Irish food....stick with any of the incredible Chinese restaurants around since this is in Chinatown.
author: Cheri P.

description: This place is great. The owner is a fantastic bloke and the pace is spot on. I had the fish and chips, expecting them to be good from an Irish bar, and they were. Only thing better would be if they served them in newspaper. Dig the outdoor seating too.
author: Brian H.

description:
Wondered in here on a vacation with my girlfriend. It's tucked away in an alley and has a pretty good sized patio. 
We went in on a Thursday night around 9:00 or so. Most restaurants in this area seem to close around 9:00 or 9:30, so it was great to find somewhere that was still open and had a decent menu. 
They were pretty busy and we had to order food at the bar and then seat ourselves. This, in and of itself, really wasn't a big deal. The main reason I'm only giving three stars is because of the service we received from one of the bartenders. He was very short with both of us and seemed annoyed with everything.
The food was overall really good and reasonably priced. They had some decent beers on tap as well. I'd recommend this place to my friends that are visiting San Fran or to locals who haven't discovered it yet.
author: Iris C.

description: Hidden away in the bustle of downtown SF, this bar is a real Irish haunt complete with actual Irish bartenders. Adorable alley dotted with tables reminiscent of something you'd find in Europe welcomes you as you enter the bar. Good beer selection. Great place to watch a football match or get some grub.
author: Kate P.

description:
I wandered down there for the St. Patrick's day party. I don't normally come here, it's usually too crowded and the food is really mediocre, but I thought I'd get there before 4 when everyone said is when they would start charging a cover.

Somewhere in the 5 minutes it took me to walk, the bar owners got greedy and decided start charging cover an hour and a half early. Want a St. Patrick's Day party? Go to Royal Exchange, they do it better with no cover.
author: Darren M.

description:
Well, came by this afternoon for a burger and maybe a drink or two. The burger was great, but waiting 20 mins before the bartender bothered asking if I wanted a refill on my water was kinda disappointing. Sigh.

This isn't the type of experience I'm used to getting here.  I guess the lunch bartender didn't really want to wait on a new face.  I think I'll stick with nights - the night time staff is much more attentive.
author: Jay B.

description:
Let me just say this: I'm a HUGE fan of Irish pubs. And while this isn't necessarily a tiny little pub, it's decor, sports games, old fashioned posters and selection of beers on tap make it a wonderful, not-so-little Irish pub.

The food is pretty solid, too. Try a burger or the cheese steak with peppers. Make sure to visit on a warmer day so you can enjoy the "patio" in the alley...
author: christine c.

description: Quality fish tacos at an Irish place? Odd but true. Also points to the Irish server who wouldn't let me order an Irish coffee incorrectly. Large amount of outdoor seating off the beaten path and a dark indoors that makes you feel like its a time of the day that should involve drinking.
author: Megan C.

description:
This place does only one thing really bad and it's service. Waitresses are few and far in between, so if you're about half through with your drink, you better snag the closest server you find or you won't get a drink until you've sobered up.

I used to come here with my coworkers all the time because it's so convenient and they have a full bar that accommodates everyone's tastes. It's super casual, so if you come with your coworkers, get prepared to know everyone's dirty little secrets.
author: NickJess S.

description: I ended a fun night of bar hopping at the Irish Bank. The bartenders were Irish, the crowd was fun, & drinks were replaced right away after the last one was finished. Didn't try the food but overall a fun night!
author: Maggie M.

description: Outside is where it's at! This was a great place to meet up with old friends and drink some beers. Their food was mighty tasty- normal pub food. Service was spectacular- our server was so attentive and helpful.
author: Mandy B.

description: When we vacation in SF, we always end a good day of running around the hilly city with a drink at the irish bank.  Its easy to miss, it is tucked away in an alley off of Bush.  We have met some great people here (Armand if you are reading this, we still look for you every time we come).  I will be back many times in the future, until San Francisco falls into the ocean.
author: Kat K.

description: A nice place to have a couple of beers. Overall, the staff is friendly. At time, they appear to be a little hurried as if there might not be quite enough staff on. But it is still one of San Francisco's better pubs. The patio is great. and there potato skins are very good. Decent pub food all around.
author: Mark D.

description: Great Irish Pub just where it should be - down an alley, middle of town, not pretentious. Had about 16 beers on tap and the Fish and Chips were light and tasty. For a $20 meal, with a Guinness, in SF you can't beat it.  I keep coming back.
author: Drew O.

description:
Great bar on Saint Patty's Day to hit up early with friends and bail on before it gets too crowded... they serve food, live talented music, and a big alley that is both cool and functional enough to stuff in a hundred of your friends.

Unfortunately my only exposure to The Irish Bank is on Patty's Day, but inside the bar they were on it.  Outside the waitresses seemed to be working the crowd pretty well, however it was still pretty early.  The service here is spot on when the place is not crowded, otherwise, plan on double fisting it out of necessity rather than want.

The inside of the bar is cool, but the outside spills out into an alley where you and a hundred of your friends could be in and totally comfortable if you get there before noon and thats a hard quality to duplicate by any other Irish Bar in The City on Patty's Day! lol ..  which is the main reason for the rating and I look forward to eating and actual meal here and seeing if the four stars is warranted.
author: Edibleocea N.

description:
"Bless your little Irish heart and every other Irish part"...as they say 

Especially the Irish part such as that stomach of yours once you head on over to the Irish Bank

Love this charming little bar & restaurant tucked away in an alley at the Financial District

Growing up, corned beef was in a can and we ate it with fried rice...loaded with preservatives but it was damn good, I admit, but it was an awesome surprise that I finally got to taste the real thing 

Corned beef & cabbage was served in a warm plate with buttery mashed potatoes, tangy golden mustard and fresh sauerkraut. The corned beef was prepared as if you can pull the beef apart...so juicy and seasoned to perfection. The cabbage was steamed, easy to eat & salted just right

Plus you can savor the meal in such as quaint restaurant setting...great for dates or a night out with your friends. I came by after 5PM on a Thursday and the place was filled with the happy hour crowd...you can make it lively or relaxing

Their famous Reuben sandwich is a try on my next visit
author: Charmian D.

description:
Navigating through a dark alleyway in the midst of dumpsters from both sides, Miss Princess Stab Stab (Juv) and her Irish accomplice accompany me through this walk. Juv pointed out that it would be a great place to dispose of a skinny little white-boy.. 
As we approach the bar, the exterior immediately radiated this rustic backwater charm. White brick walls littered with Guinness tin pub signs give this place a Wally's Filling Station feel. I sit down, take a deep breath and really enjoy the relaxed atmosphere. Here is a bar to have a few drinks and relax. Every time I find myself in this area I have trouble finding a relaxed bar with a chair to rest my lazy bones and this is it. I mean who wants to go to a bar and stand anyway?
author: Bradley P.

description:
02.04.10

Did you know that the Irish Bank used to be named the Bank of Ireland, until they got sued by the actual Bank of Ireland for trademark rights?

Things you learn drinking on a Thursday night.

Do you know that this place serves the most Guinness out of all of SF?

Imported beer on draft: $5.50-$6
Domestic beer on draft: $4.50-$5.50
Bottled imports: $4.50-$7
Bottled domestics: $4-$5

A few rounds kind of breaks the bank.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This was the Second stop for me on my Drinking Thursdays.

This place really wasnt my cup of tea, but my friend chose this place cause it was close to her work.  

We had the nachos and I had an Anchor Steam.  Cant go wrong with that combo.  At least it was a really nice day to be hanging out outside.  When everyone else showed up, we ended up leaving and headed to Thirsty Bear.

All in all, this place isnt bad.  I would just prefer a different atmosphere.

= )
author: Tony Y.

description:
Thought I would try a pub close to the triton hotel for lunch.  The Irish pub was just in the alley. And looked fun. I ordered shepherds pie and a beer and the waiter was off. The dish clearer came by with the shepherds pie which was obviously burnt and scalding inside making it virtually inedible. Beer gone, I waited patiently for the waiter who was taking a break flirting with the kitchen staff. (After they just opened). Again dish clearer to the rescue who brought me my new beer and blue cheers fries.  When I tried to open the ketchup, it exploded like a well shaken coke. All over a cashmere blazer. I hunted down my waiter and asked for a towel and sparkling water. When he brought it, I asked why it exploded. "Oh yeah, we clean the bottles and refill them. Air trapped in the hot bottle compresses and explodes, sorry". When I asked whether they would offer to pay for cleaning I got, "I bought you a beer"

Wow. Maybe this is normal?  A new normal for customer care?

Some times we can't mark even one star, if they offered black hole reviews, this would get two black holes.
author: Griffin D.

description:
MIX REVIEWS.

The first time I came here was the start of our 5:30pm - 2:30am Happy Hour session. That was one long and crazy night. This was the first bar we hit up only to walk in and be the only people of color. The people were nice but it was overly crowded and we just didn't feel too comfortable. 

The second and third and forth time I've been here were lunch meet ups. Grab a beer or a shot and have some lunch-eats. CHICKEN WINGS and FRENCHFRIES are the hit. Definately worth the taste. 

I'll be back for another visit.
author: Jane A.

description:
A cute, clean, elaborately decorated pub with a great selection of booze for all of your pubbing needs.  Great stop while shopping at Union Square or China Town -- also always fun to drag not-in-the-know friends down the alley with the dumpsters as they demand to know how you found this place the first time.

For some reason this place always shuts down earlier than most of the other places in the city on holidays like St. Patrick's and NYE.
author: Tasha D.

description: The bartenders never seem to be too happy but I love the abundance of outdoor seating under a canopy of lights. One of my go-to after work spots.
author: Hillary H.

description:
I wish I would have found this place earlier in the night AND in my life!  I've been to a few pubs out in the states, but this is so far on my top list.  Ever since I went to Ireland, I have fallen in love with Irish pubs.  Something about the atmosphere is extremely relaxing yet lively at the same time. 

At there late in the evening but there was quite a bit of people in and out of the bar.  The patio area is nice, not sure if they have heaters in the winter but the summer, drinks there must be amazing. Their menu looked delicious but I didn't get a chance to try much.  I wanted to try them all even though I do not eat meat.  The Fish n Chips looked really appetizing.  

The downside to sitting on the patio is that it is hard to get service.  It's perfect for large groups and parties. For a more intimate experience, sitting at the bar or inside is probably best.  All in all, I recommend this place.  Kind of hard to find but worth it.  Hopefully I will be able to make it there for St. Patty's Day and have a Guinness!!
author: chibi c.

description:
I loved mostly the very laid back chilled atmosphere and lay-out of this place, I've made it a 'the spot' sort of place and look forward to hanging out there, I've build memories there on dates and just mostly enjoyed the cozy feel that it overs! 
   I liked the beers I had, although I found the mixed drinks a bit on the weaker side at times and way too strong at others.
author: Benoît B.

description: Awesome tap selection & great atmosphere
author: Nathan M.

description:
Way Way back in the mid 90's, this was "The Bank of Ireland."  They got threatened with some legal action, and changed the name.  I was worried other things would change about the bank as well.  They have not.  The sheperd's pie still dominates, the Irish bartendresses still rule, and the confessional is still a great place to make out late night.

I could do without the smell of piss in the grant alley enterance.
author: Pablo E.

description:
.This is my absolute favorite bar to stop at after work with a group of people. It has outdoor seating during nice weather and it has a decent sized indoor seating area as well, especially if you're ordering food.

We go in around 6 and start our evening with a round of Irish car bombs,. The bartenders are friendly, the mixed drinks are strong, and they have a nice selection of beers on tap. We order some cheesy chips and chicken wings (not hot wings sadly, just normal chicken wings) but the savory food more than takes us through the evenings. A pint of Magners, a pint of Smithwicks, a pint of Leffe.... we alternate what we drink throughout the evening and occasionally will order another around of car bombs.

Their food is a bit pricey, but it's solid and goes well with my Smithwicks or Boddingtons. We can drink at a relaxed pace and get away from the madness of work by walking only 2 blocks.

Their bathrooms are quite small, but I won't begrudge them that. Overall, it's a fantastic place to spend the evening and a favorite place of mine for Friday nights. See you there.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Awesome bar with great food.  Just remember that it's a pub, so get pub food and drink--they do both exceptionally well.  Great place to go to hang out with friends after work.  They have great outdoor and indoor seating, the staff is friendly, and the music is good.  People will make friends with you if you look like you are alone for two seconds.  I heartily recommend the shepherd's pie.

The St. Patty's day party is off the hook.  Get there early or late if you want to avoid being crushed by a mob trying to get to the bar.  Literally, 5 people deep all around at 7 pm.  The party is also frequented by real Irish people (complete with thick accents), who say it greatly resembles Ireland, except everyone is slightly more sober.  However, the base is so loud that it's hard to have any sort of conversation outside in the alley, and American pop princesses are favored over Irish music of any sort, though apparently this is true of parties in Ireland as well.
author: Sydney H.

description: Not sure if this was a racist moment or not, but I was the only black person in a large crowd watching the World Cup semi finals this morning. And I was also the only one that was asked to purchase something while I was waiting for my group (we were planning to order bfast and watch). Whether it was or not, it's still lame and counter to general celebratory World Cup feeling in the city. Heading back to my local bar where they'll probably have free pastries. Won't be back.
author: Hopey N.

description:
It's ALL about the company you keep.  I'm certain of this.  NO matter where the venue --- how much you enjoy yourself has a lot to do with those you choose to surround yourself with. 

That said, my best bud and I took the advice of Mike the bartender @ Gitane --- to head over to the Irish Bank for two choice whisk(e)ys.  

Gotta love the "neighborhood" feel of the place, even at a smidgen before last call.  I have to admit, most of the appeal for this place was their extensive selection of scotches.  I'm duly impressed.  

What impressed me more was the staff.  Especially Mark --- who not only got dragged into a heated debate between my best bud and I, but ended up reminding me why I love pubs so much.  It's the company you keep, people.  It really is.

I've gotta try their fish n' chips.  I've been so traumatized by the demise of the Cat & the Fiddle's lackluster fare --- I haven't mustered up the courage to go foraging for another option.  Hmmmm....
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
Came here after sushi for pre-running drinks on SF Marathon weekend.  
5 people in the party and we were seated in a nice area. Started first with drinks and then food, then of course, more drinks...
The waitress was excellent. She had a great disposition even though we were acting like total tourists to the bar and could not figure out what we wanted.

We ordered the Ruben and some Blue Cheese fries.  Not extraordinary food but hot, fresh, and totally perfect for the atmosphere of the place.  

Had a great night there and totally love the ambiance of the place. Being of a strong Irish-Welsh background it totally made me stop and look around a while to revel in the past.
author: Dean M.

description: I loved it. The only place for the Saint Patrick's Day Festival.
author: Reid T.

description: I love the fact that it's irish owned and that it has some authenticity cool irish artifacts news clippings and the likes I just wish it had a stage
author: Josh A.

description:
Good selection of drinks and food. But my veggie shepard's pie was cold in the middle :( and was gross other wise.
I really wanted this to be my mclarens (how I met your mother lol) I'll try the nachos next time and drink maybe I can enjoy this place since its across the street.
author: Courtney M.

description:
I've been to this place twice now.

Every time I come it's always a fun crowd and very lively and upbeat!  

Now, I don't know if they do this all the time but, yesterday when I came they had a little Irish band with bagpipes and all playing inside and outside the place!! How cool was that!!  

Anyway...I usually come here with big groups so it's always nice.

We usually get apps like chicken fingers, shepherd's pie, chips and things!  Apps are really good!  

It's a really cool place to visit!!
author: Monique T.

description:
I'm sorry, when was it ever okay to treat your customers like they are all rude drunken idiots no matter how busy and hectic the place gets. The moment I sat down, our service was nothing more than terrible. I flagged down a waitress after being ignored for a while and our interaction goes as follow:

Me: Hi, excuse me; can we order some food through you?
Waitress: Yes, but I can't do split checks.
Me: Ok. But can we split it two ways...
Waitress: NO. That was the first thing I said. I can't split the bill.
Me: Oh Sorry, I meant on two credit cards.
Waitress: Yes. But I can't do it on more than two cards. And there must be a minium of  $10 dollars per card.
Me: Ok. That's fine. I'll have the wings and my friends here wants some fries.
Waitress: You do realize that's only 15 dollars right? You must order at least $20 dollars.
Me: Ok, give me another beer.

So she storms off and disappears. My friends later meets up with us and sits down at a different table and tries to order some more food. Again, they were met with a similar situation from the same waitress with the condescending and bitchy tone. We weren't even sitting at the same table but she forced us to lump our bills together for some reason or another. She then proceeds to to get into an argument with my friend for even having the audacity for asking to split the bill again (even though she was unaware of the situation) and was firm in making sure we were all grouped together under one bill. I understand that whole multiple transaction thing can get annoying but it is never ok to speak to your customers with a short tone and make it seem like they're burdening you with the worse job in the world. It wasn't until we got our bill that I realize the waitress just wanted to tack on the mandatory gratuity to our bill since we were a big group. Good move waitress, I know you depend on tips for your salary but tips should be earned and not something you try to force onto your customers. You work in the service industry, please learn some manners and how to treat your customers with respect.

I know I should have escalated this to a manager that night instead of passive aggressively writing this review on yelp but oh well, what's done is done. I am never returning to this place again.
author: Kien N.

description: True through and through. Want an Irish bar down an alley? Done. Good cold drinks and authentic ambiance.
author: Ryan B.

description: Fantastic food, great service and they are ever so warm and welcoming.
author: Deanna P.

description: Good local Irish bar, I've had excellent times here. When its nice out they have outside seating in the alley way which is nice. Not to much to say here, good bar, good location in Union Sqaure.
author: Jess O.

description:
Boyfriend and I went here the Friday after St Patrick's Day with a friend to celebrate without the crowd.  I've been here before a few years ago, and I had fond memories, but mostly of the baked beans ... which are just from a can (Heinz). 

This time I was excited to go, but all of us were disappointed by the end.  The menu online said they have a Ploughman's sandwich which I came to LOVE when I used to live in London.  Then I found out once there -- it was taken off the menu!  But they kept NACHOS?   Really?  Blah.  Also not many other vegetarian choices.

The three of us split the mac and cheese appetizer, hearing wonderful things about it ... but, uh, those people obviously haven't had good mac and cheese.  It tasted like it'd be microwaved and then they threw some bread cumbs on the top to give it a homemade look.

The only good thing they did was pour a pint of Guinness just right, but you'd hope it wouldn't be too difficult for an Irish pub to do that.
author: Dana G.

description: This place is so welcoming and "homey"... You'll find great drinks, great people, and WONDERFUL food here! My favorite is the chicken strips. This is a hidden treasure in the city. LITERALLY hidden ^_^
author: Katrice S.

description:
Nice spot in the Fidi, tucked away in an alley.

Bartenders were friendly, wait staff attentive.
author: David H.

description:
I will tell ya the only saving grace about my Saturday eve visit last night....was the location, plenty of indoor & covered
outdoor seating!!  A good selection of brews on tap.!!  I had something amber from Deschuttes OR...not Irish by a long shot but "bloody" excellent! 

The mixed drinks really weak & ripoff. I almost called them cocktails because of the eye candy bartenders (authentic accents almost make the ripoff worthwhile).  But we got overit amd moved on to greener & better Irish pub on west portal.
author: Bryan G. W.

description: The food was okay, but the service was terrible. It was on a Wednesday night and not even busy. Took forever to get our drinks and even longer to order our meal. Way over priced!!!  Never again!
author: Michael W.

description:
Love this place!
First visited it in August with a very large group for dinner and then went back this past weekend for lunch on Saturday with a small group.  
The service is not amazing but it's not bad but the food is GREAT!
I love the mac and cheese.  The salad with walnuts and blue cheese is really good - although it could use more of both.
The Irish Stew is very tasty and even tastier if you throw in chunks of blue cheese from the blue cheese fries - recommend them also!  They come with tons of blue cheese so I guess you could throw some of that on your salad too if you order it all.
My wife had the vegetarian shepherds pie and was very happy with it.  
The coffee is good.
I think this place is only good for large groups in the summer when it is warm as most of their large tables are outside in the alley and it can be quite cold even in the summer.
author: Janz P.

description:
I never write negative reviews, but this place deserves one.  Went there on March 31 after an event per suggestion from a friend.  Got there and was initially quite impressed.  Good location, neat decor, great patio outside, had great potential.  That was the highlight of the evening.

Sat down with my group and ordered a round of Guiness.  Half the group had already arrived a bit earlier, and were finishing their meal.  Paid for the first round, and stepped outside to use the patio.  Had been out there all of 15 minutes, and ordered our 2nd round.  Upon delivering the 2nd round, the waiter informs us that the patio is closing at 11pm.  It was 10:55.  So he tells us we have to down our just delivered Guiness.  Um, no, you don't pound a Guiness...

We asked if the bar was closing, and they said no, the bar is not closing until 2:00am, they just don't want to have to deal with the patio.  On a Saturday night?  Seriously?  Sure enough, 5 minutes later, they are pulling the tables and chairs out from underneath us, and then taking away half unfinished beers from part of the group that couldn't finish a pint of Guiness in 3-5 minutes.  The best part was when one of the group went to get a drink of water from his glass, and the waiter even took that away mid-drink, saying they didn't even want the appearance of alcohol outside.

OK, fine, goodbye then.  Talk about a massive disappointment.  I'm sure this place is fun at times, but given my experience, on a Saturday night no less, I am never coming back.  Crappy staff means crappy management, and I don't give my business to places like this.
author: Clifton L.

description: One of the girls in our group got kicked out for being too loud.  I guess this Irish pub wants a library like atmosphere since she honestly wasn't being that much louder than the other patrons.   We had intended to end a birthday pub crawl there but instead were forced to find someplace else.  The fact that she was Irish was ironic.
author: Isaac H.

description:
The drinks here have always been awesome and affordable, and you can't beat drinking inside a confessional!  On hot days it can get pretty stifling inside, but the "patio" area in the alley has plenty of tables and a server will come to you for drink orders.

However, on my most recent visit I wasn't impressed with the food... I ordered sheperd's pie and a sausage. A while later, I was presented with a small dish filled with Manwich, Potato Buds, and canned vegetables along with something that probably came out of a wrapper that said Johnsonville. Come on, this is pub food, not rocket science.
author: Megan K.

description: A great little spot in the city to enjoy a beer and some pub food outdoors. We stumbled upon this place for the first time on one of those rare warm summer nights  while we were walking around Union Square. A pub with a little outdoor alleyway patio in the middle of San Francisco? We had to check it out. The food is pretty standard...it's not overly great, but it's not bad either. It's goes with beer just fine. Their service if you sit outside can be spotty...the two times that we've been, there was only one person covering the whole patio area so it took a while to flag them down if we wanted something...but we understood that they had a lot of area to cover and they were friendly. Their patio area is basically in an alley, but they've made it cozy and comfortable with plenty of decorative signs and lights. We've never been inside, so I can't account for the ambiance indoors. But, overall, it's a cool casual space to enjoy some beers with some friends.
author: Melissa C.

description: The crowd is older and somewhat business-y. It's really, really chilled in there. I like the selection of liquor and beer they offer here, but I wish the service would be better. The bartender that served my friend and I weren't exactly too welcoming, but he did make me a pretty strong and good cocktail, haha.
author: Mandy C.

description:
Was hungry for an early lunch so we were the first patrons inside when they opened at 11:30am on a Friday.  Within 5 minutes, the place was packed!

And I can see why!  The food came out quickly and was delicious.   We split the rueben and steak sandwich.  The blue cheese fries have huge hunks of blue cheese - yum!

The servers are really friendly and pleasant.  And a good value for the food and drink.

Would love to go back when it's warmer and sit outside all day!
author: Kirsten S.

description: Great atmosphere and decent pub grub, but if you're looking for a place to look for some footie, this isn't it: none of the TVs have HD service, and, even worse, are set to take an SD image and distort it by stretching it.  Quite disappointing, actually.
author: Mike B.

description:
Rude, not a great pint of Guinness, food dull........It had so much potential. What  went wrong,  Firstly we were asked to move, then we were told a liar as to why we had to move....but whatever, I thought not to worry, a great pint of Guinness and Shepherds pie would make up for it....how disappointed was I. My Guinness was not creamy like at my local, oh no this was bitter and some horrible after taste. I changed drinks. The food, nice selection but the shepherd pie was terrible it was sweet as though sugar had been added. My friends had the curry, same again and it was more Chinese not the korma style I had expected. The burgers were okay- frozen sort but acceptable, wings were good but nothing to write home about. However the service was the worst I had in some time and to add insult upon insult they told me how much to tip.....this is a cardinal sin, never ever tell me what to tip and certainly done make it 19% when there was no service. I wont be going back.

The only good thing was the snug.
author: Bells H.

description:
Burgers, wings and Guiness

You can't go wrong with that

TV's and music is good too.
author: Leo V.

description:
Ah, the Irish Bank.

Solid pub food.
Solid libations.
Solid Irish bar overall.


A note to my fellow misanthropes:
This place is a complete and total clusterfuck during peak hours.  This includes happy hour, weekend nights, and St. Patrick's Day.  You've been warned.
author: Cara Y.

description: Fun, casual atmosphere--great place to go and grab drinks and catch up with friends. Friendly staff, cool interior. They have this really cool booth you can sit at that's actually inside of a confessional. Pretty neat. Not a very wide range of beer on tap, but they do have chimay.
author: Emily L.

description:
This is my favorite bar in Union Square. Its got amazing food and good drinks. I love the outdoor seating area and the servers are super cool. I believe Jesse is one of the servers; he is so cute and sweet. I always send my guests here from the hotel. 

Keep up the good work.......
author: Gina S.

description:
I'd like to say Irish Bank is a good place to go after work if you're around the Financial District.

Forgive me if I'm being bias, but I enjoy Irish bars for reason that they serve Guinness on tap. I love Guinness and if they serve this delicious beverage, it's an automatic 5 stars on my list. I usually order the Black and Tan. Oh and how can I forget the BBQ wings!
The service is good. There were a few times when a few friends and I arrived right when their kitchen was about to close. They were still happy to take our order. That's something to really appreciate! I've been in their shoes, and whenever customers walk right before you close shop...It's not cool. The way the server kept his composure was something I needed to take note of.

Did I already mention they have Guinness on tap?
author: Jason N.

description:
The scene:
Saturday of Hardly Strictly. 
The group:
Me, boyfriend, brother and roomie
The crowd: 
bleh
The music:
bleh
The bartender:
MEGA BLEH!

 Upon arrival I'm instantly ditched by those who have in their 24 years not learned to control their bladders, so I head to the bar to get drinks. I smile, order and wait for something resembling a nice, human response from the bartender. Nothing. Annoyed that he could resist my charm and good taste in booze, I say: "You're pretty personable, eh?" Response: death stare. 

After a mild grimace and payment, we headed to the back room, which was loud and crowded, and the music ceased to exist. and it was hot hot hot! The four of us giants shared a mini table for four, finished our drinks as fast as we could, and took off for some horrible karaoke that was paramount to the experience we had here. 

Not stoked on it, but I would give it a second chance just so I could sit on the terrace outside (I'm a sucker for drinking in alleyways...)
author: Sarah C.

description:
I like the irish bank, but some of the servers need to be reminded that they are in the service industry and should show less attitude. In the back, I always see the bussers hustle from table to table, cleaning, helping out with orders, delivering food, etc, while the server is no where to be found. Finally, that person will saunter out and over at some point to check in/drop check. 

I was a server and cocktail waitress for years and obviously indifferent service drives me crazy.
author: J. M.

description:
I have been here a few times with my coworkers and I have enjoyed myself every time.  

Pros:
They know how to pour a Guinness 
Fun outdoor seating
Decent prices

Cons:
Outside is really windy
Food kind of sucks
author: Jeff P.

description: A large group of us went here on St. Patrick's Day. It was a lot of fun. Good drinks, great music, quick service. The only downside  is that  they did last call five minutes before they closed and we had to throw away all of the drinks that we had just bought.  They close at 12:00 A.M....weird.
author: Greatreviewer N.

description: Not a real Irish bar, and the service sucked big time.
author: Nikki F.

description:
The champagne splits are nice--we found it more economical to drink champagne than beer here.  I've only ever sat outside, so I can't comment on the inside atmosphere or service.

Wait staff can be a bit unpredictable, depending on who you're matched with for the night.  I've got a couple of favorites and then one woman who is just sour faced and dreadful.  It can be hard to get another round during the busy times, even with one of the better servers, but near impossible if you strike out and get one of the lesser crew members.

I'd skip the food here.  I didn't feel the quality matched the price, especially when you can duck into Akiko's for fantastic sushi, or slightly down the block to Claude Lane for either French or Catalan fare.  

Crowd is pretty mundane here.  Lots of people just off work stop in, and then sometimes there might be the odd party of newly 21 yr olds who are very loud and have trouble controlling themselves.  It's not really the sort of place you'd go to for the people, though.  Really, I think it's just a sort of generic place to hang out and have a few drinks before moving on for the evening.
author: Tuesday F.

description: Great stew drinks very reasonable. Great place to watch the Giants beat the tiger's. It's a bar with a lovely and tall Irish lass behind the bar. She works hard is attentive oh and attractive. Drinks are good place is close quarters when packed but a nice neighborhood feel to it. The cheers of San Francisco.
author: Dean C.

description:
We happened upon the Irish Bank when we made a wrong turn.  Since we are always up for a drink, we sat down.  Unique to San Francisco, where else do they turn an alley way into outdoor seating for a bar.  Drinks are cold and good, and if you are looking for good variety of American and Irish food, this will fit the bill.  We even found food that the kids would eat.  Maybe the service is slow, so don't come here on your lunch break.
Plan on staying a while and sampling beers poured correctly from the UK, decent food  and just a nice, unhurried place to hang with your friends.
And oh yeah, try to get the confessional booth....
author: Gina B.

description:
Properly poured Guiness by a friendly bartender is always a winner in my book.  

I also liked the atmosphere and crowd, no neon-robed hipsters or barely-21ers.  Everybody there seemed to be really chill.  It's loud, but reasonably so, and outside is better for conversation of course.

If I lived in SF, this would probably become my pub of choice.
author: Sarah C.

description: Irish Bank is a place for groups, by this I mean if you're looking for a pensive pub experience, you've messed up.  Downtown SF is notorious for bars that just feel cramped if your group is more than 5, but the inside/outside seating split works masterfully here.  Though the $10 minimum for credit cards doesn't thrill me (What is this, the stone age?), Irish Bank fits the bill if  you're searching for somewhere to be outrageous with a lot of outrageous people.
author: Michael D.

description: Great place for a pint when after a business meeting in the Financial District.  I have never had anything to eat more the the french fries.  Why because I am at an Irish pub and I am there to drink.  The staff is attentive and the people are friendly.  I will be back when in San Fran.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
FISH N CHIPS! YUMMMMMM! (Don't forget the side of curry sauce for dipping!)

Now go get yours!
author: elaine i.

description: So, I've been here 3 times. I give it three stars but I'd totally go back on the right occasion. I mean you can't give 5 stars to an Irish bar where you get spilled on while wasting away in an alley on plastic chairs . . . but there's totally a time for that kind of thing and when that time comes around . . . I will think of cruising over to Irish Bank.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I LOVE this place!  This place brings SO many memories!!! (Hang outs, random meets with strangers, birthday celebrations, dates, etc.)

Low key, private dive restaurant/bar, fun crowd during big sports finals, outdoor seating on an alley street!  

The outdoor seating is great on a nice SF day or night!  

Staff is helpful, service is fast!  Bar has tvs!  Variety of beer.  Food is priced fair, good selection of couple of Irish foodies - cabbage with corn beef hash, etc.  This place is good for groups especially outside.

This is one of my FAVE SF bars!
author: Natalie O.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars in the city.  The people are nice, the environment is very laid back, and the location is great.  It really feels like you're in Ireland (well ive never been, but i can pretend).  

I always have a good experience here...
author: Justin A.

description: Service is slow. Shepherd's pie still frozen in the center. Strange dank, musty smell... totally authentically Irish!!!
author: Mike B.

description:
Seriously? Is there a requirement in San Francisco for there to be one half ass/rude/lazy bartender/waiter at every bar? 

After the wedding we went here to have some food (as most of the people had hit their weekly quota in the drink fest the night before) and everything was going well. The food was pretty good, with special props to the chicken nachos and the blue cheese fries, and everything was going OK. about a half hour later they informed us the outside was closing. It was almost 11 and we understood. The inside was packed to the gills and we were all pooped, having just done all the wedding stuff, so we decided it was time to go to our respective sleeping rooms. 

So we asked for our check, and she tells us there are too many people to split the check. WHAT!? We've been here how long and you're deciding to tell us this now? Where was this information when we started ordering? Then you had the testicles to charge automatic gratuity. Personally I wouldn't have tipped. I'd had enough of piss poor service. Luckily some people were willing to pick up the slack due to the single check and horrible breakdown. 

It wasn't too bad of an offense, but I probably still wouldn't go back.
author: Sam H.

description:
It's a classic (not classy) place with an awesome outdoor area (heaters included). The food is typical bar food with an irish twist...did someone say cornbeef and cabbage, and the beer selection is decent. The bar itself has a fireplace (nice), and we were greeted by no shortage of peeps in santa costumes. Apparently, there were a few "parades" today - at the castro, embarcadero and hooters? We were skeptical as to the value of daisy duke santa shorts.
The BLTs were mmm mmm good.
author: Sarah T.

description: I hosted a private party in the dining room last night and it was perfect!  Stephanie was an absolute joy to work with, the service was excellent, and I heard great compliments about the food (though I was running around and too busy to try anything).  If you're looking for a cozy/fun space for around 50 people and an establishment who is amazing to work with, look no further!
author: Angie F.

description: Good beer and food, quick service, and interesting people. A good place for a pint!
author: Clint C.

description:
I was definitely not expecting to get an Irish server at The Irish Bank.

I've been here twice, once for drinks only and again for lunch. Drink prices are reasonable, they have a good selection of beers and a modest but excellent scotch selection. Not too many places carry Macallan Cask Strength. 

I didn't want one of the heavier options so I ordered chicken curry, which I felt a little apprehensive about getting at an Irish place, but it was awesome. Pretty cheap, and they made it really spicy like I asked. Also it was fast, I was able to get in and out during my lunch hour with no problem. Looking forward to trying their Irish fare!
author: Beth D.

description:
Little known fact- It wasn't the potato famine that killed all those people in Ireland. They actually starved to death while waiting for their dinner at The Irish Bank.

If you've had a few drinks, you might believe that history. If you've managed to have a few drinks at the Irish Bank, please tell me your secret! Our waitress was as elusive as a leprechaun. Everything took painfully long to arrive. And it wasn't one of those deals where they were intentionally slowing the food service so you'd order more drinks. Or if they were, they were failing to cash in on the set-up. We'd have gone for it. The flesh was willing but the spirits were unavailable.

I came for the BLT I read about on Yelp. The quality of the ingredients was good. But, while I thought that I'd like having the mayo automatically on the side, the end result was a dry sandwich. Applying mayonnaise at the table wasn't the same because it didn't give the ingredients a chance to mesh.

Boyfriend had the turkey melt. He also felt that while the individual components were good, the end result was only so-so. He suffered serious diner's remorse when he saw the great looking fish and chips ordered by the next table. I initially promised him we'd return to have it, but by the end of the meal we both knew that was unlikely to happen.

The nail in the coffin was the dessert- the caramel apple torte. The cake-like shell that held the apples and caramel sauce had fridge funk. You know how you can smell it in your mouth just as you take a bite of something? It's disgusting. But while I pretend to be discriminating, I'm actually indiscriminate and I ate almost the whole thing.

Shout out to the busboys! Busboys always show me love, God bless them. The busboys at Irish Bank were attentive, efficient, and NUMEROUS. Maybe if some of them were switched to waiting tables or cooking... just a thought.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I did not have the luck o' the Irish with me when I visited The Irish Bank & Bar during Happy Hour a few months back.  Three Chimays and four Irish Car Bombs deep, I left this quaint little alleyway pub and stumbled home.  I proceeded to throw up for a solid 4 hours after that.  Those are not the fondest of memories I have of this place, nor the $500+ bar tab that we (my 10 or so co-workers and I) managed to rack up in a few hours.

But I can say that I had a good time, all told.  Next time I just have to remember my old friend Moderation.
author: Kira K.

description: Fish and chips (sometimes I substitute the fries for a caesar salad)...and a Leffe. Perfection. :)
author: Kathleen C.

description:
This place is great for lunch if you work in the financial district. It's conveniently located (and I love that it's located in an alley). The outdoor seating is awesome if it's a nice day. In fact, the majority of the seating is outdoors. 

They have awesome cider and have traditional Irish food a well as general American Pub food. 

Great place to gather with friends.
author: Lauren F.

description: Last weekend in SF.. My pub loving partners in crime and I yelped.. say it isnt so! AND found this pub near our hotel in a little alley.. FOR a Monday night this place was packed.. lively and fun.. TONS of beer on the list.. Im an Irish cider girl.. My group apparently are english cider types .. ying and yang.. but it works.. Because they have all the ales you would want! They even grabbed the 5 from me.. AND since that was the night my 9ers whooped the Cards in my town.. I am feeling generous:-) drinks on me?? I love this pub!
author: Kimberly V.

description:
I went here for Saint Patrick's day a couple of years back and I was not prepared! It was packed full of crazy, fun, festive people! 

When you get there, you go though the cute little alley. It's great there's an outdoor patio to chill at. When I went inside, the entire bar was backed up with people all the way back to the wall. I was on a mission to get my beer so I had my girlfriend hold onto my purse and coat and I ducked underneath everyone and made my way through the crowd and ended up right at the bar! Ordered 2 beers for myself and 2 beer for my friend, ducked back down, and got out of there before anyone realized I cut in front of the entire bar. Mission accomplished! 

Spent the rest of the day chillen in the alley and starting random convos with hot young professional guys. That's what I like about the bars around the financial district area, there's never a shortage of cute white guy eye candy. Don't get me wrong, I don't discriminate against certain kinds of guys but I like finding a whole pack of them in one spot *wink*
author: Lucky N.

description:
Probably my most frequented Pub in the city due to it's extremely welcoming and friendly staff, comfort food and arguably the best pint of Guinness in the city.

A medium sized bar with plenty of seating in the main room, a more quiet function room and alleyway seating with canopies and heaters for less welcoming weather.

The menu is traditional pub fare; Bangers and Mash, Fish & Chips, Corned Beef and Cabbage, Cheesy-Chips and Curry Sauce.. a veritable feast of heart warming - although probably not good for your heart food.  I do recommend the smoked salmon and trout platter for a lighter/healthier but none the less filling option.. the Wasabi creme fresh is yum and the Zucchini soup is a win.

The bar is chock full of great beer, (both bottles and draft) and a hefty supply of whisky. My birthday treat is a 30yr Laphroaig Single.. tho it's a very high priced scotch.

On Friday nights and weekends this is a very popular hang out with financial district workers.. so expect a crush.

Saturday mornings they serve a traditional breakfast.. which when I can drag myself out of bed for is well worth it.

The Bank is renown for big parties .. ask about St.Patrick's or Bastille day for example. They also sometime will show the Football, (Soccer for the Americans).

Have to end by saying everyone who works at the bank is fantastically welcoming and friendly even at the most hectic of times. I wish more places could have such level headed and good-natured service staff.
author: Rev Michael H.

description: Cool pub with tons of good brews on tap and centrally located. Gets pretty packed around happy hour, which leads to standing around outside, because it's to hot inside, but they won't let you stand around outside with your drink, you actually  have to sit, even if there are no actual seats---so problem ensues. But if you snag a seat in the alley, it has a very brew-ha-ha feel and is tons of fun.
author: Shira O.

description:
A Yelper took me here after our shoot. To be honest, I really can't eat before, during and after a shoot. Too wired and my mine is usually still in a trance.

But it was cold outside and the place felt like it had a nice fireplace going type feel to it. 

I got the reuban and should have gotten the Irish Beef Stew or Shepherd's Pie. Next time.

The beer was good, but beer is always good before, during and after a shoot and helps the trance. ;)
author: Brandon M.

description:
I love that this place has its own little alley. And I like the fact that its patron are actually irish. I'm not a huge drinker but I like the atmosphere. It's got a decent selection of brews for decent enough prices considering its very close to union square. But it's so tucked away mostly locals will find it! 
I'd go here again!
author: Lacey C.

description: Great place to grab a drink and there's plenty of seats outside to enjoy a nice cold beer!  Fries with curry sauce, Shepherd's pie, and a huge selection of drinks!  This is an awesome sports bar too...I came here to watch the World Cup and there was a great vibe!
author: Sandy L.

description:
"Where are you taking us?" After you get past the smelly alley without throwing up from the stentch of urine, garbage, and who knows what else, you are rewarded with tables on the street and a fun, lively bar. Service was pretty good considering it was a packed Friday night. Lots of beer on tap to choose from and a full menu if you're hungry. Great for large groups. No happy hour specials, but their prices are decent.

- Mac & Cheese: okay
- Chicken Fingers: yummy, crispy, a bit salty
- Chicken Wings: crispy, seasoned and peppery
- Fries: nothing special
author: Linda C.

description:
Came here on a Saturday Night with a group to enjoy some guiness. 

The crowd, the booze was good. But the place was not. 

There is a steaming water pipe right next to one of the tables that burned my hand. Its like totally out in the public and next to the chair that I was sitting at. At first I thought I was sitting next to a heater and I didnt think much of it. Turns out it was HEAT emitting from the freakin pipe. Freaking A. 

I told the bouncer Zack as we walked out what happened since I knew him from high school.  He said he would tell someone but I think I will stay away until they mortar it--I felt like I was in the 1800's, in a building with no safety code or something. terrible.
author: Amy S.

description: Natatandaan ko nung bata pa ako, lagi kaming pumupunta dito. Nag-iinuman, nagsasayawan. Pero sandali, hindi pala nung bata ako kasi illegal un diba? Tama nung bente-uno na ako! Pero ang natatandaan ko sa lugar na ito, ay lagi silang puno ng mga tao. Ok lang naman. Popular na lugar pero sakin 3 stars lang sila. Walang masyadong espesyal sa lugar na ito. Okay lang.
author: J C.

description:
Basically, the Irish Bank is the place to go if you want to hit up a popular happy hour spot with outside tables.  

Sit outside, chill out, and order two beers at a time (and don't worry about how often the waitress comes).  

The food's pretty good; I like the curry fries.

If you go expecting a high-touch, reasonably priced place, you will be disappointed.  If you go looking for a crowded, non-dressy but trendy place to have a beer. You'll have a good time.  

Things to remember- the bartenders are Irish- don't ask about the red wine (or drink it).  Order a Smitticks or a shot of Powers.

Good: Outside Seating; Great Scotch Selection; Actual Irish Bartenders
The Neutral: Food is standard Pub Food
The bad: Expensive, so-so service
author: Bob R.

description: Always good times at the Irish Bank! One of the most notable watering holes in the financial district of San Francisco. Any given day around 5pm you'll find bankers, asset managers, advisors, and the like loosening their ties and double fisting two glasses of Stella chased with a shot of Jager.
author: Stephen Y.

description: For pub grub it's pretty good, for beer selection and the lilt of the Irish servers and bartenders it's outstanding!  Gotta love sitting in the confessional to the right of the bar with friends and many beers and the outdoor seating (while neither fancy nor a beautiful setting) adds to the experience.
author: Sara A.

description:
I've only ever eaten outside, because the inside is for 21+ only, but I love this place.

The menu isn't huge (and if you aren't drinking beer there isn't much else- but I don't see why you could come to the Irish Bank and not have beer) but the food is great. Comfort food to a tee- Shepard's pie, Irish Beef stew, Rueben sandwiches.... their food is delicious, and it's always what you're in the mood for.

Not to mention that this place is in an awning-covered alley- not what you'd expect at all, but really cool. (there are outdoor heaters but it can still get a little cold- but hey, that's just san francisco)

Try the Irish Bank!
author: ali r.

description:
I came here about 2-3 years ago when I use to work nearby. So today I called my friend and said I had a craving for Shepherd's Pie and he suggested this place. He's like the best I've had so far and I agreed. :D this was at like 2:30 and I was drooling up until he picked me up at 5.

So we get there, waited in the cold for about 10 minutes before we had a waitress come show us the menus. We ordered ginger ale first and let me tell you, the one I got was totally watered down. It looked like carbonated water LOL.

Homemade Macaroni and Cheese 
- it was very good. Cheesy goodness, although I think it's slightly watery compared to the standard mac n cheese that's typically thick and creamy. But it was still good. 

The Bangers
- it comes with Heinz baked beans and your choice of a scoop of mashed potatoes or fries. I picked mashed potatoes. YUMMY! I asked the waitress to put it under the broiler to crisp the mashed potatoes a bit. It was delish. The bangers? The best part of the dish. I love bangers, they're kind of like bratwursts but the exterior is crispy. It's so juicy.

Shepherd's Pie
- ground beef mixed with vegetables and topped with mashed potatoes and put under the broiler to crisp it up. It was so good, unfortunately I don't eat beef anymore but I do recall it being extremely delicious. A MUST to try on the menu. 

Chocolate Lava Cake
- I've had better at Roy's Restaurant on Mission St. This lava cake looked like they just put some chocolate ganache on the plate and slapped a warm chocolate cupcake on it (which by the way, for some reason the cake was split already on the side) and served with two scoops of Vanilla ice cream in a side dish. The warm ganache wasn't even coming out from the middle it was on the bottom haha. Not even suppose to be like that.

Overall I enjoyed my dinner with my friend. I'd go back again *thumps up*
author: Linda X.

description: If you are stranded in this godforsaken neighborhood and need a beer, and maybe some deep fried fish, this is your safe haven.
author: Helena L.

description: I came here for a beer, and definitely enjoyed the Leffe they had on tap!  The inside is very yellow-lit and a bit depressing, but the weather was good, and the outside tables were perfect!
author: Katie M.

description: Like Mark Lane, Like that there's Heat Lamps, Like the Long Tables, Like the Small Pub Room, Like the Drinks, Like the prices: $5 to $16, Like the Fries with Vinegar, Like the Waitress, Uber Dislike the bland Fish and Chips I ate on a a Friday night happy-hour at the soulful Irish pub tucked away in a Financial District alley. I think the Leprechaun hiding inside might have prepared it. I had to overdose on Tums, thanks.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Handed the chap a 20 bill, and got back 15. Walked in to a noisy bar and got the bartender's attention. Ordered a glass of wine. Here's where the stars get lost: a glass of wine is 6 ounces and made of blown glass, lead crystal, or hock glass. The glass this was poured in was 3 ounces AT MOST, and disposable. Also, they charged an exorbitant amount for it ($6) and the wine wasn't very good either, but I suppose that's normal for this sort of pub. 

The crowd's where this joint holds its own. People are EXTREMELY friendly. I chatted up almost everyone, which is normal, but getting everyone to respond in a friendly manner is not. No one was in a bad mood, everyone I talked to was a great conversationalist. 

They don't serve food, drinks are overpriced and underserved, but the crowd is grand.
author: Hasan D.

description:
When I walked into The Irish Bank with four friends, I felt like I was walking into another English/Irish/Scottish ex-pat pub (yea, they all resemble each other, deal with it).  When I sat down with said friends, I started to feel like I was in a nut house.  First, a stumble-drunk, middle-aged Mexican dude saunters over to our table and immediately starts on a nearly incomprehensible tirade about types of beer commonly consumed on the premises by different nationalities.  No one of my party speaks a lick of... anything but English as far as I know, certainly no Spanish to speak of, so I'm left to translate his Spunglish into coherent words and phrases as best I can and respond accordingly.  He brings over menus and continues, only because my friends are finding him more entertaining than awkward.  When the balance shifts in the favor of "ok drunkie, take a hike," I politely shoo him away.  He returns to his post, the edge of the bar by a cash register, where I'd seen him out of the corner of my eye on the way in.  He squats a little, tips a standing beer on the chest-high counter beside him toward his mouth, and suckles away without the bottom of the bottle leaving the counter's surface.

At this point, about 5 minutes since we entered the building, this is the only attention our table has received.  It would have probably been a more enjoyable drinking/dining experience had it remained that way.  Unfortunately for us, an unabashedly impatient, ponytailed shrew bellies up to the booth next, soon showing **discernible aggravation** at our having decided to order beverages and food together, rather than running off a list of one first, then the other.  Each subsequent visit from her to our table is like an angry nun in a reading room, rearing a whipping stick as she passes the "misbehavers" whose voices are raised too high for her liking.  Everyone clams up and hopes she doesn't bite one of us, then shoulders decompress as she walks away.

Looks of disbelief, confusion and hilarity are exchanged among us following each character's departure from the table.  The $6 pints are tasting more and more expensive.

It suddenly occurs to me that there is a distinct possibly that the first of the two extreme threats to this business' return customer factor **works** for the establishment, but is apparently only gracing our table with his presence, and only when the spirit moves him to wobble our way for another soliloquy in his own private language.  I personally leave my table to inform one of the uniformed, undrunk waitstaff that his double-dipso coworker by the bar should probably call a cab.  Moments later, after assuring me he'd "take care of it," he's engaged in jovial, half-spanish/half drunk-ass Spanish conversation with him, which lasts for the duration of our meal.

The Irish Bank broke nearly every rule in my hospitality industry book, on top of serving utter shit for food (fresh from the freezer Ore-Ida fries and Dinty Moore Stew covered in just-add-water mashed potatoes in a re-purposed crème brûlée dish masquerading as a "Shepherd's Pie") and charged us $50 to do it.  Laid back and slacking off are not synonymous.  If you were going for that sardonic, "I don't give a fuck" kind of aesthetic we see in Guy Ritchie movies, you missed.  Those places have character.  You're an overpriced frat trap.
author: Danny N.

description: Cool place.  Fodd not so good but come for the beer and the outdoor seating in the alley next door.  Looking forward to coming back.  Be a good place to drink some breakfast  beers and watch World Cup.
author: Jim H.

description:
I come here often just because it's in my neighborhood and in the summer time there is nothing really better than sitting outside and drinking beer with friends at nighttime. 

I really do come here for the blueberry cosmos, though, my favorite time being happy hour because it's therapeutic. I easily drink about 5 or 6 of these. Unfortunately $9 bucks a pop, they're not wallet-friendly and I don't know how drunk I am until I walk home and all of a sudden it hits me.

Good beer selection, although could be better for a pub/Irish bar thing... decent pub fare; my favorites is the Shepherd Pie (really good, trust me on this). Fish & chips = ok, greasy and heavy; not my fav, and not very good service. I come here for an excuse to drink outside year-round.
author: Y K.

description:
Great place to grab a brew or get something to eat.  Shepard pie and irish stew was pretty good.

Bleu Cheese Fries are off the ROCKER!

Kinda pricey for food but they have a great selection of drinks.  Place is hard to get a seat at so go early.  Wait staff isn't that great but pretty on par with any bar.

Great place
author: Eddie C.

description: i had the corned beef and cabbage here and it was not very good. i expected a signature default irish dish to be decent at a place called irish bank. it comes with mashed potatoes and a section of cabbage uncut. the corned beef was dry and overcooked.
author: Alex H.

description:
OK, although I have given the Irish Bank 5 stars, I must be honest, I have not tried everything the restaurant has to offer. Their hamburger is ok, typical pub fair...HOWEVER, their fish & chips, LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! They set the bar with their fish & chips and now everywhere I go, I judge the fish & chips based upon the Irish Bank's. 

Their bartenders rock! The best Bloody Mary I ever had, was at the Irish Bank. They do vary pending upon whom is bartending, but they do not get it wrong. If ever you are craving Liquid Lunch, I recommend trying their bloody mary. The Irish Bank also sets the bar with this one.
author: Robert A.

description:
I have so many AMAZING memories from this spot.
From St. Patrick's Day to Bastille Day to just a bad day after work, the Irish Bank has never let me down.
You can come here after work and grab a beer and shepherd's pie or dance in the alley all night on major drinking holidays. Great balance of a kick back drinking spot and hardcore party time.
author: Kathleen E.

description: Hidden out of the way place near Union Square.  We were staying at the Hotel Triton right next door, so it was an easy place to stop in.
author: Dave C.

description: This place is awesome. The perfect spot for dinner and drinks after a long day at work.  The outdoor seating is amazing, and it has the perfect combo of casual and classy. True pub atmosphere, and the fish and chips are amazing!
author: Bridget B.

description: fun lil spot for drinks on the "patio"-- i.e. the alley out back. chill crowd and cheaper than rickhouse.
author: Jenna D.

description: One more star for the Irish Breakfast.  Don't get the mac n cheese or the shepherd's pie.  The Irish Breakfast is where it's at, especially if you're hungover.
author: Ken L.

description: Absolutely amazing!!! Best Irish spot in town if you have ever been it'll let you reminisce if not it'll transport you to ireland for sure!!
author: Nick D.

description: This is an awesome place to meet up with great company, enjoy delicious food and have drinks. Their Shepherd's Pie is quite tasty. It was my first experience with Shepherd's Pie(heavy) and it definitely will not be my last. Recently I've had tried their Bank Burger and was pleasantly surprised. That burger was outstanding!
