The burger was grilled just right and the bread they used is hard to describe but pretty much made the whole burger perfect.Their blue cheese fries are sinful good. This place has a real chill atmosphere, the crowd is diverse and everyone is out for a good time.
author: Caroline N.

description:
CUH-REE FRIES! CUH-REE FRIES! 

Curry fries. That alone warrants 5 out of 5 stars. First of all, the fries are obnoxiously big, measuring approximately 1" in width, and a good 4" in length. Size matters, know this. They throw a hearty helping into a decent sized basket - and there in the middle is where you find the magic. The curry. Dip your fries in, take a deep breath, and bite down. You will be content with life. 

This place also introduced me to the Shepperd's Pie (beef), of which I cannot fail to mention. It's steaming hot and extremely delish. 

The inside of the bar can get quite crowded, but don't fret! There's a large patio seating area with picnic benches that will comfortably fit a decent crowd of good timers.

CUH-REE FRIES!
author: Ro D.

description:
So, I came here on a Tuesday afternoon after attending a workshop on the recommendation of my friend Xis.  I really wanted to catch the Sharks game because they were playing the Bruins, which was one of the biggest games of the year.

I strolled down Bush trying to find this place, totally not paying attention to the signage that clearly marked it's location.  

I parked myself at the bar and asked the sweet bartender, Mary, if she could flip one of two TVs to the Sharks game.  "I suppose I could," she responded in her delicate Irish accented voice.  She served me up a Manger's, even though I ordered a Boddington's, and I patiently waited through the replay of the previous night's match between the Devils and the Rangers and watching Liverpool come back from a 2 goal deficit, and downed the Manger's and ordered a Boddington's.

The Sharks and the Bruins faced off in what turned out to be a fast-paced, yet bruising game.  Several pints later, the Sharks came out victorious 5 to 2.  I was the only one really following the Sharks game, but as I view it, everyone else missed out.  

I actually saw an acquaintance there and had a beer and a chat with him before I had to scurry off to dinner with the family.

Good bar.  If i'm ever in the area again, I'll be sure to have a pint or two here.
author: Gene A.

description: Good place to laugh and drink.  I can't recall eating here but I might have!  I like the woods floors and the brick walls.  It feels as a pub should be.  It can be a little tight inside but hey, you might make a friend while sloshing your pint around.  Drink up!
author: Mike B.

description:
The Irish Bank?!?? More like The Irish BLAND!!!! 

Wild Field Greens Salad?!?? More like MILD Field Greens Salad!!!! 

Irish Beef Stew?!?? More like Irish Beef BORING!!!! (I couldn't think of a witty word substitute for this one...)

The salad consisted of wilted greens on the brown side, blue cheese that tasted like dirty dishwater and soft, almost chewy, walnuts.

The boiled whole potato placed on top of this dish of tasteless brown-colored liquid thingy they tried to pass off as "Beef" "Stew" was the "most" "flavorful" thing about it.

For pub food on the pricey side (around $10-20+ a person), I should experience some sort of flavor explosion in my mouth. Or at the very least a semi-good time.

Instead, I faced the gastronomic equivalent of sitting through Ben Stein's recital of The Compleat and Unabridged History and Genesis of Canadian Barley.

In half-speed. 

While drinking watered-down decaffeinated coffee.

And wearing J. Crew chinos.
author: Joshua L.

description:
Back when I was in college, I dated an Irish boy who lived in an Irish neighborhood in the Bronx.  

Woodlawn was one of those insular immigrant neighborhoods where the only way to get an apartment was by word of mouth (and only if you had an Irish last name).  My last name, despite what most would assume since it starts with a "Mc," is Scottish.  EVERYONE in Woodlawn asked me why I had an Irish first name and a Scottish last name.

"You LOOK Scottish," they'd say suspiciously.

"I'm half Irish & half Scottish - on BOTH sides," I'd tell them.  "I'm from the West Coast."  For some reason, being from the West Coast explained EVERYTHING.

In Woodlawn, you could shop the main street and never know that you were in the U.S.:
- The grocery store was fully stocked with Irish and some English products
- The shopkeepers' Irish accents were often almost too thick for my ears to splice through to recognize the English
- The sidewalks were filled with people who looked like doppelgangers of my uncles in Maine, my great aunts in Boston, and the distant relations who sent my family a Christmas card from Galway every year
- The most popular place to eat was The Snug which served dishes like shepherd's pie and beef stew, and for breakfast, fried eggs with Irish bacon. And beer. Lots and lots of beer.  You could spend all day there, if you were so inclined.

The Irish Bank is quite possibly The Snug's twin sister who took a train out West and is now living the high life in San Francisco's Financial District.  While she's hobnobbing with lawyers and bankers and management consultants, deep down, she's still just an Irish gal from the Bronx.

The dark wood and worn wooden furniture is the same (albeit a bit cleaner).  The creaky wood floors make the same sound.  The moderately friendly (but not disingenuously or effusively so) bartenders pour a good pint.  The waitstaff is attentive and occasionally chatty, but more often than not, straight business.  It can sometimes take what seems like FOREVER to get your food.  The condiment bottles are a teeny bit greasy/grimy but not gross - just used FREQUENTLY. The prices are reasonable and the portions are hearty.  The shepherd's pie is perhaps IDENTICAL in look, flavor and smell.  I think they even use the EXACT same dish to serve it in.

I'm sure Woodlawn has changed since the days when I'd study at a little table in The Snug, sipping a pint and eating shepherd's pie while the waitress asked me about how my classes were going.  Not only, as the saying goes, can you not go home again, but you also can't go back to your favorite haunts and not expect them to have evolved.  At the Irish Bank, I can at least descend back in time - for a little while.
author: Alannah T.

description:
Anything with Irish in the name should encourage heavy drinking and raucous behavior. I know this because this is what I encounter at MOST of the Irish pubs I enter. Not this one. 

This place has more of a German beer garden feel than Irish pub feel as a good majority of their seating is at large tables outside. This should be encouraging since my experience in German beer gardens is, also, centered around heavy drinking and raucous behavior. Nope, not here.

Here you can only heavily drink if you can afford to because a Guinness will run you $6 (there are no happy hour specials), and the raucous behavior consists of, wait for it......... standing on the sidewalk that lines the backside of the tables. They have a team out back who will yell at you should you stand on the sidewalk, so don't get too wild and crazy!! 

The food is pretty bland and on the pricey side for pub grub. I guess they have to recoup the cost of hiring all of the gatekeepers out back, though I think they ought to reallocate some of the funds to a few more servers because finding one to order food or a drink is near impossible. 

In short, this is your typical FiDi watering hole. Overpriced and unforgiving to people who actually want to drink and don't have six figure incomes.
author: Drue C.

description:
Mexican food at an Irish pub?? Si, senor!

Don't get me wrong, all the pub grub at the Irish Bank is absolutely stellar (I personally have a weakness for the bangers and mash), but the nachos were a decided surprise. I think I could safely recommend anything off the menu. 

But while this place is great for grabbing a meal with a friend, it's even better for groups. Tucked neatly in an alley off Bush Street, the large tables and ample seating make it perfect for late night philosophical brawls over Smithwick's or Guinness.
author: Chris P.

description:
I've been spending a lot of time here recently. Why? I don't know why. It's not terribly suited for me...

1. Their veggie burger is just so-so. And they have nothing else I can eat because Irish people like their meat (see: http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-liberties-bar-and-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:O5W7xT-06SCV3mRPm6xGRw).

2. I've recently learned that Guinness may not be vegan. As insane as that sounds, I googled it and found out that a LOT of beers may not actually be vegan. Panicked, I decided to ignore this fact and just stop drinking Guinness. LEAVE ME ALONE! It's hard enough being me! So I have to drink whiskey here instead (because it's an Irish bar -- DUH!), which is expensive. Argh.

3. The great appeal of the Irish Bank's ambiance is sitting outside in the alley. Which is not a good idea for me times TWO because, 3a.) I've been struggling with quitting smoking for months now and, 3b.) it's downtown in the middle of lots of tall buildings and I have a death-by-earthquake/being-buried-alive fixation (see: http://www.yelp.com/biz/mr-smiths-san-francisco#hrid:g2nra86tXx-7riu5idsYng).

Something continuously brings me back to the Irish Bank, however. Perhaps it's my lovable Irish guy friend and drinking buddy, who once told me that the Irish Bank was the place to meet one of those few-and-far-between "good" Irish men. My buddy who is from Dublin, and has an illustrious past with drugs and alcohol, and the IRA, and such things of legend.

Hmm...

Don't ask me. Don't ask me how, or why, HE would know. I've been trying to figure that statement out for a while now. 

Just like don't ask me if my beer is vegan. Seriously.
author: Lisa T.

description:
nice irish bar, get there when it is not crowded. 
not super great food, but hey! it's and Irish bar!
author: ric n.

description:
"Wait, were you there?"

This was the answer I got when I turned around just now to ask my now one year older birthday co-worker what the name of this place was. Yes, Drunky Magoo, I was there and happy birthday.

A gang of drunkees came here last night after throwing quite a few back at Azul's happy hour. It was my first time here and on the whole, I liked it. It was a charming little joint with fun photos on the wall. My fave was of Queen Elizabeth in a McDonald's outfit. It's nice to see she is a woman of the peoples. 

I also liked that we came in and totally took over the place (including said bday girl noshing off of someones plate who wasn't even in our party) and nobody seemed to mind. The service was prompt and had a sense of humor about the drunken state of affairs and that is always nice when you are ripped by 9pm on a Thursday night. Ahhh, the life of yelpers.

As for the food, i have to deduct a hefty few points for the mac n cheese. Yuck! This thing tasted like what I imagine glue or paste might taste like. Bland, boring and just kinda there, which was disappointing since it looked promising. I also ordered the Reuben and it was okay, but i think the thing to order here is something like fish n chips or a banger or more traditional pub fare. Those dishes looked tasty.

Over all, it was a cool little place down an alley and usually that's where the best times are found. Just ask Hugh Grant.
author: Stephy S.

description:
I really like this place, its close to my house and easy.

The food is ok, the bartenders are really nice and the environment its great!
best day are friday afternoon!
author: Jennifer m.

description: They get a whopping huge 2 stars because I like some of the items on the menu and used to actually have a decent experience eating there.  As of today, not anymore.  Our waitress was evasive about answering the question 'what brand of cola do you have' and insisted it was 'just cola'.  OK, no big deal, maybe it's RC or some generic brand they're ashamed to admit to - or perhaps she's too new to know.  Whatever, we brushed that off and ordered our food anyway.  The problem came when we were finished and waited far far too long for our ticket.  I tried to get the waitress' attention a few times, but she just bounced around taking more and more orders and dashing back into the bar.  When I finally got her attention and asked for the ticket, she copped an attitude.  She said 'we're really busy and there's a billion of YOU GUYS and only a few of US'  Um, wow, that was a crappy way for her to handle it.  She had another woman bring our ticket, a lady in a purple dress.  I'm not sure if this lady is the hostess, manager, owner, etc, but she acts like she's queen of sheeba, so I figured she must be one of the higher ups.  When I noticed we'd been overcharged, I told the queen-of-sheeba gal about it and she got flustered.  Then, a nice man in a black apron intercepted and said he'd take care of it.  I asked him if the bill could be processed quickly because we'd already waited a long time just to get the bill.  He responded positively and apologetically (which, by the way management, this is the  appropriate way to respond when a customer is dissatisfied at the slow service your staff has provided).  He was good, but ms. queen-of-sheeba had to jump into it with a snotty tone and declare 'We're really busy!!' I told her 'I get that but at least' ....nevermind what I was saying because she walked off in a mighty huff.  She brushed by me a few moments later with an angry glare.  If she is on the management team they should really do something about it because this kind of attitude sets a bad example for the service staff.
author: Leslie F.

description:
I'm kicking myself for not checking to see if there's an ATM here, just for the sake of irony.

There are, however, all the trappings of a great Irish bar*. I think I even heard traces of a northern Irish accent in our first server's voice. And they make a good burger, about 1/4 lb, which as far as I'm concerned is about the right size for a burger, being that I'm really against the whole huge burger trend going on these days both from an epicurean and a public health standpoint. Ask me what I think of run on sentences some time.

The fries are crisp and delicious too. 

The kitchen was uncommonly fast; This was pretty early on a Wednesday night though and I'd expect to wait longer when its busier. Our server was a little curt but brought everything quickly and correctly. 

I'm trying to reserve 5 star reviews for places that completely floor me, and the Irish Bank seems just like any other pub, though it's one with fast attentive service and really good food. Actually, I am a little completely floored, now that I think about it.

*There were no drunken brawls. I'm willing to overlook this.
author: matthew r.

description:
My friend and I were in SF for a weekend staying at my brothers house in North Beach - we ended up walking to union square for shopping and on our way back we were ready for some beer and food...

They have a huge beer selection! This is a major plus for me. The bartenders are really nice. The outdoor seating was way to crowded so we ended up sitting at the bar. 

It has a good mix of people for the financial district. Walking down the alley to get to the restaurant kind of threw us off - we were not sure what to expect - but it is worth the trip down the alley..
author: Emily W.

description: It's located at the end of a kind of sketchy looking alleyway, and there weren't that many seats inside. They do have outside seating though (I think...or at least a lot of tables directly outside). It seems to just be your standard bar, though it was pretty clean when we went.
author: Melody L.

description:
After a pretty rough (but fun) Halloween night, I was feeling pretty hung over and in desperate need of greasy bar food and a little hair of the dog. After wandering around Embarcadero for an hour trying to find a place that was open on Sunday for lunch. Luckily Yelp on my iPhone pointed me to The Irish Bank. 

I'd heard about this place, and seen it packed with people for happy hour. I typically avoid places like this as they're usually overrated, boy was I wrong.

Sat down, and almost immediately a very cheerful server asked me what I wanted to drink. A  Langunitas IPA was delivered a few minutes later and definitely hit the spot. I placed my order of fish and chips hoping for the best, but expecting a soggy mess. Not too long afterwards I was totally shocked by what was delivered. A steaming plate piled high with 2 pieces of uber crispy fish, and a mound of perfectly cooked fries. With malt vinegar on the table, I was ready to dig in. The fish was fresh and thick...almost too thick for my taste...but it was delicious. I was a bit worried about my stomach handling all of the food, but I couldn't stop eating. By far the best fish and chips i've had outside of London (the Pheasant outside Heathrow is still my all time favorite).

The server was very attentive, and the atmosphere was great. I still think happy hour / dinner might be a bit overwhelming but I might have to brave it next time I have a craving for F&C.
author: William W.

description:
I didn't used to have fond memories of The Irish Bank, but my view of this place changed recently.  

Sometimes, you meet people who are losers, who contribute very little to society.

But, other times, someone special enters your life.  You're not sure what exactly you are supposed to learn from them, but you know that being around them makes you a little bit better.  A little bit less of an insecure/overconfident walking contradiction and a little more grounded with a better sense of self. 

If this fact is realized over chugging Irish Car Bombs to win a fictional title with no monetary reward, even better.
author: Janney B.

description:
Years ago, back in my college days, I came here for a happy hour.  I was sporting my fake ID (and my name was Dallas for three years, yeah I'm not proud of that).  A 30+ year old professional woman came up to me and started flirting with me.  I was 19 -- I had no idea how to respond to this.  The term "cougar" had not entered the vernacular at this point.

Anyway, once she found out how old I was, she reached down and grabbed my crotch.  I was a bit taken aback, and she said she "just wanted to make sure my balls had dropped."  She was a lovely lady.  I wonder whatever came of her.

The beers here are pretty good...a nice selection of import draft beers.  $5 for a pint, but it's a nice pour.  A star for letting you drink outside.  Reminds me of Maiden Lane and Belden Place...what is it with foreign alleys in this city?
author: Geoff K.

description:
It's a bar in the FiDi that is dark and woody.  

It's cold as all hell outside but props for trying to help that with heat lamps.

The waitstaff is random and not uber-friendly but I don't think they have a happy cheery policy on service.  

It's weird how much the suits and pencil skirts clash with this place yet it's full of them.
author: Jay H.

description: Completely casual enviorment and a good place for boys to go and watch a game. I appreciate an ice cold stella when seated in the confessional style private booth between the bar & resturaunt area.  Food service is terribly slow but I keep going back for the home town appeal.
author: Hannah A.

description: My friend and I decided to get dinner today after she got off work.  She had heard of this place from coworkers and wanted to try it.  Being 20 we had to eat outside and split the potato skins and fish and chips.  The potato skins were good but the fish and chips were...weird.  No flavor and the fish was hard. gross.  We sent it back and the waiter apologized and brought us some chicken nachos which were pretty good.  All the food came out really fast which was nice.  After seeing other reviews saying the fish and chips are good I might have to try them again another day.  I liked the whole alleyway atmosphere.  As it got darker they lowered some sun shades and turned on the lights which made it a little warmer.  I will definitely come back!
author: Fiona M.

description:
L-O-V-E The Irish Bank.  

If you aren't smitten once you stroll down the quaint alleyway on the way in, then just leave now.  You don't deserve The Irish Bank.  I love walking in here and heading straight to the back.  May the Gods smile upon you if you get the nook booth.  You are one lucky bastard.  But even if you get a normal table in the back your stoked.  Depending on the weather also try outside.  They do have heating lights out there so it doesn't get too bad.  And if it does, DRINK UP and get warm.  Inside is better for 2-5 people but if you come with a larger group odds are you will only find space out on the patio.

They have Magners on tap here, which I love.  Can't get enough hard cider personally.  But the thing that sets The Irish Bank apart from many other pubs is their food.  Fish-n-Chips to die for.  Just ask Tiffany Y.  She knows I know my ish when it comes to a good Fish-n-Chips :)  Big steak fries, none of those puny over cooked Mickey-Dees fries here folks.  If you like Bleu Cheese (and by like I mean absolutely effing love) then do yourself a favor and order the Bleu Cheese fries.  Superbly bleu.  They also have astounding Mac-n-Cheese.  Just like mom used to make (especially if your mom was a drunk irsh woman generous with the heavy cream and cheese and didn't care that you might die from a heart attack at 30).

Do yourself a favor and go here.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
The staff here are always without fail really nice. 

Reasonable prices and decent (not fantastic) food for lunch. Personally I don't like sitting outside in that alley. I find it damp and distasteful. But the Irish Bank is super cute and the interior feels like a cozy pleasant place.

They have great chicken wings, but when I asked where they came from he told me Del Monte. So they are great wings from chicken hell. But delish.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
Situated in an alley, The Irish Bank has an authentic old world charm that is hard to find elsewhere.  I like to haunt it early on Fridays before the FiDi crowd arrives and the Euros run for cover.  

They have Guinness, Boddington's and Leffe on tap, and unique imported ales for the connoisseur.   

Beers and Fernet all around, please!
author: Nicole G.

description:
If its a great day, and you are feeling more of a nicely dressed financial district kind of vibe, i highly recommend coming here for a drink and enjoying the out door alley for drinking.  You aren't going to get the biker bar, seedy, charming qualities of drinking outside at Zeitgeist, but the Irish Bank is especially great if you want to stay local after work.  We have had many a going away party here because the space is really good for groups.

I remember quite fondly a St. Patrick's day extravaganza that started here after work.  I experienced my very first Irish Car Bombs (i know thats not PC, but its the only thing i can think to call them).  They were beautifully poured and me and my drinking companion quickly ordered another.  You never forget your first.  Our evening ended up with us seeing Flogging Molly at the Warfield, continuing the Irish theme of the night. The drinks at the Irish bank helped us in our good time.

I also remember a rainy evening last Christmas time, when hundreds of drunken, debacherous Santa Claus' and Zombies made their way to a tarped alley.  We took over the bar and the alley, and i was super thankful for the tarp, cuz we would have been spilling out of the bar and probably would have ended in some trampled Santas.  They were very accommodating with the large back room as well, and all of the local Irish fellows must have just thought we were plain nuts.

I guess to make a long story short....memorable days and evenings spent here make for the desire to come back here whenever invited.
author: Lauren F.

description:
OK; this is from the horse's mouth....I'm Irish. This is a great Irish bar and the perfect pairing of food and drink to have here at Happy Hour is "Bangers and Mash (with Baked Beans)" and a "Pint of Guinness". This pairing not only tastes good but it is the perfect combination to line your stomach from the craziness that will follow a happy hour gathering at this location.

I celebrated my 21st birthday here a long time ago and I can still taste the "flaming blue Lamborghini"  LOL

Definitely worth checking this place out...
author: Bryan B.

description:
Huge alley way with awning, plenty of seating & outdoor heaters (though they can be testy) 

Loud, boisterous crowd inside & out.  

Came here with a big group of friends & we snagged the 2 big tables outside as we had a huge group of about 20.  Stellas on tap $5.50, Heif $5.50, Bud light $4.50.  Quickly ordered rounds of drinks for everyone and grabbed our menus.  

I had the fish & chips $11.50 - came with 3 large pieces of perfectly deep fried cod & wonderfully cooked french fries.  The cod was nice & tender.  The meal definitely hit the spot.  

My girlfriend had the hamburger with cheddar -$9  and it was huge.  The bun was very good & you build your own burger, with the tomatoe, lettuce, onions coming on the side.  

The Mac & cheese $9, was very thick, but tasteless.  We had to add lots of salt to it.  

Cheddar Fries - $8 huge plate of thick steak fries with melted cheddar cheese on top.

No happy hour.  =( boo, we asked if they had happy hour and our answer was "we don't have happy hour, but on Thursdays between this time & this time, it's $1 off Spinach"  WTF?!

 And service was slow on the food but fast on the drinks.  Our waiter was not very friendly either. so got docked a star.  but would come back here again for the fish & chip/burger & hanging out in the alley with friends.
author: Lulu C.

description:
This dark, side-alley nook, with its well-worn wood floors and faintly glowing bottles of single malt, might induce you to order your Guinness with a bit o' brogue.  Weekdays, it tends to be crowded with downtown financial types, but at night, Irish Bank is a mixed bag of beer, ale and whiskey lovers of all stripes.  Oh my.

The fish-and-chips are pretty tasty.  Don't look for too much from the fries and slaw, but enjoy the large hunks of hake or Alaskan cod, which are fried way crisp.  If you must, try the burger, it'll go down well with your Harp.
author: Yve F.

description: Great place to relax in between neighborhoods. This place sits just outside  of Chinatown and about 3 blocks from union square. The bar has outside seating which is in between two buildings. Beer is good. I've tried their yellow curry and it was good. Also it has nice clean bathrooms. Always a plus in the City!
author: April L.

description:
You turn a corner into an alley and It's like you've walked into a time machine ~ and stepped into a parallel Ireland (without the jet lag).   

Hardwood floors, brick walls, cozy lighting, Guinness adverts, and Gaelic signs.   They even turned an ol' wooden confession booth (so I'm told) into a dining box...back room is the main dining area.  Bonus ~ they have Xlerator dryers that dry your hands in a jiff. You can see the power as it makes the skin on your hands flatten with its turbo blow. 

Food-wise, my ol' fav. has been the mixed field greens salad (with pear, walnuts, blue cheese) and a huge basket of thick cut fries.  I've also had their Banger (see menu) and it was good.  I think they must've had an off night when I tried their fish & chips..but I'm willing to try again.
author: Cathy K.

description:
"A man takes a drink; the drink takes a drink; the drink takes the man."  Well that pretty much describes everytime I have been to the wonderful land that is the Irish Bank.  

I love this place for after work/work functions.  Good beers, good people, good scotch, good god this place is pleasant.  Everytime I go there I have a great time.  The bartenders are quick, the staff are friendly and even the bouncer seem to be not that menacing.  I have never been more comfortable sitting outside in a dingy alley way throwing back Single Malt scotch intermixed with the occasional Jager bomb.  And hey if you have a few to many and need some pub food to soak it all up with, well have no fear ya heat on, they serve up a varity of tasty vitles.

If your in the area I would definatly recommed checking this place out.
author: Carter H.

description: Casual, low-key, carefree drinking and dining close to Union Square.  In the dim lighting, seated outdoor in the alley, you could almost imagine yourself transported to Italy or Spain... maybe even Ireland?  Stick to the traditional dishes though.  Translation: steer clear of the chicken curry.  Way too sweet.  You probably wouldn't order Bangers at a Chinese restaurant.  So why risk chicken curry at an Irish one?  :)
author: Kristen S.

description: I love Irish Bank, what is there not to love! Magners, Outdoor seating, nice staff, hot bartenders, and good food. I'm happy :)
author: Karen T.

description:
Great place for dinner and drinks. Good prices, cool atmosphere, and good for groups.

Outdoor seating great for nice nights.
author: Eddy N.

description:
I've had hit or miss experiences at the Irish Bank over the years.  I've been coming here since the days when the restaurant was called the Bank of Ireland.  (They had to change the name because they got in trouble with the real BOI.) 

HITS:
1. Scoring a table outside on a balmy evening.
2. Scoring the table for two inside the confessional.
3. The delicious and spicy bloody mary the bartender made for me this past Sunday afternoon. (She even asked me whether it was for a hangover!!! No, it wasn't.)

MISSES:
1. How crowded this place gets.
2. Dinner two weeks ago. I had the Irish Stew. Never again.
3. The time, many moons ago, when they had two different prices posted for the bangers and mash. Of course, they charged me the higher price even though I ordered because I saw the lower price on the sign on Bush St. Stupid waitress needed to learn a thing or two about customer service.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: We literally had an hour to get in & out.  It was packed on a Wednesday night, but we made our way past the noisily crowded bar & into the back room.  Sat our cabooses right next to the warming fire.  I was craving a burger & got me one - big with two fat pale buns.  It came with a boatload of generous sized (that's what I'm talkin' about!) fries, which I slathered on with ketchup. Service was extraordinarily quick & efficient.  They took our orders with lightning speed, brought the food, checked up on us, cleared our table, and gave us the check.  I didn't feel rushed tho  - they just came when we needed them.  Our tummies full, we headed out for our next thang.  A definite mainstay for quick pubby food.
author: Peg S.

description: A real pub. We stopped in for a pint and ended up staying for dinner. The Banger with mash was delicious and done to perfection. The prices are down to earth and the lengthy food and drink selection is great.
author: Aaron S.

description: While my straight FiDi and British-born friends seem to enjoy this bar, I recommend against taking your gay boyfriend here on a night out. The two of you might fnd yourselves uncomfortably drinking beer and being jostled out of the way by other patrons.
author: Miriam W.

description: Party under giant tents! I was really feelin this joint because it reminded me of a street in Hong Kong called Lan Kwai Fong, which consists of an alley of bars and clubs. Plus 1 from the start. So my friends and I got the table at the very back. This is your hardcore outdoor pub. I ordered the Irish cider, pleasant but w/ a strange aftertaste of sourness.. I wish they had Strongbow here! Also ordered a side of cheese fries and fried chicken strips. Loved the cheese fries, and the chicken was ok. Great vibes here, and service was friendly and attentive. Also tried Hendricks gin, since they were doing promos that night for free gin n tonics. Interesting flavor is the best way to put it, kinda tastes herbally.
author: Thomas L.

description:
I live close by and  I think this is a great after-work place to go. They have a very good variety of beers and the staff will help  you choose if you are undecided -my favorite beer there is the IPA. 

If you find yourself after a long day of work and looking to get a pint close to the financial district, swing by the bank. Thur and Fridays are the best days to go between 6 and 8. Good crowd, great ambiance.
author: Juan Camilo R.

description:
I love the fact it's in an alley. Always nice to have a Stella Artois after work and a smoke. I have met a lot of Europeans time and time again there. Good conversations. Good bar food and friendly staff. 

Not real down with the 747 hand dryer in the potty. I was sitting in the farthest stall and I still felt a draft. Not cool when your trying to tinkle.
author: monika l.

description:
I like this bar ... the Guiness is yummy! I havent eaten here but have been for drinks on numerous occassions. There are tables outside for the smokers .... 
The bar staff have always been super friendly.

Easy, convenient, lively ... and has clean rest rooms ( well i havent been in the mens .. but hte ladies is tidy like ! )
author: Amy W.

description: It's fairly cheap for the area. But honestly the bartenders suck. I was standing at the bar for five minutes on a really slow night and the guy walked past me a couple times and ignored me. I would get it if it was busy, but I am offering you my money and you walk right by me. My gf got her drinks really fast though... maybe she'll give a better review.
author: Brandon R.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed this location for happy hour with some gals after work on a Friday evening.

- Phenomenal listings of beers - what more could you ask for?
- a fun setting with a cute alleyway
- fun group of yuppie people
- good bar foods to munch on

order drinks, grab some apps to munch on and you're good to go!

Great place to start off your evening/weekend!
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: The service was good and the bar itself was nice, they were willing to put my game on even though it was out of town.
author: Aiden M.

description:
I've been a patron of the Irish Bank since I started working in downtown SF.  Over the years I've gotten to know a number of the bartenders/staff and both the current owners, who incidentally have done a lot of work upgrading the place to make it even more of a jewel.  Not to mention they're both genuine, damn good people.

The Bank is a great place to head for a lunch (be it with or without a pint).  The food is really quite good and the menu is perfectly suited for a pub.  It definitely packs up with the usual after work crowd Wed-Fri but they manage to run a smooth operation even when it gets nuts.  Factoring in the back room and abundance of covered seating outside there's *usually* enough space to find a place to sit and relax.  If you really want to enjoy it, grab some friends and go off peak on a Monday or Tuesday or stop by on the weekend.

They have one of the better Guinness taps in the city IMO and feature a mind-blowing selection of whiskey.  To top it off they have The Smiths on the jukebox (impresses me anyway).  Definitely worth a look if you've never been.
author: Ross A.

description:
You don't go to an Irish bar and restaurant and skip out on Irish drinks!  Thanks to the suggestion of my Irish friend I had a Magners Cider, very tasty and reminded me of the German Radler.

Don't be shady folks, they will check your id.  Gets nice and crowded on a Thursday night.  Service is pretty quick and easy.  Food is decent, but goes well with your beer.  Yum.
author: Yosie G.

description:
I got decent service, but my friends didn't, and it wasn't THAT busy when we went.

1 star for being an upscale Irish bar. (translation: not a dive)
1 star for having St. George, from Hangar One distillery in Alameda
1 star for my service being decent

no stars for no happy hour that I could tell
no stars for slow service for my friends
no stars for our-drinks-coulda-been-a-little-stronger

all in all, if you've got a deposit to make in your liver, don't do it at the Irish Bank.
author: Joe B.

description: I love coming here to hang out with friends or my love. It's a nice place to relax and be casual. The fish and chips is still one of my favoriates. I still remember the first time I came here and had a shepards pie. From that moment, I just fell in love. Yes, this place can get rudy and sometimes dirty, but I will come here night or day.
author: Thu L.

description: The food was okay, the place is a little cramped and fairly small. Waitresses were rude and were not very attentive. They took along a long time serving us and didn't check back on us as much as I'd hoped. My friends and I did not feel welcomed in the restaurant at all.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Love this place.  Good food, GREAT beer selection, good vibe.  Its great to be able to sit outside in the alleyway under the heaters where you can eat, drink, and smoke (I don't smoke but have many friends that do).  Food is comforting and is the usual pub grub.

The only reason they don't get that 5th star is because their Shepherd's pie doesn't quite match up to some other Irish Pubs I've been to.  Still a great place though!
author: Lauren W.

description: Been back and yes, my original assessment, along obviously with that of others, is dead on. Fuck this place and their horseshit prices. It seems like the owners do not care about their customers. Too many better places in North Beach or elsewere to spend time..
author: Jim B.

description:
Did I find my Irish soul mate tonight? Possibly.  Was his name Steven?...it was.  Did I have both Guiness and Tequila? Don't judge me!  I can see you judging, but it really was a fantastic time.  

The outdoor area is very nice, as well as the bartending/door crew.  I've only been to the Irish Bank during the week surrounding St. Patty's day, but 'tis always been a real treat.

As my Irish soul mate told me upon leaving, "now, get on with ya."
author: Kia S.

description: This place has horrible customer service. The bar manager spends most of his time scowling at people and the wait staff disappear for long stretches of time. Don't bother showing up with a group- even if you call days in advance- as they really seem to hate that.
author: Robert H.

description:
Today, as I was leaving my last client for a lunch bite, I had a vision and it included, Grilled Cheese with Crispy Bacon on White Bread. When I have a vision, I have to have it! 

I was meeting my friend for lunch at the Irish Bank and I was late, so I ordered my dream dish, as it was not on the menu. As it was not on the menu, I was not as specific as I should have been. I did not tell them to fry the bacon, so it was crispy as I wanted. I am not faulting them, but this is a lesson that if you have a vision, be sure to clearly explain what you want.

Don't go to the Irish Bank if you are on a diet! This is a place for fish and chips, BLT's, Macaroni and Cheese, and french fries! The food is good and fried, just how I crave sometimes.

The atmosphere is very homey! Where a sweater, comfortable shoes, and relax at the Irish Bank. You don't need a reservation and there usually isn't a wait, unless it is an Irish Holiday or a Street Festival.
author: Christopher W.

description:
(1PM today, ally tables)

Before i get to the food....

My friend and I ordered a Stella. When it came out, mine had lipstick on it. No biggie, these things happen. I call the server and he takes it away.... straight to the table behind me and serves the same drink to a woman...  That's that gets a 2-star.

The food... fries were good. I ordered the Rueben and the meat was dry. Not too tasty...
author: Chris P B.

description: We were looking for the perfect cozy bar in the city with some good grub. Wasn't it!! The food was mediocre at best, I'm assuming they stay in busniness because they are able to lure tourists in. Don't bother!
author: Nicole M.

description:
Oh, the Irish Bank.  That's how many of these reviews go for this place.
I've had really good times here.  
And saw some really truly dangerously drunk people here.  Well, dangerous to themselves.
A girl who fell off her chair.  Her friends just laughed.
Hmmm.  Nice friends.
author: Kev M.

description:
Great place for after-work drinking. The crowds spill out of the Pub and into the alley on weeknights. Chairs and tables can be at a premium, but this is the kind of place where you go with a large enough group to have someone snag a table for you.

They wouldn't be able to call themselves The Irish Bank without having Guiness on tap, and they also have Powers Irish Whiskey, which can be hard to find. Their bar fare is decent, nothing gourmet, but you just wanted chicken tenders anyway, didn't you?
author: Timothy O.

description:
This place is fantastic! It's like stepping into another world. I went here the other day looking for some good fish and chips, and wasn't disappointed. The fish and chips are amazing! I also had a bite of a burger and it was great too. The only downside was that the service was a little slow, but that really doesn't bother me. Who goes to a bar for food if they're in a hurry anyways? The servers were fantastic though, they seemed to work more like a team than having their own specific sections.

The bottom line:
* great food (especially the fish and chips)
* lots of outdoor seating
* good for groups
author: Thia R.

description:
Darn darn darn... I was at this wonderful place about 6 years ago and thought I'd found a true little hide-away spot that I could claim as my own and figured I'd come back more often. But of course, reality brings a different life. So yesterday I came into the city to enjoy one of those great Walking Tours and afterwords worked my way over to relax outside with a beer and dinner. I had checked out Yelp before I came, though, and saw Autumn W's review and thought maybe she was just ticked at them for some other reason.

The atmosphere is still wonderful and the help pleasant. But I ordered the "World Famous Reuben"  and well, I can safely say that I had the worst Reuben sandwich I've ever had. The "meat" was as tough as a bad steak and I had to chew and chew to get through the damned thing. I should have returned it but I was hungry and figured I just wouldn't come back. The fries were good but that wasn't redeeming enough.
And then wouldn't you know, about 1 hour later I felt that old familiar feeling and need to find a restroom. Go for the beer folks, avoid the food
author: Kyle S.

description:
I'd been here before but it's been a while so I was pleased to go back for a friend's "leaving do" last night.  Arrived around 6:15 to find the whole outside alley area packed.  Wow, I guess this is a popular happy hour area!

Great selection of beer (even for my discriminatory, beer snob friend from the UK who was visiting)  and the servers did a decent job of trying to keep everyone's glass full, despite the number of people far outweighing the number of servers.

Actually went inside to eat dinner and it came so fast, I'm sure it must almost all be pre-prepared, but neither of us complained.  Food was excellent!

Strangely enough, it DOES actually seem to be run by Irish folk...either that or they're putting on accents to impress the locals. ;-)

Definitely would head back here for a happy hour....the only inconvenience is it's downtown which I usually try to avoid at that time of the day....Irish Bank may sway me to change my mind!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I saw nothing exceedingly special or terrible about this place. It lacked any real personality, the clientele was a mixed bag, and the drinks were standard to strong.

But listen, earlier that day I was working and paying half attention to my customers when I recognized a vaguely familiar face. I did a quadruple take before I asked him if he went to my university, and we realized that we graduated in the same class (among the other 10,000 other students graduating in '06). Coincidence is a mischievous tart. Flash forward to him facebook-stalking me, us exchanging contact info, and him telling me he's in town for business and has nothing to do. 

I'm not sure why, but I felt generous. And that's unlike me. For instance, I wouldn't volunteer unless I was getting paid, which, to some sticklers, isn't volunteering.

Regardless, I decided to meet up for some drinks because I feel that it's the nice thing to do for a fellow alum. I guess the food and outdoor seating can lead to some jovial times, but getting buzzed and then having the I-just-came-out-recently bomb dropped on me isn't something I consider a slamming good time. 

Was I supposed to be witty? Cool and detached? Concerned? My 2-sapphire self couldn't figure it out. Let's face it, I was expecting to go deep into a bottle of gin, not into personal conversation. But after some awkward stammering on my part, and probably some over-sharing, I managed to recover and we had what seemed to be a pretty good conversation (at least it seemed pretty good to gin-soaked Brian). And that's good enough for sober-Brian any day.
author: Brian K.

description:
It is so funny to roll in here on a Thursday or Friday evening and find it flooded with other bank employees from the area. Schwab, Wells, Citi... You name it. 

I like the Irish Bank because it tends to fill with unpretentious young people out to mingle and have a good time. No attitude here.
author: Sahra H.

description:
This place has FUN written all over it! The inside has a great "bar" atmosphere with lots of Irish paraphernalia... The patio- that is where the gold is. The patio is great, lots of room and lots of seats. This place is tucked away and hidden enough not to be "hip" but known well enough to stay busy. 
We did not try the food- but that will come at a later time; the beer was great though!
author: Janell D.

description:
What can I say, I am always at the Bank. It always seems to fit the occasion whether it is a nice day to drink outside or a night that you want to chill and sit with friends, or a place to just grab a nightcap. Always a good time. I have never had a bad time here. 

Great Service from everybody in the bar, always a great atmosphere and they are super friendly. It is great for groups, as I just recently started out there for some birthday drinks we ended up staying there the whole night. HA! it was Fabulous! Would recommend this bar to everyone.

Its tucked in off the street and you can drink outside in the alley way with great table seating and nice environment. 

 What else can I say, I love this place. :)
author: Lisa S.

description:
This is the only confession booth I'd visit in town should it be available at The Irish Bank. Even though you're served the same grub as the rest of the crowd, the food somehow tastes better devoured in this little private space next to the bar; the burger slightly more bloody juicy and the corned beef and cabbage slightly more sinful ;-) Make sure and top off your blasphemy with a draft cider.

Otherwise, if you're looking for comfort food, look no further. The Irish Bank offers a well-rounded menu of comfort ranging from fried Fish & Chips to Banger Sausages with buttery mashers, Shepard's Pie, and old school Reuben sandwiches on Rye. 

The servers are friendly, and should you want to find them outside the bar, some of them play in the band Cannons & Clouds - great stuff.

All in all, thank you Irish Bank for making me a fan. Cheers!
author: Kirsten L.

description: Yeah, the food is great and all. But damn are those bartenders snobby if it's apparent you're not a FiDi yuppy.
author: Elliot B.

description: Great atmosphere! Very cool bar with delicious food and vegetarian/vegan options. Try the blue cheese fries. Omg!
author: Elly W.

description:
An old favorite is now a new favorite. I was hanging with Matt L. last night and I hadn't been there since I left my old job across the street six months ago. So great to see the new awnings and the two stalls in the girls room. Really, it's the little things that count.

Service is fantastic (friendly and quick). Food is great - curry fries are a must. And the drinks are not too shabby either.

Drop by when you are in the neighborhood...
author: Rachel G.

description:
When compared to most bars in the financial district, The Irish Bank is most likely one of the best; however, the fact that it is in the financial district often times makes me stay clear during happy hour - due to hoards of Cosmo drinking idiots.   If I'm around during non-happy hours, I'm always willing to stop by.   Lots of good scotch and beer and the atmosphere is spot-on. 

****bloody mary review******

Considering that any good pub should be able to make a good bloody mary, I've now had a bloody mary at The Irish Bank twice, and both times it was similarly good.  What is ironic is that their bloody mary tastes similar to the ones Natalie has served me at the Blackthorn Tavern - I wonder if this how a typical way a bloody is served in Ireland, heavy on the Worcestershire.  A quick Google search didn't come up with anything specific about an Irish blood mary - except an awful idea of combining irish cream and blood mary mix - PUKE!!!.  

What I also like about the bloody here was that they put a little HP Sauce in.   Somehow I am always impressed when an establishment that uses a unique condement to their bar/restaurant to differentiate their bloody mary.  

All-in-all has been a descent drink every time I have had one, and is served in a proper pint sized glass.  Can't say it's the best by any stretch, but differently does the trick.

Read some of my other Bloody Mary reviews at:
http://www.yelp.com/list_details?list_id=YHu-iA23Xj2c1bVa7JROhA
author: Josh M.

description:
This is our "Thursday Thing" place. After 5 hours of work and 6 hours of class, all I want is a cold Hefeweizen... or 3.

Anyways, the Irish Bank is the perfect place for me to drink my troubles away. Everyone their gets trashed and friendly. The bartenders and servers are cool. I like to sit in the confessional booth, but the back room is just as comfortable and its not super tourist-y or full of creepy FiDi scummies like some of the other downtown pubs.

I will continue to drown my school/work/like sorrows in my nice, cold wheat beer at this wonderful place.
author: Syd V.

description:
Hit the spot! So maybe I had one or three too many beers the night before. But San Francisco seem particularly bright and noisy on Sunday morning. So head pounding and stomach doing its own thing I headed to find some starchy comfort food to take the edge off. 

I know, maybe I am shallow, but I also have a thing about women with an Irish accent. So I just about forgot about the blinding lights and fuzzy teeth when the gal behind the bar soothed away my cares just by speaking. Sigh! Marry me? Keep talking, I don't care what you say, it just sounds so good! 

That aside, the food was good. Reasonable portions, hot and well prepared for simple pub food. 

A great place to hang your head and contemplate the night before even better taking another hit of the hair of the dog and the world looks a lot more of a rosy place!
author: David G.

description:
Had some folks from our UK office visiting us today and we had a few pints at the Irish Bank.  Good place to chat and have a few beers, especially if you're a fan of Guinness (on weeknights).  Bar food is okay if you like fries (I hear the curry sauce is great, but have yet to try it.), chicken strips and wings.  I would not recommend this place during St. Paddy's Day because it is always too crowded.  You barely have any room to move, which doesn't make for a very comfortable evening.

I'm not a smoker, but it's a plus that the pub is in the alley.  There is ample outside space for people to smoke and still keep your distance.
author: Annalynn C.

description:
Hmmm...this is tough.  This place has received good reviews so I feel guilty for giving it a 2 star rating, but I have a reason for my two stars...a good reason.  

Came here for lunch and ordered a Shepard's Pie which arrived piping hot, but that was deceiving.  You see when I penetrated the mashed potato surface and entered into the juicy meat, well, the meat was cold.  But I gave the dish a few chances and took a few more bites and some parts were piping hot while other parts were cold...Cold meat is not really my thing, so hence, TWO Stars.  See told you I had a good reason.
author: Karen B.

description: If you're near the financial district and craving some tasty pub grub or beer, head to the Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant.  Just be warned: it can get a little chilly sitting in that windy, shaded alley!  I had a juicy bacon cheese burger and fries.  Yeah, boring!  It was hella good, so step off!  The fries were nice and hot, and fortunately thick-cut--the big ones hold in their heat better.  Others seemed pretty pleased with the fish and chips.  They of course had a great selection of beer on tap and did up a nice black & tan for one of my buddies.  Definitely head over after a day at the office (or conference).
author: Nick H.

description: The Irish Bank is nestled in a small alley along bush st. The crowd there seemed really fun and the staff was upbeat and friendly. Earlier i the night they have tables and chairs set up in the alley . It's actually a romantic feel if your in a pub.The beer there on tap is a great selection. They have Chimay, which I love. If I am in the area I would  go back and try their food that all the yelpers are talkin about.
author: Emily B.

description:
Good place to chill after work or after dinner, tucked into a private alley in downtown sf.   Nice outdoor seating, esp on a warm day.  Extensive menu of drinks bottled and draft.  Bar fare--  hamburgers, fries, fish and chips with reasonable prices.  Wait staff is very friendly.

Would return with my friends if in the area.  ;)
author: Vickie Y.

description: Such a cute place hidden in a weird alley. The cheesesteak isn't a real cheesesteak. It's literally cheese and hunka steak. Did the Irish get it wrong?
author: Angela K.

description: Been here virtually every Friday after work this summer and I don't anticipate stopping anytime soon! (Not that I'm complaining about it!) It's definitely a great place to chill and unwind with friends and co-workers over a frosty Guinness, bloody mary (like drinking deliciously spiced salsa with vodka)  better yet a "poor-mans black-velvet. (My newly discovered favorite drink.) Their curry chips (french fries with curry dipping sauce) are amazing: hot, crispy and great to munch on while drinking. Atmosphere is what you'd expect for a pub, fairly loud, dark with lots of beer paraphernalia adorning the walls. What's really fun is if you and a small group go and sit in the "cloister"  next to the bar and chat, drink, and psychoanalyze each other while getting smashed. (Ok, so maybe you don't need to do the last part like we did.)
author: Adrian W.

description:
"Is that a leprechaun in your pocket or are you just happy to see me?" ;-)

This is my most favoritest bar in SF. It was a regular stop when I lived in SF, and I make a pilgrimmage whenever life takes me back to Northern CA. I actually like this Irish bar every bit as much as I like many of my fave Irish bars in Ireland. Without exception, something good happens every time I visit.

Things that make the Irish Bank cool IMO:
1. Barman Dave: quick, witty, adorable, from West Cork
2. The Confessional: if , like me, you were raised Catholic, drinking Magner's (aka Bulmer's) in a confessional feels a little naughty. Drinking Bulmer's in a confessional and making out with your date feels a lot naughty.
3. Clientele: Collars both white and blue, drinking together in perfect harmony. Consistently good looking and overwhelmingly straight. Note that I heart my gay men. But sometimes a girl likes the attention of straight boys, too.
4. A-OK on the jukebox.
5. Perfectly pulled pints. (See #1.)
6. Burgers.
7. Based upon past experience, friendly members of the SFFD will take you back to your hotel in a fire engine if you don't feel like grabbing a cab.  OK, maybe not you. Maybe just a couple of my friends and me. But then, how you get home isn't my problem.

Slainte'.
author: Tracey P.

description:
I am a huge fan of Snake Bite (Harp and cider as I know it) and Black Velvet (Guinness and cider) and I'm also a huge fan of being in alleys (I don't know, it just feels like you're in Italy or something with the awnings and canopy covered chairs and tables sprawled out on the concrete).

In times of the winter wind, fear not.  The alley of the Bank is accompanied by heaters and they do serve Jameson neat if the heater isn't doing it for you.

Inside, you can get the traditional Bangers and Mash, Sheppard's Pie, Fish N' Chips, etc. and sit at these really old tables (that were at one time a long, long time ago Singer sowing machines).  The place feels like a traditional Irish pub with its random barrels sitting around and black and white pictures on the wall of people that are probably actually named Shamis.  Hard wood floors (inside - not in the alley!  duh) lots of space for a Thursday or Friday happy hour, garlic fries to eat before going over to that person that you think is too cute to NOT know you (kidding - eat some gum dummy.  show some moxy, but have some class for goodness sake).

Yes, Irish Bank is a lovely spot.  I work for an international company, and every time we have our visitors from the UK over they always want to go to the Bank - guess it makes them feel a bit more at home.  If nothing else, I think it is a good indication that this place is credible.  

See you there.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
I have to admit I like it when you can barely understand your waiter when you go to an Irish bar because their accent is so thick. Really fun bar to hangout after a long days work. You can chill outside if you so choose and enjoy the crisp evenings which is always a nice option (and they do have heaters out there as well). It will get a little smoky if it's crowded outside however. 
They have your typical Irish Pub beers and food. They do have one of the better Fish and Chips I have had in the city.
author: Stephen K.

description:
The location and setting were cool enough and the fish and chips were pretty good, unfortunately that's where the positives end for The Irish Bank. 

The place was packed to the gills on the inside and pretty well crowded in the outdoor seating area, which made it so in order to be comfortable I had to stand on this walkway that spanned the alley the outdoor area was in. 

Don't dare do this at this joint!! 

For some reason this "forbidden walkway" can not be stood upon or the keepers of this establishment will oust you out on to the street, to shamelfully trodge back to the peasant shoebox from wherest thou came!! (Seriously though what's the big fucking deal about standing on a sidewalk?) 

So yeah they threatened to throw me out if I stood on said walkway, pretty lame. Prices are high too. Definitely wouldn't recommend it coming to this place unless your into asshole staff and theFiDi crowd, neither are my cup of tea.
author: Tommy P.

description: Went here for lunch.  Very cool Irish bar and restaurant, old and rustic looking.  I ordered a basic salad with grilled chicken, pears, walnuts and blue cheese with a honey mustard type of dressing.  It was very tasty, not too large for $11 though.  Everything was fine until a few hours later my stomach started bothering me.  Something I ate was not fresh.  I generally can eat anything and not get sick.  Don't know if it was the dressing or what.  Another thing that bothered me was that they had mayonnaise at each table.  That should definitely be refrigerated.  Maybe they take it out for lunch, but I would not even do that.
author: Kay J.

description: I regret choosing this place for one of my two nights in the area. Service was slow, food was mediocre at best, and the place smelled. I know drinks are pricey, but the quality of the the three I tried here were all sub par, especially for the price.
author: Chris d.

description: My girlfriend and I dropped in for the heck of it and thought the Irish Bank was a great place to put back a few Guinness and Smithwicks!  Super friendly people and staff... it helped that the weather was phenomenal and we had a whole day to ourselves.  Split our time between the alley and inside seating... kept locking eyes with black and white picture of the old lady on the wall... hmmmmmm.... luckily I didn't drink to the point where she was talking to me, but an interesting set of decor.
author: Scott P.

description:
I don't know that I would call this a dive - A dive usually has a cigarette machine that eats money, a broken table in the corner, and toilets that are always backed up...  This place is dark and laid back - but not divey.  That said, I like the Irish Bank's atmosphere.  

Good menu.  Busy but good waitstaff.  Decent beer.  Prices could be cheaper and I'd avoid the cheese fries, but I'd still recommend it.
author: Cara C.

description:
I have started a habit of getting out of class and going to the bank for a nice tasty beer.  It is a great place for a bunch of friends who want to get together and enjoy a drink and conversation.  
I have not been on weekend nights but i believe it gets really packed.  Also i have never had the food so i can comment on that.
I love how they have seats out in the alley and when it rains they have a tarp up so you can still sit outside.  If it gets cold they have heat lamps.  
If your lucky enough to get the confessional that is always fun to drink in.  But watch out for people making out in it - wooo.
I always have fun.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Overcrowded, hey Fire Department!
Homophobic, hey Human Rights Commission
Who needs this place?
author: Razza M.

description: My husband is Irish, so we checked out the Irish Bank. We loved the fish and chips! Great beer and great atmosphere! We will be here again when we return to San Fran!!
author: Stacie C.

description: Great atmosphere, outdoor seating in the alley.  Good beer selection.  Didn't eat the food.  Friendly service.
author: Vareen O.

description:
$40 for pub grub and ONE beer on a lazy Sunday afternoon?  Fool me once....

I will say that my office peeps have wandered over for happy hours a few times and have always enjoyed a good time.
author: Daryl E.

description:
So fun and divey- but with good pub grub.
You can really hang out all night with Friends or bring your aunt and uncle to the dining room. They really enjoyed it. You can even bring your baby- I love Irish people.

update: This used to be a 5 star review BUT then we ordered lunch here the other day and they charged me an extra $2 to replace my fries with salad. that wouldn't suck so bad, if had been an actual salad... what I got was a measly handful of leaves  :(
for that money I might as well go to cafe de la pressing
author: Melissa B.

description:
The cavernous recesses of the Bank! I was in San Francisco visiting an old friend who works a hop, skip, and a jump away.  She knew one of the barmen which may have been why our drinks (g & ts) were made SO strong.  My friend had a point, "When you know a friend give them two free drinks rather than one undrinkable stiffer than stiff drink." 

The place was dark, woody ----a good place to cuddle up and shoot the breeze.  We took a seat in what my friend calls 'the confessional" a wooden booth tucked away from the rest of the floor. . . not one of us could finish our drinks.  We just had a running commentary going about the smattering of pictures on the walls and the wood carvings in the benches. . . 

the alley leading up to this place had character as well. . . would be back for a pint or something along those lines. . .
author: Janell M.

description: Nice ambiance.  Good beer selection.  Service was good. Food was lousy!  I had the Ruben.  The bread was not toasted, the sauce was on the side, not much cheese.  I'll go there for a beer but I will eat elsewhere.
author: Roy K.

description:
I guess my cognitive dissonance about the Irish Bank is from the disconnect between the perceived authenticity of the physical environment there and the seemingly incongruous crowd it draws. 

What I mean is, it looks like an Irish pub so I'm drawn in by the magnetic pull of my people... and then there's nobody in there even remotely Irish and worse, it's full of all the annoying finance assholes I *don't* want to run into when I go to the pub. Add in the crappy food and not-cheap drinks, and you can see why it's a problem for me. I want to give it stars based on the wall decor, but I can't.
author: Megan W.

description:
As much as I love the other Irish bars in the city, there's something special about the Irish Bank. Maybe because it's in an alley... and my favorite Irish Bar in all of Germany was hidden in an alley near the tourist areas. I'm not exactly sure, but it just had the right craic - that feeling that you only get in an Irish Bar... warm, cozy, and like you can spend the rest of your life there in the corner, perched on a stool and drinking whiskey and stout.

The bar itself is simple and comfortable, with two televisions and a wall full of whiskeys (+1 point for having Redbreast 12 and +1 point for having Jameson 18). Guinness, Harp, Bass and Magners Cider are available on tap (+1 point for Magners) but unfortunately, there was no Murphy's Stout (-1 point for ignoring the amazing stout from San Francisco's sister city of Cork).

It's a great place when you're done dealing with the Union Square crowd, but not quite ready to head home.
author: Avery G.

description:
UPDATE: 10/9/07
What was I thinking, as a novice yelper giving the Bank 5 stars? Was I blinded by whiskey? Probably. The food here is mediocre. The service, mediocre. I waited ten minutes at the bar, staring at the bartender for any service. My friend waited, having already ordered, for her credit card, for about 15 minutes. I actually sat down and joined my group back at the table bc I believed I wasn't getting my drink.

My bf came to meet us and he got service within two minutes...hmmmm, a little suspicious lady bartender, don't ya think? 

I went back after everyone had their first drink, ready for their second. I figured, why the hell not. Apparently, it's better to go behind the bar and mix your own drink, bc the one on staff that Tuesday night didn't want anything to do with the bar, or tending to anyone's attention. 

After getting a drink that was weak, she practically threw my money down on the bar with a sulk on her face. Now mind you, I walked away the first time bc I didn't want to end up giving any attitude ( discipline, folks) but she apparently was at the end of her whiskey slinging rope!!!

***

My coworker took me here for my birthday lunch this year. God bless that man. Nothing finer for an Irish girl than whiskey, potatoes and some cake on her birthday.

I love the selection, the bartendars are great and friendly, it's tucked away so no one can see you stumble in or out to your office. The food isn't that great, but it's decent bar fare. The BLT was a little dry, but the fries were good. 

The Confessional is a great place to sit too.

We tend to make a lot of deposits...at the bank.
author: Jessica P.

description:
My boss took me out to lunch one random afternoon. We had no idea where we were going, but ended up eating at the Irish Bank Bar & Restaurant.

We both ordered Hamburgers and coleslaw with an iced tea.

Our food came out in a timely manner and the food was GREAT!!!!

The burger was flavorful and tasty! They had the condiments out for you to customize what you wanted inside of it. The long quartered pickle was on the size rather than having coin sized slivers inside =)

I wanna def. go back!
author: J-nine I.

description:
Here is the deal.

As my buddy says- this bank may need to diversify it's bonds. 

Atmosphere:
It's an Irish pub straight out of Ireland.  Except for the boys in suits who like to go out play after work and the tenders behind the counter that really don't know how to pour a Guinness.  This place gets very packed very quickly.

Price:
It's well over priced with a pint costing you about $6. 

Food:
Skip it.

However, like any Irish pub, or pub for that matter- it's really about the quality of time you will have there. I go here about every Thursday with my mates, not because we like the food (we don't) or enjoy buying rounds that break the bank (no pun intended). It's because the place -with it's alley and bar that has oak barrels to rest your pint on- is conducive to good conversation and good laughs.
author: Aaron A.

description:
I dropped in on the old bank last night for the first time in a while, and wow, look what they've done to the place. It's clean, heated, protected from the rain... they even fixed up the bathrooms. 

The food is great pub food, I recommend the burgers, curry fries, fish & chips, Sheppard's pie and now even the Ruben. They may not have happy hour specials but they are one of the few places in the city that actually knows or cares how to pour a pint of Guinness correctly.
author: matt l.

description:
I went here for lunch on afternoon during he europcup 2008.  We basically had no service and had to go to the bar to get drinks and order food.  And based on the number of patrons going to the bar from the outside area...the service kinda sucks.  It was way understaffed.  So if your looking for service, this is not going to be your bag.

The food?  It was better than most standard bar fare.  The menu had the standard bar food to be expected.   I had a BLT and fries.  Mayo was on the side if I wanted it.  Generous portions and reasonably priced for the FiDi.  I will be back but maybe for drinks only and when I am not pressed for time.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
I've got a biased opinion of this place because I came on such an interesting night.  There was a group of French Basque musician/dancers entertaining the place.  They were here on tour and just happened to be here partying all night.  One of them grabbed me to dance the second my friends and I came in (what a better way to start off the night?)  

We ate in the back and the food was sooo good (especially the fries), but the server suuuucckked!  I forget her name but she was this really pretty chick with brown hair and some black and green tattoo going down one arm.  I don't know if they have the same servers helping outside as they do inside, if that is the case then I blame the manager for setting up the floor that way.  Otherwise this chick was just extreeeeeemely slow or forgot about us every time she left.  

Anyway, we left after eating to go check out some other places and wound up at Vessel for a bit (which was rather lame) so we came back to the Irish Bank and partied with the French Basque dudes until they closed.  It was by far one of the best nights I had going out in the city.

I love the set up of this place though and the fact that it is in an alley way is very cool.
author: Jane S.

description:
i give this place 5 stars considering that i've never been there when it's crowded. i have a feeling its not my kind of place at night. Its a great place have eat fish and chips and beer downtown where as far as food goes the pickins are slim. they have a good salad, too, so you feel somewhat healthy. i like how its hidden in an alley although i don't sit in the alley (inside is cute). a respite from the hustle and bustle.

*went at night and still pleased..."we're still having fun and youre still the one!"
author: Jenna E.

description:
This is a slightly better then average example of the faux Irish Pub. They're located just far away from Union Square and hidden down an alley, so they don't get quite as slammed with tourists as Johnny Foley's. They get points for a couple quality local craft brews (e.g. Lagunita's IPA) alongside the faux Irish pub mainstays (e.g. Guinness, Boddingtons, Smithwicks, etc). The menu is serviceable with a few standout items, like my favorite the blue cheese chips, giant pub fries covered in gobs of stinky blue cheese. The requisite fish and chips aren't that bad either. The large number of big tables outside in the alley makes it more likely that you can grab a seat somewhere, or find seating for a large group. Wear something warm though, the wind howls down the alley and the heat lamps only do so much.

Where do they do fail? For starters there is a FiDi/UnionSq jack-up of prices, to about around $5.00 a pint. Then there's the hit-or-miss service. It's beyond comprehension that in a pub, you would have to sit at your table twiddling your thumbs with an empty glass, while you wait for your server to take his/her sweet time to come back and ask if you need a refill. This has happened to me 2 out of the last 3 times I've been here. In a good pub you should always end up having to hurry up and finish the last part of your current drink because they've already brought the next one. I'd be more then happy to go up to the bar and order myself, but they discourage that here.
author: Joseph R.

description:
I've been to this place a few times and I really like it. It's away from the main roads and convenient for after work drinks for those, like myself, who work in the financial district area. 

Somehow I come out of this placed only fairly buzzed and a $200 + tab for drinks alone. Bet hey, at least it's a good time.
author: Alia L.

description: Boddington's on tap and Curry Fries... I was sold within 5 minutes of sitting down. They also had a decent sized menu, and the service was great. Our food and drinks were brought out quickly, and our drinks were refilled promptly. Greatly enjoyed sitting outside in their patio area, although the inside is quite nice as well. I'll definitely come back next time I'm in the city...
author: Norma H.

description:
Found cozily in an allyway in the financial district, this Irish restaurant provides indoor and outdoor seating.
The problem I had with this place was the waiter kept forgetting some of our orders and messed up on a few. The prices are overcharged for a 'pub' and they add a 15% you for service charges for 5 people even if the waiter was really bad. 
If you like spending a lot of money for medicore food, go here!
author: Jon-o G.

description:
A super reliable, not overcrowded and friendly late-night watering hole.  Last time I was there, I had had a particularly bad day (spent the day pulling weeds out of my dead ex-boyfriend's grave.  Yeesh.)  The bartender found me some incredible tequila, the name of which I don't recall and did shots with me until I....well....until I couldn't recall the name of the tequila.

EDIT:  Jesus, the fish and chips.  I have no more stars to give!
author: Frankie D.

description:
I came. I burped. I danced! I conquered.

Allow me to explain...

I'm usually a very polite person. I hold open doors for old (sometimes even middle-aged) people, I give up my seat on the bus when old (sometimes even middle-aged) people get on, and I smile at babies and old (but not middle-aged, cause they're still young enough to be pervy) people on the street.  I always say "please" and "thank you," and my mom seems to be (somewhat) pleased by the way I've turned out. Polite, right?

Well, something about the Irish Bank throws all that right out the window. I don't know if it's the alley, or the way the Guinness tastes there, or the sort-of-secret location, but I begin to feel like I can do whatever I want and not only not be judged, but be better liked! A loud burp after quaffing a Guinness once earned me applause, and I swear that the time I knocked over a man's beer as I was showing off my jigging ability (which is admittedly negligible), he actually tipped his hat. Come to think of it, maybe people are ENCOURAGED to leave their societal manners at the door along with their inhibitions. Whether they are or not, I know I always do. Fair warning to all the old people, middle-aged people and babies at the Bank: I'll be back soon, and I won't be Mr. Nice Guy when I am.
author: Annie B.

description: good bar with a great atmosphere. people are friendly. a great place to grab a drink after work.
author: Ricardo M.

description: Found a new hangout in Union Square, The Irish Bank. As we turned the corner, into the alley we were pleasantly surprised to find the alley filled with tables and chairs. The outside of the building walls decorated with pictures and plaques with a single vine climbing the drain pipe. On a sunny day in SF we couldn't have asked for more. I give the atmosphere outside a 5 out of 5 on a sunny day. The outdoor ally seating, reminded me of Boston, very quaint. We had a drink, some good hearty potato skins (each skin was a half of a medium potato filled with bacon and cheese), and lightly battered, mostly rings, calamari. Friendly server, clean bathroom, can't wait to return. The bar was small so on a nice day outside is best but as it started to cool down the inside looked better.
author: Dianne M.

description: The food is a little above average but the atmosphere is what really makes thus place social.  The decor and it's location in an alley (complete with outdoor seating) made me feel like I was back in Dublin for lunch.  Definitely recommended!
author: Justin W.

description:
Went here with the paki playa and his friends. Was a fun bar, cool people, Irish atmosphere, loud drunk people, really nostalgic of Notre Dame bars. Only one bathroom for guys and paki playa threw up for an hour in it till they finally kicked him out. 

Would have been a good night had someone not backed up into my car and crushed my fender, headlight and bumper. ;(

if I go here again would park at a garage a few blocks down rather than right out front.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
Dear Irish Bank,

Thank you for the tequila shots, and the massive hangover.  

So.... same time next week?

Wonderful.
author: Alice H.

description:
Came to meet a girlfriend here on Friday night - I remember why I don't come here often if at all - I got a sore throat at the end of the night from having to yell at her during our conversation - it's pretty noisy inside! I owed her shepard's pie for a belated birthday dinner and although it was pretty decent I remembered why it was so good the first time I had it - It was about two years ago - I was drunk - it was my birthday and some random guy bought me (and her) shepard's pie to try to get my number - he didn't! This time around I had regular ass chicken strips and that's all it was - so not worth $8! Needless to say, I don't think I may come back again for a while.

So why 3 stars? Our bartender gal was very friendly and attentive to us, the guiness was properly poured, it was easy for us to get a seat right at the bar and Sal Castaneda from mornings on 2 sat next to me - but he didn't buy me a drink! And I thought he'd appreciated me not saying, "hey traffic guy - you lied about the no traffic on the Nimitz!"
author: Alexis D.

description:
Boo-hoo!! They tried to make Blondie sit. Whatevers!!

Well roll over girl, The Irish Bank has some of the friendliest staff in the city.
